title: Aptamer-based expansion microscopy platform enables signal-amplified imaging of dendritic spines
authors: Yuting Zhuo, Bo Fu, Ruizi Peng, Changbei Ma, Sitao Xie, Liping Qiu
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the aptamer-based ExM strategy for imaging dendritic spines (DS) with enhanced resolution. Fig 2 demonstrates the ExM's ability to expand cellular structures, showing a 4.5-fold increase in nuclear size. Fig 3 highlights the use of hybridization chain reaction (HCR) for signal amplification, significantly enhancing fluorescence intensity. Fig 4 combines HCR with ExM, improving imaging resolution and sensitivity of DS, revealing more structural details. The study evaluates early ischemic stroke by monitoring DS morphology, showing potential for early detection of brain ischemia.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution and high-sensitivity imaging of dendritic spines, allowing for detailed morphological studies and early detection of ischemic stroke by visualizing changes in dendritic spine structure.
novelty: This work introduces an aptamer-based ExM platform combined with HCR for enhanced imaging of dendritic spines. Unlike traditional antibody-based methods, aptamers offer smaller size and easier modification, improving penetration and signal amplification. The integration of HCR addresses fluorescence dilution, a common issue in ExM, by significantly enhancing signal output. This approach provides a cost-effective alternative to super-resolution microscopy, offering detailed insights into nanoscale structures without the need for expensive equipment.

antibodies_and_dyes.name: Secondary antibodies conjugated with Alexa Fluor 488

title: Light-sheet fluorescence expansion microscopy: fast mapping of neural circuits at super resolution
authors: Jana Bürgers, Irina Pavlova, Juan E. Rodriguez-Gatica, Christian Henneberger, Marc Oeller, Jan A. Ruland, Jan P. Siebrasse, Ulrich Kubitscheck, Martin K. Schwarz
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrated limitations of confocal Airyscan imaging for volumetric reconstruction of dense neuronal networks. Fig 2: Showcased the enhanced resolution and speed of light-sheet fluorescence expansion microscopy (LSFEM) in imaging expanded mouse brain slices. Fig 3: Compared contrast and resolution between Airyscan and LSFEM, highlighting LSFEM's superior performance. Fig 4: Illustrated the ability of LSFEM to resolve individual dendritic spines in sparsely labeled neurons. Fig 5: Demonstrated multicolor imaging of pre- and postsynaptic proteins, enabling synaptic connectivity mapping. Fig 6: Showed two-color imaging of mossy fibers and GABAergic interneurons, revealing connectivity details.
application_goal: The protocol enabled rapid, high-resolution imaging of large neuronal populations, allowing detailed mapping of neural circuits at the synapse level. This approach significantly reduces imaging time compared to traditional methods, facilitating comprehensive volumetric analysis of brain regions.
novelty: This study introduces a combination of tissue expansion and light-sheet fluorescence microscopy, achieving super-resolution imaging of large brain samples at unprecedented speed. Compared to previous expansion microscopy techniques, this method offers a 17-fold increase in imaging speed over confocal laser scanning microscopy, while maintaining high resolution. The use of a single-shot expansion strategy with a 3.9x expansion factor and the integration of multicolor labeling for synaptic proteins represent significant advancements in the field, enabling detailed connectivity analysis in large neuronal ensembles.

antibodies_and_dyes.name: goat anti-guinea pig conjugated with Alexa Fluor 568

title: Ultrastructure Expansion Microscopy (U‑ExM) in Trypanosoma cruzi: localization of tubulin isoforms and isotypes
authors: Victoria Lucia Alonso
summary: Fig 1: Validated U-ExM workflow in T. cruzi, showing antibody specificity by western blot. Fig 2: Immunolocalization of α- and β-tubulin in T. cruzi, highlighting subpellicular microtubules and flagellar axoneme. Fig 3: Localization of acetylated and tyrosinated α-tubulin, showing distinct patterns in subpellicular microtubules and flagellar axoneme. Measured expansion factors for nucleus and kinetoplast, demonstrating homogeneous expansion.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of tubulin isoforms and isotypes in Trypanosoma cruzi, providing insights into the cytoskeletal architecture across different life cycle stages. This approach allows for detailed imaging of subcellular structures, such as the flagellar axoneme and basal body, which are crucial for understanding the parasite's biology.
novelty: This study is the first to apply U-ExM to Trypanosoma cruzi, expanding its use beyond previously studied protozoan parasites. The work demonstrates a significant resolution gain, achieving ∼65 nm, which is four times better than standard confocal microscopy. The use of U-ExM in T. cruzi allows for detailed visualization of cytoskeletal structures, providing a robust and accessible method for studying this parasite. The study also highlights the compatibility of U-ExM with conventional fluorescent probes and inexpensive chemicals, making it a valuable tool for researchers in the field.

title: Differential labelling of human sub-cellular compartments with fluorescent dye esters and expansion microscopy
authors: Thomas M. D. Sheard, Tayla B. Shakespeare, Rajpinder S. Seehra, Michael E. Spencer, Kin M. Suen, Izzy Jayasinghe
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the labelling patterns of 14 fluorescent dye esters in HeLa cells, highlighting differences in compartment specificity. Fig 2 shows differential subcellular labelling patterns, comparing fluorescent esters to electron microscopy images. Fig 3 illustrates the use of fluorescent esters as counterstains alongside antibody-labelled structures, providing spatial context for antigen localization. Fig 4 explores interactions between multiple fluorescent esters, showing how simultaneous or sequential application affects labelling patterns.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of subcellular ultrastructure in HeLa cells using fluorescent dye esters combined with expansion microscopy. This approach provided detailed insights into cellular morphology and allowed for the differentiation of various organelles and compartments, enhancing the understanding of cellular architecture.
novelty: This study expands the range of fluorescent dye esters characterized for use in expansion microscopy, providing a comprehensive assessment of their labelling patterns in a widely used human cell line. The work highlights the versatility of fluorescent esters as counterstains, offering a broader palette for visualizing subcellular structures compared to previous ExM variants. The study also identifies factors affecting labelling patterns, such as timing of application and inter-ester interactions, which are crucial for optimizing the use of these probes in bioimaging.

title: PExM: polyplex expansion microscopy for cell trafficking studies
authors: María Navalón-López, Pau Castells-Colldeforns, Silvia Pujals, Cristina Fornaguera, Salvador Borrós
summary: Fig 1: Developed a PDMS scaffold for localized cell seeding, crucial for controlled gel expansion. Fig 2: Demonstrated the anchoring and digestion steps for optimal gel swelling, achieving isotropic expansion. Fig 3: Validated PExM with A549 and BEAS-2B cells, showing enhanced resolution of polyplexes. Fig 4: Showed temporal localization of nanoparticles in cells, highlighting their trafficking pathways.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization and analysis of polyplex nanoparticle trafficking within cells, providing insights into their spatial and temporal localization. This method allows for the study of nanoparticle interactions with cellular compartments, facilitating the understanding of their internalization and fate, which is crucial for the design of efficient and safe nanomedicines.
novelty: This study introduces Polyplex Expansion Microscopy (PExM), a novel adaptation of expansion microscopy tailored for polymeric nanoparticles, specifically polyplexes. Unlike traditional ExM, which focuses on proteins and lipids, PExM allows for the visualization of synthetic polymeric carriers within cells. The use of AcX for anchoring and the optimization of digestion and expansion steps provide a significant resolution gain, enabling detailed study of nanoparticle-cell interactions without the need for super-resolution microscopes. This advancement offers a cost-effective and accessible method for nanoscale characterization, potentially accelerating the clinical translation of polymeric nanocarriers.

title: Photo-expansion microscopy enables super-resolution imaging of cells embedded in 3D hydrogels
authors: Kemal Arda Günay, Tze-Ling Chang, Nathaniel P. Skillin, Varsha V. Rao, Laura J. Macdougall, Alicia A. Cutler, Jason S. Silver, Tobin E. Brown, Chi Zhang, Chih-Chieh (Jay) Yu, Bradley B. Olwin, Edward S. Boyden, Kristi S. Anseth
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the PhotoExM process, highlighting the mixed-mode polymerization that enhances mechanical properties and expansion isotropy. Fig 2 demonstrates the isotropy and resolution of PhotoExM, showing improved imaging of microtubules and sarcomeres post-expansion. Fig 3 showcases super-resolution imaging of hMSCs in hydrogels, revealing fibronectin deposition and focal adhesion dynamics. Fig 4 explores nuclear architecture and MT-MMP1 activity in hMSCs, indicating cell-surface metalloproteinase involvement in matrix remodeling.
application_goal: The protocol enabled super-resolution imaging of cells embedded within 3D hydrogels, allowing detailed visualization of cell-matrix interactions and cellular processes at nanoscale resolution. This advancement facilitates the study of cellular behavior in biomimetic environments, providing insights into focal adhesion maturation and matrix remodeling.
novelty: This study introduces PhotoExM, a photoinitiated polymerization method for expansion microscopy that overcomes limitations of traditional ExM, such as oxygen inhibition and hydrogel fragility. By enabling rapid, oxygen-insensitive polymerization, PhotoExM allows for uniform expansion of 3D cell-laden hydrogels, achieving <120 nm resolution. This method provides a significant improvement over previous ExM techniques, particularly in imaging complex 3D environments, and offers a robust approach for studying cell-matrix interactions in synthetic hydrogels.
source_file: Photo-expansion microscopy enables super-resolution imaging of cells embedded in 3D hydrogels.pdf

title: Label-retention expansion microscopy
authors: Xiaoyu Shi, Qi Li, Zhipeng Dai, Arthur A. Tran, Siyu Feng, Alejandro D. Ramirez, Zixi Lin, Xiaomeng Wang, Tracy T. Chow, Jiapei Chen, Dhivya Kumar, Andrew R. McColloch, Jeremy F. Reiter, Eric J. Huang, Ian B. Seiple, Bo Huang
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates the workflow of LR-ExM and compares fluorescence retention with different methods, highlighting the improved signal retention. Fig 2: Shows the chemical structures of trifunctional anchors used in LR-ExM. Fig 3: Illustrates two-color LR-ExM imaging of cellular structures, demonstrating compatibility with SNAP and CLIP tags. Fig 4: Reveals subcellular protein organizations using LR-ExM, showing detailed nuclear lamina and chromatin interactions. Fig 5: Combines LR-ExM with SIM and STORM to achieve high-resolution imaging of cellular structures, such as clathrin-coated pits.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-efficiency labeling and retention of fluorescence signals in expanded samples, allowing for detailed visualization of subcellular structures with molecular resolution. This was achieved by using trifunctional anchors that prevent signal loss during polymerization and digestion, and by combining LR-ExM with superresolution techniques like STORM and SIM.
novelty: This work introduces label-retention expansion microscopy (LR-ExM), which addresses the significant issue of fluorescence signal loss in traditional ExM methods. By using trifunctional anchors that are resistant to polymerization and digestion, LR-ExM retains high labeling efficiency and fluorescence intensity. This method is particularly advantageous when combined with superresolution microscopy, achieving molecular-scale resolution. Compared to previous ExM variants, LR-ExM offers improved robustness and reproducibility, and it is compatible with both immunofluorescent and enzymatic protein tags, providing a versatile tool for high-resolution biological imaging.

antibodies_and_dyes.name: rat anti–α-tubulin antibody, tyrosinated, clone YL1/2

title: Super-Resolution Imaging of Clickable Lipids With Lipid Expansion Microscopy (LExM)
authors: Brittany M. White-Mathieu, Jeremy M. Baskin
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the LExM process, highlighting the chemical structure of the trifunctional fluorophore used for lipid anchoring. Fig 2 demonstrates the resolution improvement in imaging choline lipids pre- and post-LExM, showing clear differentiation of nuclear membranes. Fig 3 provides a detailed protocol for preparing samples for LExM, including the use of masks for pre-expansion imaging. Fig 4 shows the application of LExM to IMPACT-labeled lipids, emphasizing the method's ability to resolve nuclear envelopes. Fig 5 presents the use of LExM for imaging alkyne-cholesterol, demonstrating the method's versatility in visualizing different lipid types.
application_goal: The protocol enables super-resolution imaging of cellular membranes without the need for permeabilization, allowing for detailed visualization of membrane structures and colocalization studies using standard confocal microscopes.
novelty: LExM represents a significant advancement in expansion microscopy by enabling the imaging of lipids without permeabilization, which traditionally compromised membrane integrity. Compared to previous ExM methods that focused on proteins and nucleic acids, LExM uniquely addresses the challenge of lipid visualization, offering a robust method for studying membrane dynamics with a resolution of approximately 50 nm. This approach leverages a trifunctional fluorophore for effective lipid anchoring, setting it apart from other ExM variants that require more invasive sample preparation.
source_file: Current Protocols - 2024 - White‐Mathieu - Super‐Resolution Imaging of Clickable Lipids With Lipid Expansion Microscopy .pdf

title: IntAct-U-ExM: Ultrastructure Expansion microscopy of actin networks via an internally-tagged actin
authors: Anubhav Dhar, Nishaant Kumar Palani Balaji, Sanjana Mullick, Sucheta Dey, Angana Ghosh, Deepak Nair, Sudarshan Gadadhar, Saravanan Palani
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrated IntAct-U-ExM in yeast, showing actin patches, cables, and rings, highlighting improved accessibility post-expansion. Fig 2: Applied IntAct-U-ExM in mammalian U2OS cells, visualizing actin networks like stress fibers and filopodia, emphasizing isoform-specific imaging. Fig S1: Optimized fixation improved actin cable preservation in yeast, enhancing staining uniformity. Fig S2: Validated IntAct-U-ExM in Neuro-2a cells, confirming isotropic expansion and actin network visualization.
application_goal: The protocol enabled isoform-specific visualization of actin networks in yeast and mammalian cells, allowing detailed study of actin structures at nanoscale resolution. This approach facilitates the exploration of actin's nanoscale organization and its role in cellular processes across different species.
novelty: This study introduces IntAct-U-ExM, a method that leverages an internally-tagged actin (IntAct) for expansion microscopy, enabling isoform-specific visualization of actin networks. Unlike previous ExM variants, this approach provides robust staining post-expansion and is compatible with U-ExM workflows, overcoming limitations of phalloidin and anti-actin antibodies. The use of ALFA-tagged IntAct variants allows for high-resolution imaging of actin structures, offering new insights into actin's nanoscale architecture across diverse cellular contexts.

title: Super-Resolution Imaging in Collagen-Abundant Thick Tissues
authors: Ya-Han Chuang, Yueh-Feng Wu, Ya-Hui Lin, Yin-Hsu Chen, Yu-Xian Zhou, Shao-Chun Hsu, Hsin-Mei Lee, Ann-Shyn Chiang, Yunching Chen, Shiang-Jiuun Chen, Sung-Jan Lin, Li-An Chu
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the successful 4.5-fold expansion of collagen-abundant tissues, highlighting minimal structural distortion. Fig 2 shows enhanced tissue transparency post-expansion, facilitating detailed 3D analysis of hair follicles. Fig 3 reveals super-resolution visualization of collagen fibers using immunostaining. Fig 4 illustrates the preservation of neuronal structures and mitochondria visualization in expanded tissues. Fig 5 compares tight junction visualization in corneal endothelium using ColExM and STED, showing superior molecular distribution in ColExM. Fig 6 maps tight junction disruption in corneal endothelium post-EGTA treatment, revealing dynamic interactions between Zo1 and F-actin.
application_goal: The protocol enabled super-resolution imaging of collagen-abundant tissues, such as cornea and skin, by achieving a 4.5-fold expansion with minimal distortion. This allowed for detailed visualization of 3D structures, including neuronal networks and tight junctions, which are challenging to image using traditional methods.
novelty: This study introduces ColExM, a novel expansion microscopy method optimized for collagen-rich tissues, achieving a 4.5-fold expansion with minimal distortion. Unlike previous ExM protocols, ColExM effectively expands tissues with over 70% collagen content, such as cornea and skin, which were previously challenging to image. The method enhances tissue transparency and is compatible with immunostaining, allowing for detailed visualization of nanoscale structures without the need for specialized super-resolution microscopy equipment. This advancement provides a significant improvement over traditional ExM and super-resolution techniques like STED and STORM, particularly in terms of resolution and molecular distribution.
source_file: Small Structures - 2024 - Chuang - Super‐Resolution Imaging in Collagen‐Abundant Thick Tissues.pdf

title: Expansion microscopy of C. elegans
authors: Chih-Chieh (Jay) Yu, Nicholas C Barry, Asmamaw T Wassie, Anubhav Sinha, Abhishek Bhattacharya, Shoh Asano, Chi Zhang, Fei Chen, Oliver Hobert, Miriam B Goodman, Gal Haspel, Edward S Boyden
summary: Fig 1: Developed ExCel protocol for expanding C. elegans, overcoming cuticle barriers. Fig 2: Demonstrated antibody staining post-ExCel, enhancing fluorescent protein visualization. Fig 3: Validated isotropy of ExCel expansion, with low distortion. Fig 4: NHS-ester staining revealed anatomical structures, aiding spatial context. Fig 5: Achieved simultaneous readout of proteins, RNA, DNA, and anatomical features. Fig 6: ExCel resolved synaptic proteins at super-resolution, enhancing synaptic mapping.
application_goal: The ExCel protocol enabled nanoscale imaging of C. elegans, overcoming the cuticle barrier to allow visualization of fluorescent proteins, RNA, and DNA with high resolution. This approach facilitates detailed mapping of synaptic proteins and gene expression analysis in individual neurons, providing insights into the spatial organization of molecular types within the organism.
novelty: This study presents ExCel, a novel expansion microscopy protocol tailored for C. elegans, addressing the challenge of its impermeable cuticle. Unlike previous ExM variants, ExCel achieves high-resolution imaging (~65–75 nm) without requiring super-resolution hardware. The iterative expansion strategy and new chemistry, including the use of N,N'-diallyl-tartardiamide and N,N'-methylenebisacrylamide, enable detailed visualization of endogenous proteins and nucleic acids, surpassing the capabilities of traditional super-resolution methods in this model organism.

title: Feasibility of 3D Reconstruction of Neural Morphology Using Expansion Microscopy and Barcode-Guided Agglomeration
authors: Young-Gyu Yoon, Peilun Dai, Jeremy Wohlwend, Jae-Byum Chang, Adam H. Marblestone, Edward S. Boyden
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the simulation of ExM volume reconstruction using electron microscopy data as ground truth. Fig 2 shows the input and output slices from the ExM simulation, highlighting the labeling density variations. Fig 3 compares real and simulated ExM images, demonstrating the realism of the simulation. Fig 4 details the architecture of the 3-D convolutional neural network used for boundary detection. Fig 5 presents the boundary detection process using the ConvNet. Fig 6 describes the agglomeration algorithm using barcodes to guide supervoxel merging. Fig 7 shows segmentation results, comparing input images, boundary maps, and final segmentation. Fig 8 provides 3-D renderings of ground truth and segmentation results. Fig 9 quantifies segmentation accuracy, showing improvements with barcode density.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the dense 3-D reconstruction of neural morphologies in brain circuits using expansion microscopy combined with convolutional neural networks for boundary detection and barcode-guided agglomeration for improved accuracy.
novelty: This study demonstrates the feasibility of using expansion microscopy (ExM) for dense 3-D reconstruction of neural circuits, achieving a resolution of 25 nm with a 20x expansion factor. Unlike previous ExM variants, this approach integrates in-situ nucleic acid barcoding to enhance segmentation accuracy, allowing for the identification of individual neurons within dense tissue. The use of convolutional neural networks for boundary detection and the incorporation of barcodes for supervoxel merging represent significant advancements over traditional electron microscopy connectomics, offering a scalable optical alternative for brain mapping.
source_file: Feasibility of 3D Reconstruction of Neural Morphology Using Expansion Microscopy and Barcode-Guided Agglomeration.pdf

title: Fluorescence Photobleaching as an Intrinsic Tool to Quantify the 3D Expansion Factor of Biological Samples in Expansion Microscopy
authors: Marisa Vanheusden, Raffaele Vitale, Rafael Camacho, Kris P. F. Janssen, Aline Acke, Susana Rocha, Johan Hofkens
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the photobleaching method to create a 3D cube in the cell nucleus, serving as a ruler for expansion. Fig 2 shows the optimization of photobleaching conditions using one- and two-photon excitation to achieve well-defined cubes. Fig 3 demonstrates the isotropic expansion of a photobleached cube, confirming uniform expansion in all dimensions. Fig 4 presents a cube with local distortion, highlighting the method's ability to detect anisotropies. Fig 5 depicts an anisotropic cube, showcasing the method's sensitivity to expansion irregularities.
application_goal: The protocol enables the quantification of the expansion factor in three dimensions within biological samples, providing a tool to ensure isotropic expansion and detect distortions without the need for additional super-resolution techniques.
novelty: This study introduces a photobleaching-based method to quantify the 3D expansion factor in expansion microscopy, addressing the challenge of ensuring isotropic expansion. Unlike previous methods that required super-resolution techniques or only assessed 2D expansion, this approach provides a straightforward and intrinsic way to validate expansion isotropy in 3D. The use of photobleaching to create a well-defined 3D cube as an intrinsic ruler is a novel strategy that simplifies the evaluation of expansion quality, offering a robust alternative to existing methods.

title: Expansion microscopy with carboxylic trifunctional linkers
authors: Xuecheng Chen, Yaqian Li, Jiabin Wang, Jielin Sun, Daniel M. Czajkowsky, Zhifeng Shao
summary: Figure 1 illustrates the synthesis of trifunctional linkers and their attachment to antibodies for hydrogel anchoring. Figure 2 demonstrates the method's effectiveness by imaging microtubule filaments in COS-7 cells, showing a peak-to-peak distance of 253±40 nm. The versatility of the approach is further shown by imaging DNA, nuclear pore complexes, and nuclear lamina in U2OS cells, achieving a resolution of ~24 nm. The method's ability to resolve individual subunits of the NPC complex is highlighted, validating the CT-ExM method's effectiveness.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the attachment of labels onto the hydrogel for routine ExM, making the method accessible to most biological labs. It allows for the interrogation of biological structures at a resolution of tens of nanometers, using antibodies, nanobodies, or click chemistry.
novelty: This work introduces a simplified synthesis of trifunctional linkers for ExM, making the method more accessible compared to previous approaches that required complex organic chemistry techniques. The CT-ExM method achieves high resolution (~24 nm) and maintains fluorescence intensity, overcoming limitations of traditional ExM. The use of commercially available materials and routine reaction schemes allows broader adoption in biological labs, extending the utility of ExM in structural biology.

title: Expansion microscopy applied to mono- and dual-species biofilms
authors: David Valdivieso González, Josué Jara, Víctor G. Almendro-Vedia, Belén Orgaz, Iván López-Montero
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the workflow for biofilm expansion microscopy, highlighting the enzymatic digestion and expansion process. Fig 2 compares pre-expanded and expanded biofilms, showing preserved bacterial morphology and organization. Fig 3 quantifies the expansion factors, indicating species-dependent variability. Fig 4 confirms the preservation of the relative position of cells within the biofilm architecture post-expansion. Fig 5 validates nanoscale preservation by measuring the division septum in S. aureus. Fig 6 explores dual-species biofilms, showing species-specific expansion factors and interactions.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of the three-dimensional architecture of biofilms, preserving the morphology and spatial distribution of bacterial species and their interactions within the extracellular matrix. This approach provides insights into the structural organization of biofilms, which is crucial for understanding their resistance to environmental stresses and antimicrobial agents.
novelty: This study optimizes existing ExM protocols for application to complex biofilm systems, including both mono- and dual-species biofilms. The work demonstrates the ability to achieve isotropic expansion of bacterial biofilms, preserving their three-dimensional structure and enabling detailed visualization of bacterial interactions within the extracellular matrix. Compared to previous ExM applications, this study highlights the importance of enzymatic digestion for efficient expansion and the potential for ExM to study biofilm-associated infections, offering a new perspective on biofilm structure and composition.
source_file: Expansion microscopy applied to mono- and dual-species biofilms.pdf

title: Expansion Microscopy Reveals Plasmodium falciparum Blood-Stage Parasites Undergo Anaphase with A Chromatin Bridge in the Absence of Mini-Chromosome Maintenance Complex Binding Protein
authors: Benjamin Liffner, Sabrina Absalon
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the application of U-ExM to visualize microtubule structures in P. falciparum, revealing detailed views of hemispindles, mitotic spindles, and interpolar spindles. Fig 2 shows that MCMBP-depleted parasites exhibit defects in hemispindle and mitotic spindle formation, with increased branch length and number. Fig 3 introduces BODIPY TRc as a nuclear envelope stain, highlighting nuclear envelope dynamics during mitosis. Fig 4 reveals that MCMBP-deficient parasites form anaphase chromatin bridges, leading to uneven DNA segregation and aneuploidy. Fig 5 presents a model of mitosis and segmentation in MCMBP-depleted parasites, illustrating the consequences of chromatin bridges and nuclear fission defects.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of microtubule structures and nuclear envelope dynamics in P. falciparum at a single-nucleus level, providing insights into the mitotic process and the effects of MCMBP depletion on nuclear division.
novelty: This study applies U-ExM to P. falciparum, allowing unprecedented visualization of microtubule structures and nuclear envelope dynamics. The use of BODIPY TRc as a nuclear envelope stain is novel, providing a reliable marker for studying nuclear dynamics. The findings highlight the role of MCMBP in preventing anaphase chromatin bridges and ensuring proper nuclear fission, offering insights into the unique mitotic process of P. falciparum compared to other organisms. This work advances the understanding of Plasmodium mitosis and the potential for targeting cell division in antimalarial strategies.

title: Visualization of F-Actin Through Expansion Microscopy (ExM) with Trifunctional Linker-Conjugated Phalloidin
authors: Jianjun Huang, Gang Wen, Thibo Iven, Débora Linhares, Leewon Koo, Markus Sauer, Wim Dehaen, Volker Leen, Johan Hofkens
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the workflow for fixing HeLa cells before staining, crucial for maintaining cell integrity. Fig 2 shows pre- and post-expansion images of actin filaments, highlighting the effectiveness of TRITON in visualizing actin structures. Fig 3 presents representative post-expansion images, illustrating the enhanced visualization of actin filaments using the TRITON linker. These figures collectively underscore the protocol's ability to achieve high-resolution imaging of actin filaments in expanded samples.
application_goal: This protocol enables the robust visualization of actin filaments in expansion microscopy by using a trifunctional linker-conjugated phalloidin, which ensures efficient anchoring and signal retention. The method allows for detailed and specific imaging of actin structures, overcoming previous challenges in actin visualization within the ExM framework.
novelty: This study introduces a trifunctional linker (TRITON) that significantly improves the visualization of actin filaments in expansion microscopy. Compared to previous ExM variants, this approach minimizes linkage errors and enhances gel-grafting efficiency, leading to superior imaging performance. The use of TRITON, combined with AcX anchoring, provides a more effective solution for actin staining, addressing the limitations of traditional phalloidin derivatives in ExM. This advancement represents a notable improvement over existing methods, offering a reliable strategy for high-resolution imaging of actin filaments.

title: Fast photostable expansion microscopy using QDots and deconvolution
authors: Loku Gunawardhana, Wilna Moree, Jiaming Guo, Camille Artur, Tasha Womack, Jason L. Eriksen, David Mayerich
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates pre- and post-expansion imaging of mouse brain tissue, highlighting the preservation of QDot labels. Fig 2 compares the photostability of QDots with traditional dyes, showing superior stability of QDots. Fig 3 further confirms QDot photostability post-expansion. Fig 4 illustrates the reduction in point spread function variability after expansion. Fig 5 shows the enhancement of image quality through deconvolution. Fig 6 compares widefield deconvolved images with confocal microscopy, emphasizing acquisition speed. Fig 7 and 8 highlight the improved resolution and structural visibility post-expansion and deconvolution.
application_goal: The protocol enabled rapid acquisition of high-resolution, super-resolved images of large three-dimensional samples using expansion microscopy combined with QDots and deconvolution, overcoming limitations of traditional fluorescent dyes and confocal imaging.
novelty: This study introduces the use of QDots in expansion microscopy, providing enhanced photostability and brightness compared to traditional dyes. The integration of widefield imaging and deconvolution significantly reduces acquisition time, offering a practical alternative to confocal microscopy. This approach addresses the challenges of signal dilution and photobleaching in ExM, enabling faster imaging of large samples with improved resolution. The work builds on previous ExM techniques by demonstrating the feasibility of QDot labeling in tissue samples, expanding the applicability of ExM in detailed 3D imaging.

title: Expansion Microscopy: Protocols for Imaging Proteins and RNA in Cells and Tissues
authors: Shoh M. Asano, Ruixuan Gao, Asmamaw T. Wassie, Paul W. Tillberg, Fei Chen, Edward S. Boyden
summary: Fig 1: Describes ExM workflows for proteins and RNA, highlighting anchoring strategies. Fig 2: Details gelation and expansion processes for cultured cells. Fig 3: Shows optical clearing of expanded brain slices. Fig 4: Illustrates gelation for intact tissues. Fig 5: Demonstrates proExM imaging of Brainbow-expressing neurons. Fig 6: Displays post-expansion immunostaining results. Fig 7: Outlines nitrogen perfusion setup for ExFISH gelation. Fig 8: Compares pre- and post-expansion smFISH imaging of RNA. Fig 9: Depicts HCR-ExFISH imaging in mouse brain tissue. Fig 10: Shows imaging setup for expanded samples on inverted microscopes. Fig 11: Illustrates light-sheet microscopy of expanded samples.
application_goal: The protocol enables nanoscale-resolution imaging of proteins and RNA in cells and tissues using conventional microscopes by physically expanding the samples, allowing detailed visualization of biomolecular structures.
novelty: This work advances expansion microscopy by providing detailed protocols for imaging both proteins and RNA, using new anchoring strategies like LabelX for RNA. Compared to previous ExM variants, this protocol allows for the visualization of RNA with high retention and resolution, and introduces methods for combining ExM with confocal and light-sheet microscopy, enhancing imaging capabilities for thick tissues and complex samples.
source_file: Expansion Microscopy Protocols forImaging Proteins and RNA in Cells andTissues.pdf

title: Nanoscale Imaging of Synaptic Connections with Expansion Microscopy
authors: Brendan Gallagher, Yongxin Zhao
summary: Figure 1 shows unexpanded and expanded images of a dopaminergic neuron in the mouse substantia nigra pars compacta, highlighting the improved resolution of synaptic connections post-expansion. The images demonstrate the separation of synaptic markers synaptophysin and PSD95, revealing the synaptic cleft. This visualization underscores the utility of ExM in resolving synaptic structures with nanoscale precision.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of synaptic connections in the mouse brain with nanoscale resolution, allowing for detailed study of synaptic organization and potentially aiding in the understanding of neurological conditions such as Parkinson's Disease.
novelty: This study demonstrates the application of expansion microscopy to resolve synaptic structures in mouse brain tissue, achieving a resolution of up to 40 nm. Compared to other super-resolution techniques like STED and STORM, ExM offers a cost-effective and accessible method without the need for specialized equipment. The use of a 7.2x expansion factor allows for clear separation of synaptic markers, providing insights into synaptic organization that are challenging to achieve with traditional microscopy methods.

title: Three-Dimensional and Chemical Mapping of Intracellular Signaling Nanodomains in Health and Disease with Enhanced Expansion Microscopy
authors: Thomas M. D. Sheard, Miriam E. Hurley, John Colyer, Ed White, Ruth Norman, Eleftheria Pervolaraki, Kaarjel K. Narayanasamy, Yufeng Hou, Hannah M. Kirton, Zhaokang Yang, Liam Hunter, Jung-uk Shim, Alexander H. Clowsley, Andrew J. Smith, David Baddeley, Christian Soeller, Michael A. Colman, Izzy Jayasinghe
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the adaptation of ExM for imaging nanoscale intracellular structures, showing the resolution of z-disc α-actinin immunolabeling. Fig 2 illustrates the adaptation of 10× EExM for imaging RyR nanodomains, revealing punctate labeling densities. Fig 3 compares RyR organization in control and MCT-RV cells, highlighting smaller clusters in pathology. Fig 4 maps the phosphorylation status of RyRs, showing a distinct gradient in MCT-RV cells. Fig 5 simulates Ca2+ dynamics based on RyR positions and phosphorylation states, illustrating diminished coupling in MCT-RV nanodomains.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of individual RyRs and their phosphorylation states within complex 3D nanodomains, allowing for the mapping of nanoscale rearrangements and biochemical modifications in cardiomyocytes, particularly in the context of right ventricular failure.
novelty: This study presents an enhanced expansion microscopy technique, achieving a resolution of ∼15 nm, which surpasses previous super-resolution methods like dSTORM and DNA-PAINT. The work introduces a method to map both the spatial and chemical topography of RyR nanodomains, revealing insights into their reorganization and phosphorylation patterns in health and disease. The combination of 10× expansion with Airyscan imaging provides a powerful tool for studying intracellular structures at a molecular scale, offering new opportunities for understanding the structural basis of nanodomain Ca2+ signaling.
source_file: Three-Dimensional and Chemical Mapping of Intracellular Signaling Nanodomains in Health and Disease with Enhanced Expansion Microscopy.pdf

title: Visualizing nuclear pore complex plasticity with pan-expansion microscopy
authors: Kimberly J. Morgan, Emma Carley, Alyssa N. Coyne, Jeffrey D. Rothstein, C. Patrick Lusk, Megan C. King
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the ability of pan-ExM to visualize NPCs and their ultrastructure, showing that NPCs are expanded and segmented accurately. Fig 2 explores NPC density and distribution across different cell lines, revealing variability in NPC number and density. Fig 3 uses nup antibody labeling to confirm the localization of nups within the NPC structure, highlighting POM121's unique position. Fig 4 investigates local differences in NPC diameter, showing LINC complex-dependent tension islands. Fig 5 examines NPC organization in annulate lamellae, revealing reduced diameter and unique stacking patterns. Fig 6 studies POM121's shift in ALS model iPSNs, indicating a pathological change in NPC composition.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of nuclear pore complex plasticity at single NPC resolution, allowing for the study of NPC composition and structure in various physiological and pathological contexts, such as neurodegenerative diseases.
novelty: This study introduces pan-expansion microscopy (pan-ExM) as a powerful tool to visualize NPC plasticity, offering a resolution at tens of nanometers. Unlike previous ExM variants, pan-ExM preserves the total proteome, allowing for comprehensive visualization of NPCs and their compositional heterogeneity. The study reveals new insights into NPC diameter variability and the role of LINC complexes in modulating NPC dilation. Additionally, it uncovers a novel shift in POM121 localization in ALS model iPSNs, highlighting pan-ExM's potential to reveal previously unappreciated aspects of NPC architecture and function.

title: Meeting Zn Needs during Medaka Eye Development: Nanoscale Visualization of Retina by Expansion Microscopy
authors: Mengyu Wang, Wen-Xiong Wang
summary: Fig 1 shows Zn accumulation in medaka eyes via dietary and waterborne exposure, highlighting different bioaccumulation patterns. Fig 2 presents ExM imaging of medaka retina, revealing detailed retinal layer structures. Fig 3 illustrates the impact of dietary Zn on photoreceptor cell development, showing toxicity at high concentrations. Fig 4 compares waterborne Zn exposure effects, indicating insufficient Zn for retinal development. Fig 5 provides RNA sequencing results, identifying differential gene expression related to Zn exposure and retinal development.
application_goal: The study enabled the visualization of nanoscale anatomical structures of the medaka retina affected by Zn exposure, providing insights into the developmental strategies of retinal cells under different Zn exposure conditions. This approach allowed for a detailed assessment of Zn toxicity on retinal photoreceptor cells, demonstrating the potential of ExM in environmental toxicology and developmental biology.
novelty: This work introduces the use of expansion microscopy (ExM) for nanoscale imaging of retinal structures in medaka, a model organism for toxicological studies. Unlike traditional methods, ExM provides high-resolution imaging without the need for sectioning or antibodies, offering a clearer view of subcellular structures. The study reveals distinct developmental responses of retinal cells to dietary versus waterborne Zn exposure, highlighting the sensitivity of photoreceptor cells to Zn levels. This approach offers a new perspective on assessing metal toxicity and retinal development, surpassing the capabilities of conventional imaging techniques.

title: Ultrastructural expansion microscopy reveals unexpected levels of glycosome heterogeneity in African trypanosomes
authors: Heidi Anderson, Rhonda Reigers Powell, Meredith Teilhet Morris
summary: Fig 1: Widefield fluorescence images of unexpanded PF 29-13 cells showed amorphous punctate structures. Fig 2: Confocal images of unexpanded cells revealed aggregate nature of punctate structures. Fig 3: Widefield images of expanded cells showed individual glycosomes. Fig 4: Confocal images of expanded PF 29-13 cells with aldolase antibodies revealed dumbbell-shaped glycosomes. Fig 5: Confocal images of expanded PF 29-13 cells with GAPDH antibodies showed spherical glycosomes. Fig 6: Confocal images of expanded PF AnTat cells in low glucose showed dumbbell-shaped glycosomes. Fig 7: High glucose conditions in AnTat cells led to dense glycosome networks.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of individual glycosomes in Trypanosoma brucei, revealing unexpected heterogeneity in glycosome morphology and composition. This was achieved by combining ultrastructure expansion microscopy with confocal imaging and LIGHTNING™ deconvolution, allowing for the resolution of submicron structures that were previously indistinguishable using conventional microscopy techniques.
novelty: This study introduces the use of ultrastructure expansion microscopy (U-ExM) combined with confocal imaging and LIGHTNING™ deconvolution to resolve glycosome morphology in Trypanosoma brucei. Unlike previous methods, this approach allows for the visualization of individual glycosomes, revealing heterogeneity in their morphology and composition. The study highlights the influence of extracellular glucose levels on glycosome morphology, a feature not observed in previous ExM or super-resolution microscopy studies. This work provides a new perspective on glycosome biology, offering insights into the adaptability and metabolic regulation of these organelles in kinetoplastid parasites.
source_file: Journal of Microscopy - 2025 - Anderson - Ultrastructural expansion microscopy reveals unexpected levels of glycosome.pdf

title: Simultaneous expansion microscopy imaging of proteins and mRNAs via dual-ExM
authors: In Cho, Jae-Byum Chang
resolution: beyond the diffraction limit of light
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the retention of mRNA signals after immunostaining, showing over 98% retention of Polr2a mRNA puncta. Fig 2 highlights the necessity of post-fixation in the IF-FISH process to prevent loss of IF signals. Fig 3 compares different anchoring procedures, showing over 95% mRNA retention across methods. Fig 4 outlines the dual-ExM workflow for simultaneous imaging of proteins and mRNAs. Fig 5 shows improved resolution of mRNA and protein structures in NIH-3T3 cells after expansion. Fig 6 applies dual-ExM to mouse brain slices, demonstrating clear visualization of GFAP proteins and Gfap mRNA in 3D.
application_goal: The protocol enabled simultaneous super-resolution imaging of both proteins and mRNAs in the same specimen, providing insights into molecular interactions and localization at a nanoscale resolution. This approach is particularly useful for studying complex biological systems like the brain or tumor microenvironments.
novelty: This study introduces dual-ExM, a method for simultaneous imaging of proteins and mRNAs, overcoming previous limitations of ExM techniques that focused on either proteins or mRNAs separately. By combining pre-gel labeling for both biomolecules, dual-ExM achieves high retention of signals and resolution beyond the diffraction limit without requiring specialized chemicals. This method provides a significant advantage over traditional super-resolution techniques, which struggle with thick tissue imaging due to light scattering, and offers a straightforward approach to achieve sub-diffraction limit imaging in 3D.
source_file: Simultaneous expansion microscopy imaging of proteins and mRNAs via dual-ExM.pdf

title: Functionalized Docetaxel Probes for Refined Visualization of Mitotic Spindles by Expansion Microscopy
authors: Gang Wen, Xiong Chen, Patrick Eiring, Volker Leen, Johan Hofkens, Markus Sauer
summary: Figure 1 demonstrates the synthesis and characterization of a new docetaxel probe for microtubule labeling, highlighting its fixability and compatibility with ExM. Figure 2 compares pre- and post-expansion imaging of microtubules, showing enhanced resolution and detail after TREx. Figure 3 presents multicolor imaging of mitotic spindles at various stages, illustrating the probe's ability to resolve fine structures in dense regions. The study showcases the probe's utility in visualizing mitotic spindles with unprecedented spatial resolution.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of mitotic spindles during different phases of mitosis with unprecedented spatial resolution, allowing for detailed observation of microtubule structures and their interactions with chromosomes. This advancement provides a powerful tool for studying the mechanisms of mitotic spindle function and architecture.
novelty: This work introduces a novel azido- and amino-functionalized docetaxel probe that overcomes limitations of traditional immunolabeling by providing dense and continuous labeling of microtubules, especially in dense regions like the spindle equator. The probe's compatibility with ExM and other super-resolution techniques like SIM and dSTORM represents a significant advancement, enabling nanoscale imaging of mitotic spindles with higher resolution than previous methods. The study's iterative expansion strategy and optimized anchoring further enhance imaging capabilities, setting a new standard for visualizing complex cellular structures.

antibodies_and_dyes.name: Alexa Fluor 488 goat anti-rabbit F(ab)2 IgG

title: Multiplexed single-cell profiling of chromatin states at genomic loci by expansion microscopy
authors: Marcus A. Woodworth, Kenneth K.H. Ng, Aaron R. Halpern, Nicholas A. Pease, Phuc H.B. Nguyen, Hao Yuan Kueh, Joshua C. Vaughan
summary: Fig 1 introduces SCEPTRE, a method combining ExM with DNA FISH to profile chromatin states. Fig 2 demonstrates colocalization of centromere-associated proteins with centromeric DNA using ExM. Fig 3 shows SCEPTRE distinguishing H3K4me3 and H3K27me3 at GAPDH loci, revealing variability in histone marks. Fig 4 quantifies histone marks at MYL6, HOXC, and LINC-PINT loci, showing differences in chromatin states. Fig 5 correlates H3K4me3 with paused RNA polymerase II at GAPDH, supporting a model of transcriptional regulation.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization and quantification of multiple histone modifications at non-repetitive genomic regions in single cells, providing insights into the variability of chromatin states at individual loci and their relationship with transcriptional activity.
novelty: This work introduces SCEPTRE, a novel method that combines expansion microscopy with DNA FISH to achieve ∼75 nm resolution in profiling chromatin states at single genomic loci. Unlike previous methods limited to population-level analysis or single histone marks, SCEPTRE allows for multiplexed detection of histone modifications and their correlation with transcriptional machinery at the single-cell level. This approach reveals heterogeneity in histone mark levels that are masked in ensemble measurements, offering new insights into the regulation of gene expression and chromatin organization.

title: Nanoscale imaging of bacterial infections by sphingolipid expansion microscopy
authors: Ralph Götz, Tobias C. Kunz, Julian Fink, Franziska Solger, Jan Schlegel, Jürgen Seibel, Vera Kozjak-Pavlovic, Thomas Rudel, Markus Sauer
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the synthesis and incorporation of α-NH2-ω-N3-C6-ceramide into cellular membranes, showing its potential for fixation and fluorescence labeling. Fig 2 illustrates the use of sphingolipid ExM for super-resolution imaging of cellular membranes and protein interactions, highlighting the compatibility with immunostaining. Fig 3 explores the application of sphingolipid ExM in visualizing intracellular pathogens and their interactions with mitochondrial proteins, emphasizing the method's ability to resolve bacterial membrane structures. Fig 4 showcases the use of 10x sphingolipid ExM combined with SIM to resolve the double membrane of gram-negative bacteria, providing insights into bacterial membrane biogenesis.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of sphingolipids and their interactions with proteins in cellular and bacterial membranes at a resolution comparable to electron microscopy, allowing detailed studies of bacterial infections and membrane structures.
novelty: This study introduces a novel bifunctional sphingolipid compatible with ExM, enabling the imaging of lipid bilayers with high spatial resolution. Unlike previous ExM variants that focused on proteins and nucleic acids, this approach allows for the expansion and imaging of lipids, providing a new avenue for studying membrane biology. The method achieves a resolution of 10-20 nm, comparable to electron microscopy, and offers a significant advancement over traditional super-resolution techniques by enabling the visualization of bacterial membranes and their interactions with host cells.
source_file: Nanoscale imaging of bacterial infections by sphingolipid expansion microscopy.pdf

title: Expansion microscopy for the analysis of centrioles and cilia
authors: N. Sahabandu, D. Kong, V. Magidson, R. Nanjundappa, C. Sullenberger, M.R. Mahjoub, J. Loncarek
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the expansion protocol using the original MAP polymerisation mixture, showing a 3.5x expansion factor. Fig 2 demonstrates the scalability of expansion by varying bis-acrylamide concentrations, achieving up to 5x expansion. Fig 3 validates the cMAP protocol, showing isotropic expansion of centrioles and cilia, with a 4.2x expansion factor confirmed by comparison with STORM and EM. Fig 4 explores centriole duplication status across cell cycle phases, using acetylated tubulin as a marker. Fig 5 and 6 apply cMAP to multiciliated mTEC cells, demonstrating its utility in studying centriole amplification and ciliation. Fig 7 confirms cMAP's compatibility with various fixation methods, while Fig 8 showcases its ability to study multiple centrosomal and ciliary proteins.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed analysis of centriole number, duplication status, length, structural abnormalities, and ciliation using conventional optical microscopes, providing an affordable and reliable alternative to electron microscopy for studying centrioles and cilia in various cell cultures.
novelty: This study presents cMAP, an adaptation of the MAP protocol, specifically for centrioles and cilia analysis. It offers a scalable expansion factor by adjusting bis-acrylamide concentration, maintaining isotropic expansion. Compared to previous ExM methods, cMAP provides a robust alternative to EM and superresolution techniques, allowing detailed structural analysis of centrioles and cilia in complex samples like multiciliated cells. The use of acetylated tubulin as a reliable marker for centriole analysis is highlighted, addressing challenges in epitope accessibility post-expansion.
source_file: Expansion microscopy for the analysis of centrioles and cilia.pdf

title: Multiplexed expansion microscopy of the brain through fluorophore screening
authors: Kyeongbae Min, In Cho, Myunghwan Choi, Jae-Byum Chang
summary: Fig 1: Compared brightness of various fluorophores in BS-C-1 cells to identify optimal candidates for ExM. Fig 2: Evaluated microtubule staining to confirm fluorophore performance. Fig 3: Assessed post-expansion brightness, identifying CF660R as superior post-expansion. Fig 4: Demonstrated 4-color ExM in mouse brain slices, revealing detailed neuronal structures. Fig 5: Compared CF and Alexa fluorophores, showing CF's superior brightness post-expansion. Fig 6: Achieved 5-color imaging by photobleaching and re-staining with DAPI. Fig 7: Verified minimal distortion after multiple expansion cycles.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the identification of the brightest fluorophores for multiplexed expansion microscopy, allowing for high-resolution imaging of complex brain structures with improved signal-to-noise ratio.
novelty: This study advances ExM by optimizing fluorophore selection, achieving superior brightness and signal retention post-expansion compared to traditional Alexa dyes. The work introduces a novel 5-color imaging strategy using photobleaching and re-staining, expanding the potential for multiplexed imaging without additional lasers. The findings suggest that brighter fluorophores can simplify iterative ExM by potentially eliminating the need for signal amplification, thus streamlining the process and enhancing imaging efficiency.

title: A practical guide to optimization in X10 expansion microscopy
authors: Sven Truckenbrodt, Christoph Sommer, Silvio O. Rizzoli, Johann G. Danzl
summary: Fig 1 outlines the seven-stage procedure of X10 expansion microscopy, emphasizing the importance of each step for achieving optimal results. Fig 2 demonstrates the effects of different anchoring and digestion conditions on sample integrity, highlighting the trade-offs between fluorophore retention and mechanical homogenization. Fig 3 provides a detailed guide for assembling a gelation chamber, crucial for successful polymerization. Fig 4 illustrates the process of removing the gel from the gelation chamber and preparing it for digestion, ensuring sample stability. Fig 5 shows the expansion process, emphasizing the importance of careful handling to avoid damage. Fig 6 details the assembly of an imaging chamber, facilitating high-quality imaging of expanded samples. Fig 7 presents methods for determining expansion factors and assessing distortions, ensuring accurate data interpretation.
application_goal: The protocol enables researchers with basic immunostaining experience and access to an epifluorescence microscope to perform super-resolution microscopy with X10, achieving a resolution of ~25 nm. This is accomplished through a straightforward protocol that includes detailed guidelines for optimization, pitfalls, and solutions, enhancing reproducibility and reliability of results.
novelty: X10 expansion microscopy represents a significant advancement over classic fourfold expansion microscopy by achieving a tenfold expansion factor in a single step, using a novel gel chemistry. This method provides a resolution of ~25 nm, surpassing the ~70 nm resolution of the original technique. Unlike iterative expansion methods, X10 does not require complex DNA-oligo-based labeling, making it more accessible and cost-effective. The protocol's emphasis on optimization and practical guidance further distinguishes it from previous approaches, facilitating broader adoption and application in diverse biological samples.
source_file: A practical guide to optimization in X10 expansion microscopy.pdf

title: Expansion microscopy allows high resolution single cell analysis of epigenetic readers
authors: Aline Acke, Siska Van Belle, Boris Louis, Raffaele Vitale, Susana Rocha, Thierry Voet, Zeger Debyser, Johan Hofkens
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the concept of ExEpi, showing improved resolution post-expansion. Fig 2 demonstrates the quantification of LEDGF spots pre- and post-expansion, highlighting the resolution gain. Fig 3 details the co-localization analysis method, emphasizing the spatial retention of epigenetic marks. Fig 4 presents the co-localization of LEDGF with various histone modifications, confirming known interactions. Fig 5 explores BRD4 co-localization with histone marks and the effect of JQ1, a BET inhibitor, on this interaction. Fig 6 analyzes the spatial organization of co-localizing spots within the nucleus, providing insights into nuclear architecture.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the detailed mapping of interactions between histone modifications and specific epigenetic readers at a single-cell level, preserving spatial information and improving resolution. This approach allows for the study of epigenetic interactions in situ, which is crucial for understanding gene expression regulation and the development of epigenetic drugs.
novelty: This study introduces ExEpi, a novel method combining expansion microscopy with immunostaining to study epigenetic reader interactions while retaining spatial information. Compared to prior ExM variants, ExEpi offers improved resolution and the ability to analyze single-cell interactions without the need for super-resolution techniques. The method's application to epigenetic drug discovery, demonstrated by the JQ1 inhibition study, highlights its potential for identifying therapeutic targets. The work advances the field by providing a cost-effective alternative to super-resolution microscopy, with the added benefit of spatial context.
source_file: Expansion microscopy allows high resolution single cell analysis of epigenetic readers.pdf

title: Accelerated protein retention expansion microscopy using microwave radiation
authors: Meghan R. Bullard, Juan Carlos Martinez-Cervantes, Norisha B. Quaicoe, Amanda Jin, Danya A. Adams, Jessica M. Lin, Elena Iliadis, Tess M. Seidler, Isaac Cervantes-Sandoval, Hai-yan He
summary: Fig 1: M/WExM protocol accelerates ExM in X. laevis and D. melanogaster brain tissue, reducing processing time significantly. Fig 2: M/WExM maintains resolution and signal-to-noise ratio, demonstrating effective immunostaining in X. laevis brain sections. Fig 3: M/WExM preserves nuclei morphology, confirming isotropic expansion. Fig 4: M/WExM increases expansion magnitude, suggesting M/W radiation facilitates expansion. Fig 5: M/WExM resolves synaptic components, showing superior resolution for subcellular structures. Fig 6: M/WExM accelerates IHC and ExM in Drosophila brains, maintaining tissue integrity and expansion efficiency.
application_goal: The protocol enabled a significant reduction in the processing time for protein retention expansion microscopy, from days to hours, while maintaining the superior resolution and signal-to-noise ratio of the original ExM protocol. This acceleration was achieved through the use of microwave radiation, which facilitated both the immunostaining and expansion processes, making the protocol more efficient and adaptable to different organisms and tissue types.
novelty: This study introduces a microwave-assisted ExM protocol (M/WExM) that significantly accelerates the traditional ExM process without compromising resolution or tissue integrity. Compared to prior ExM variants, M/WExM reduces processing time from days to hours, maintaining nanoscale resolution. The use of microwave radiation is novel in this context, enhancing both the immunostaining and expansion steps. This approach offers a substantial improvement over existing methods by increasing the expansion factor and efficiency, potentially broadening the applicability of ExM to a wider range of biological samples and experimental conditions.

title: A highly homogeneous polymer composed of tetrahedron-like monomers for high-isotropy expansion microscopy
authors: Ruixuan Gao, Chih-Chieh (Jay) Yu, Linyi Gao, Kiryl D. Piatkevich, Rachael L. Neve, James B. Munro, Srigokul Upadhyayula, Edward S. Boyden
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the design and synthesis of tetra-gel monomers for ExM, highlighting their structural homogeneity. Fig 2 demonstrates TG-mediated expansion of cells and tissues, showing improved resolution and fluorescence retention. Fig 3 presents TG-based iterative expansion, revealing detailed cellular structures with reduced spatial errors. Fig 4 compares spatial errors in TG- and PAAG-based expansions, showing TG's superior preservation of virion shapes. Fig 5 analyzes the shape of expanded virions, confirming TG's enhanced isotropy and accuracy.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the use of a highly homogeneous polymer network for expansion microscopy, which significantly reduces spatial errors and improves the preservation of nanoscale morphology and shape in biological specimens.
novelty: This study introduces a new ExM variant using tetra-gel polymers, which are assembled via non-radical step-growth polymerization. Compared to traditional PAAG-based ExM, the tetra-gel approach offers improved structural homogeneity, resulting in reduced spatial errors and better preservation of specimen morphology. This advancement points towards achieving single-biomolecule accuracy in ExM, setting a new standard for isotropy and resolution in expansion microscopy.
source_file: A highly homogeneous polymer composed of tetrahedron-like monomers for high-isotropy expansion microscopy.pdf

title: ‘Live and Large’: Super-Resolution Optical Fluctuation Imaging (SOFI) and Expansion Microscopy (ExM) of Microtubule Remodelling by Rabies Virus P Protein
authors: Ashley M. Rozario, Fabian Zwettler, Sam Duwe´, Riley B. Hargreaves, Aaron Brice, Peter Dedecker, Markus Sauer, Gregory W. Moseley, Donna R. Whelan, Toby D. M. Bell
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates dSTORM imaging of microtubules (MTs) in fixed cells, showing resolution improvement and MT bundling by rabies virus P3 protein. Fig 2: Illustrates the principles of SOFI and ExM, highlighting their resolution enhancement capabilities. Fig 3: Presents live cell SOFI time-lapse imaging of MT bundles, showing dynamic changes over time. Fig 4: Shows ExM of P3-induced MT bundles, achieving 4x expansion and visualizing MT structures using conventional microscopy.
application_goal: The protocol enabled visualization of microtubule bundling dynamics in live cells using SOFI and enhanced resolution of fixed cell structures using ExM, providing insights into the effects of rabies virus P protein on cellular architecture.
novelty: This study combines SOFI and ExM to achieve sub-diffraction imaging of microtubule structures, offering a unique approach to visualize live-cell dynamics and fixed-cell architecture. Compared to prior ExM variants, this work demonstrates the utility of combining ExM with SOFI for live imaging, and highlights the potential for further resolution gains by integrating with other super-resolution methods like dSTORM. The use of Acryloyl-X,SE as an anchoring reagent in ExM is also noteworthy, facilitating the visualization of complex cellular structures.

title: A three-dimensional single-cell-resolution whole-brain atlas using CUBIC-X expansion microscopy and tissue clearing
authors: Tatsuya C. Murakami, Tomoyuki Mano, Shu Saikawa, Shuhei A. Horiguchi, Daichi Shigeta, Kousuke Baba, Hiroshi Sekiya, Yoshihiro Shimizu, Kenji F. Tanaka, Hiroshi Kiyonari, Masamitsu Iino, Hideki Mochizuki, Kazuki Tainaka, Hiroki R. Ueda
summary: Fig 1: Chemical screening identified imidazole and antipyrine for tissue expansion. Fig 2: Developed CUBIC-X protocol for whole-brain expansion and clearing. Fig 3: Customized LSFM enabled subcellular imaging of expanded brains. Fig 4: Constructed CUBIC-Atlas, a single-cell-resolution mouse brain atlas. Fig 5: CUBIC-Atlas applied to developmental cell profiling in mouse brains. Fig 6: Revealed cell number changes in specific brain regions during development. Fig 7: Probabilistic annotation of CUBIC-Atlas identified functionally distinct hippocampal regions.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the construction of a single-cell-resolution mouse brain atlas, CUBIC-Atlas, which allows for comprehensive cell detection and annotation, facilitating systems-level analysis of brain function and development.
novelty: This study introduces CUBIC-X, a novel expansion microscopy protocol that achieves 10x expansion while retaining fluorescent protein signals, allowing for whole-organ imaging without the need for sectioning. Compared to previous ExM methods, CUBIC-X offers a balance between expansion and tissue integrity, enabling subcellular resolution imaging across entire mouse brains. The integration with LSFM and the development of CUBIC-Atlas provide a new platform for detailed anatomical and functional brain mapping, surpassing the limitations of previous voxel-based atlases.
source_file: A three-dimensional single-cell-resolution whole-brain atlas using CUBIC-X expansion microscopy and tissue clearing.pdf

title: Quantitative expansion microscopy for the characterization of the spectrin periodic skeleton of axons using fluorescence microscopy
authors: Gaby F. Martínez, Nahir G. Gazal, Gonzalo Quassollo, Alan M. Szalai, Esther Del Cid-Pellitero, Thomas M. Durcan, Edward A. Fon, Mariano Bisbal, Fernando D. Stefani, Nicolas Unsain
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates that gels with proteins expand more than gels alone, highlighting the importance of accurate expansion factor estimation. Fig 2 shows that ExM reveals the periodic distribution of βII-spectrin in axons, validated against STED microscopy. Fig 3 illustrates the 3D and multicolor capabilities of ExM, allowing detailed visualization of the MPS in dense axonal fields. Fig 4 quantitatively validates ExM against STED, showing similar periodic structures and MPS remodeling during axon degeneration.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the quantitative characterization of the membrane-associated periodic skeleton (MPS) in axons using accessible reagents and conventional fluorescent microscopes, making it feasible for neurobiology laboratories to study this structure without the need for high-end super-resolution microscopy equipment.
novelty: This study presents a calibrated and validated expansion microscopy protocol that allows for the quantitative study of the spectrin MPS in neurons using conventional microscopy. Unlike previous ExM variants, this approach provides a straightforward method to achieve nanoscale resolution without specialized equipment, making it accessible to a broader range of research groups. The work highlights the importance of accurate expansion factor estimation, which was achieved by measuring cellular protein structures, and demonstrates that ExM can yield results comparable to STED nanoscopy, particularly in the study of axonal structures.
source_file: Quantitative expansion microscopy for the characterization of the spectrin periodic skeleton of axons using fluorescence microscopy.pdf

title: Toward High Spatially Resolved Proteomics Using Expansion Microscopy
authors: Lauranne Drelich, Soulaimane Aboulouard, Julien Franck, Michel Salzet, Isabelle Fournier, Maxence Wisztorski
summary: Fig 1: The workflow for tissue expansion and proteomics analysis is outlined, highlighting the expansion and sampling phases. Fig 2: Various homogenization agents are compared, showing SDS as the most effective for protein retention. Fig 3: Reproducibility of protein identification using SDS is demonstrated across tissue sections. Fig 4: Use of a biopsy punch improves sampling reproducibility, enhancing protein identification consistency. Fig 5: Spatial proteomics profiling is achieved, mapping protein distribution across tissue sections.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the spatially resolved proteomics analysis of tissue sections, allowing for the identification of over 655 proteins from regions as small as 330 μm. This approach facilitates the study of tissue heterogeneity and protein distribution without the need for expensive instrumentation.
novelty: This study introduces a modified expansion microscopy protocol that replaces proteinase K with SDS for homogenization, reducing protein loss and improving protein retention. The method achieves a 3-fold expansion of FFPE tissue sections, allowing for detailed proteomic analysis of small regions. Compared to previous ExM variants, this approach offers improved protein identification and spatial resolution, enabling more precise mapping of protein distributions in tissue samples.

title: Using Expansion Microscopy to Visualize and Characterize the Morphology of Mitochondrial Cristae
authors: Tobias C. Kunz, Ralph Götz, Shiqiang Gao, Markus Sauer, Vera Kozjak-Pavlovic
summary: Fig 1: Compared confocal, SIM, and ExM imaging of MtCK-GFP labeled mitochondria, showing improved resolution with ExM. Fig 2: Demonstrated ExM's ability to resolve mitochondrial proteins' localization relative to cristae using confocal microscopy. Fig 3: Used SIM-ExM to show PRX3, Mic60, and TFAM localization in relation to cristae. Fig 4: Conducted 3-color ExM to compare mitochondrial proteins' localization, highlighting TFAM's proximity to cristae junctions. Fig 5: Visualized cristae morphology changes after CCCP treatment and Sam50 knockdown using ExM.
application_goal: The protocol enabled visualization of mitochondrial cristae morphology and protein localization using conventional confocal microscopy, without the need for specialized super-resolution setups. This approach allows for detailed studies of mitochondrial structure and protein interactions, facilitating research into mitochondrial function and pathology.
novelty: This study presents a novel application of expansion microscopy combined with SIM to achieve near-super-resolution imaging of mitochondrial cristae on conventional confocal microscopes. By using MtCK-GFP as a cristae marker, the study circumvents the need for specialized super-resolution equipment, making high-resolution imaging more accessible. The work highlights the potential of ExM to resolve mitochondrial structures and protein localizations with a resolution comparable to advanced super-resolution techniques like STED and dSTORM, but with simpler and more widely available equipment.
source_file: Using Expansion Microscopy to Visualize and Characterize the Morphology of Mitochondrial Cristae.pdf

title: Super-resolution co-imaging of proteins and nucleic acids on expansion microscopy
authors: Ziqing Yuan, Jiasu Xu, Luyao Li, Hongxia Li, Jie He, Kaiwen Bao, Lai Jiang, Guangxia Shen, Xianting Ding
summary: Fig 1 introduces Phan-ExM, a method using MAP-mPyTC for rapid anchoring of proteins and nucleic acids, reducing time to 10 minutes. Fig 2 demonstrates high-resolution imaging of microtubules in HeLa cells, achieving 85 nm resolution post-expansion. Fig 3 shows Phan-ExM's capability to visualize mRNA with high retention and improved signal-to-noise ratio. Fig 4 illustrates simultaneous co-visualization of Golgin-97 protein and GAPDH mRNA, highlighting improved resolution and co-localization accuracy. Fig 5 explores the impact of microtubule dynamics on mitochondrial morphology and ACTB mRNA distribution in BALB/c3T3 cells, revealing mRNA aggregation at sites of mitochondrial damage.
application_goal: The protocol enabled simultaneous super-resolution imaging of proteins and nucleic acids on a single specimen using a conventional microscope, significantly reducing anchoring time and enhancing fluorescence intensity.
novelty: Phan-ExM introduces a novel photoclick anchoring reagent, MAP-mPyTC, which allows for rapid and efficient co-anchoring of proteins and nucleic acids within 10 minutes. This represents a significant advancement over traditional ExM methods that require separate anchoring steps and longer processing times. The method achieves a resolution of approximately 85 nm, comparable to super-resolution techniques, but with the simplicity and accessibility of conventional microscopy. This work streamlines the ExM process, enabling broader adoption and application in biological research.

title: Applying the Expansion Microscopy Method in Neurobiology
authors: K. Z. Derevtsova, E. I. Pchitskaya, A. V. Rakovskaya, I. B. Bezprozvanny
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the gel polymerization chamber setup for embedding brain sections. Fig 2 shows the preparation of brain slices for polymerization. Fig 3 demonstrates handling of gel samples to prevent breakage. Fig 4 compares the size of brain slices before and after expansion, highlighting the 4.5x increase. Fig 5 and 6 present confocal images of neurons before and after expansion, showing enhanced visualization of dendritic spines. Fig 7 and 8 display two-color micrographs of neurons expressing GFP and IP3R, demonstrating the protocol's ability to maintain fluorescence post-expansion.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of nanoscale structures in brain tissue using conventional microscopy by expanding the samples, allowing detailed study of neuronal morphology and protein localization without the need for ultra-high resolution equipment.
novelty: This study demonstrates an adapted expansion microscopy protocol that maintains fluorescence of endogenous and immunostained proteins, enabling detailed visualization of neuronal structures. Compared to previous ExM methods, this approach optimizes the balance between expansion and fluorescence retention, allowing for effective study of protein colocalization and morphology in neurobiological samples. The use of MA-NHS and Acryloyl-X for direct protein cross-linking represents an advancement over traditional DNA-oligonucleotide conjugation, simplifying the process and reducing costs associated with antibody preparation.

title: Microtubules as a versatile reference standard for expansion microscopy
authors: Rajdeep Chowdhury, Tiago Mimoso, Abed Alrahman Chouaib, Nikolaos Mougios, Donatus Krah, Felipe Opazo, Sarah Köster, Silvio O. Rizzoli, Ali H. Shaib
summary: Fig 1: Microtubules in HeLa cells were immunostained and expanded using X10 ExM, demonstrating satisfactory labeling and size validation with STED microscopy. Fig 2: Comparison of microtubule labeling using secondary antibodies and nanobodies showed reduced linkage error with nanobodies. Fig 3: Direct labeling of microtubules using NHS-ester chemistry after detergent extraction improved labeling accuracy, enabling high-resolution imaging. Fig 4: In vitro assembled microtubules were analyzed, revealing challenges in fixation and anchoring, but NHS-ester labeling allowed visualization of microtubule organization.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the use of microtubules as a reliable reference standard for validating expansion microscopy techniques, providing a method to achieve high-resolution imaging of microtubules both in cellular and cell-free environments.
novelty: This study introduces a protocol for using microtubules as a reference standard in expansion microscopy, addressing challenges in fixation and anchoring. Compared to previous ExM variants, this approach offers improved labeling accuracy through NHS-ester chemistry and detergent extraction, allowing for high-resolution imaging. The work highlights the potential of microtubules as nanorulers, providing a simpler and more reliable alternative to DNA origami and other protein-based nanorulers, which are less suitable for ExM due to their integration challenges.

title: Improved Dye Survival in Expansion Microscopy through Stabilizer-Conjugated Linkers
authors: Gang Wen, Volker Leen, Yuqing Jia, Taoufik Rohand, Johan Hofkens
summary: Fig 1: Introduces the concept of stabilizer-containing multifunctional molecules to protect dyes from radicals during ExM, enhancing dye survival. Fig 2: Demonstrates the improved signal retention of NPA-modified dyes compared to regular dyes during polymerization. Fig 3: Shows the increased quantum yield of NPA-modified dyes in polymer, indicating effective protection. Fig 4: Details the synthesis of tetrafunctional molecules incorporating NPA for dye stabilization. Fig 5: Validates the improved fluorescence intensity and photostability of microtubules and actin filaments using NPA-modified linkers in ExM, compared to traditional methods.
application_goal: The protocol enabled improved fluorescent signal retention and photostability of dyes during the polymerization process in expansion microscopy, allowing for clearer and more stable imaging of biological structures such as microtubules and actin filaments.
novelty: This study introduces stabilizer-conjugated linkers, specifically NPA-modified linkers, to enhance dye survival during the radical polymerization step of ExM. Compared to previous ExM variants, this approach significantly improves fluorescent signal retention and photostability without compromising polymerization efficiency. The work provides a novel strategy for integrating photostabilizers directly into the ExM process, offering a substantial advancement over traditional methods that suffer from dye degradation.
source_file: Chemistry A European J - 2022 - Wen - Improved Dye Survival in Expansion Microscopy through Stabilizer‐Conjugated Linkers.pdf

title: Expansion microscopy of the chick embryo neural tube to overcome molecular crowding at the centrosomes-cilia
authors: Axelle Wilmerding, Paula Espana-Bonilla, Nikolaos-Nikiforos Giakoumakis, Murielle Saade
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the preparation of chick embryo neural tube (NT) for expansion microscopy, highlighting the electroporation and dissection steps. Fig 2 details the gelation and expansion process, showing the polymerization and expansion of the NT samples. Fig 3 presents the imaging results, demonstrating the enhanced resolution of centrosomes and cilia structures using Fast Airyscan. The figures collectively emphasize the protocol's ability to achieve nanoscale resolution in complex tissue samples.
application_goal: The protocol enables nanoscale imaging of centrosomes and cilia in chick neural tube tissues, overcoming molecular crowding and retaining fluorescence signals, which were previously only achievable with electron microscopy.
novelty: This study presents an optimized expansion microscopy protocol for chick neural tube, achieving sub-50 nm resolution. Compared to previous ExM variants, this protocol integrates Fast Airyscan for enhanced resolution and speed, and uses a specific anchoring strategy with Acryloyl-X. The work extends ExM applications to complex tissues, providing a significant advancement over traditional electron microscopy by allowing fluorescence-based nanoscale imaging in a biological context.
