title: Expansion microscopy of zebrafish for neuroscience and developmental biology studies
authors: Limor Freifeld, Iris Odstrcil, Dominique Förster, Alyson Ramirez, James A. Gagnon, Owen Randlett, Emma K. Costa, Shoh Asano, Orhan T. Celiker, Ruixuan Gao, Daniel A. Martin-Alarcon, Paul Reginato, Cortni Dick, Linlin Chen, David Schoppik, Florian Engert, Herwig Baier, Edward S. Boyden
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates ExM's ability to resolve fine cellular processes in zebrafish tectum, enhancing visibility of radial glial cells. Fig 2 shows ExM's utility in mapping synaptic connections in the zebrafish brain, revealing synaptic varicosities and molecular composition. Fig 3 highlights ExM's capability to resolve subsynaptic structures, such as glycine receptor rings, in the Mauthner cell. Fig 4 explores ExM's application in developmental biology, visualizing nuclear invaginations and microtubule organization in zebrafish embryos. Fig 5 and 6 detail ExM's role in elucidating nuclear architecture during cell division, revealing intranuclear channels in prophase and telophase nuclei.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed visualization of cellular and subcellular structures in zebrafish, facilitating studies of neural circuitry and developmental processes. ExM allowed for the tracing of fine cellular processes, mapping of synaptic connections, and analysis of nuclear architecture, providing insights into the molecular organization of cells in neuroscience and developmental biology contexts.
novelty: This study applies ExM to zebrafish, a model organism not extensively explored with this technique before. Compared to prior ExM variants, this work demonstrates the method's ability to resolve fine cellular structures and synaptic details in whole zebrafish brains and embryos, which are challenging for traditional super-resolution methods due to depth limitations. The study also introduces the use of ExM in developmental biology, revealing nuclear invaginations and their potential roles in cell division, highlighting ExM's versatility and potential for broad biological applications.
source_file: Expansion microscopy of zebrafish for neuroscienceand developmental biology studies.pdf

title: C. elegans: Methods and Applications, Third Edition
authors: Gal Haspel, Anne C. Hart
summary: Fig 1: Introduction to setting up a C. elegans research lab, focusing on community resources and equipment. Fig 2: Detailed guidance on maintaining C. elegans cultures, including picking and chunking methods. Fig 3: Description of chemotaxis assays to study C. elegans behavior, highlighting the use of mutant strains. Fig 4: Discussion on inclusive teaching practices in laboratory settings, emphasizing student engagement and diversity.
application_goal: The protocol enables the study of genetic mutations and their effects on C. elegans behavior, providing a hands-on learning experience for students in understanding the connection between genes and behavior.
novelty: This work provides a comprehensive guide for setting up a C. elegans research lab and conducting behavioral assays, with a focus on educational applications. It emphasizes the use of C. elegans as a model organism for teaching genetics and neuroscience, offering practical advice for maintaining cultures and conducting experiments. The inclusion of inclusive teaching practices is a notable addition, aiming to create a supportive learning environment.

title: Rapid lightsheet fluorescence imaging of whole Drosophila brains at nanoscale resolution by potassium acrylate-based expansion microscopy
authors: Xuejiao Tian, Tzu-Yang Lin, Po-Ting Lin, Min-Ju Tsai, Hsin Chen, Wen-Jie Chen, Chia-Ming Lee, Chiao-Hui Tu, Jui-Cheng Hsu, Tung-Han Hsieh, Yi-Chung Tung, Chien-Kai Wang, Suewei Lin, Li-An Chu, Fan-Gang Tseng, Yi-Ping Hsueh, Chi-Hon Lee, Peilin Chen, Bi-Chang Chen
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the synthesis of KA hydrogels and their application to expand Drosophila brains, enabling imaging with a Bessel lightsheet microscope. Fig 2 compares pre- and post-expansion images, highlighting the improved resolution of synaptic structures. Fig 3 explores PKA-based expansion, achieving a 15x expansion factor, and visualizes sub-synaptic structures. Fig 4 presents iterative expansion to 32x, showing detailed cellular structures. Fig 5 segments Tm5a neurons in the optic lobe, revealing intricate dendritic processes. Fig 6 provides a 3D skeletonization of Tm5a neurons, illustrating their spatial arrangement. Fig 7 showcases multicolor imaging of L3 neurons and photoreceptors, demonstrating synaptic connections. Fig 8 maps mitochondria and Bruchpilot proteins, validating the high resolution of the method.
application_goal: The protocol enabled rapid, high-resolution imaging of whole Drosophila brains, allowing visualization of nanoscale structures such as synaptic compartments and scaffold proteins. This approach facilitates detailed mapping of neural architecture and molecular organization within large biological samples.
novelty: This study introduces a potassium acrylate-based expansion microscopy technique that achieves a 40x plus expansion factor, significantly enhancing resolution to nanoscale levels. Compared to previous ExM variants, this method offers improved mechanical strength and stability, allowing for the imaging of large, intact samples like whole Drosophila brains. The combination with Bessel lightsheet microscopy provides rapid, volumetric imaging capabilities, surpassing the limitations of traditional super-resolution methods. The novel use of potassium acrylate and polyacrylate monomers, along with iterative expansion, represents a significant advancement in the field, enabling detailed visualization of complex neural structures and biomolecular distributions.

title: Fluorescence Lifetime Multiplex Imaging in Expansion Microscopy with Tunable Donor−Acceptor Polymer Dots
authors: Jie Liu, Zhihe Liu, Feixue Mi, Zihan Yao, Xiaofeng Fang, Yingjie Wang, Zhongying Zhao, Changfeng Wu
summary: Fig 1 characterizes the lifetime-multiplexed Pdots, showing their size and lifetime distributions. Fig 2 demonstrates the use of Pdots for lifetime multiplexing on magnetic beads, highlighting their potential for barcoding. Fig 3 presents FLIM images of subcellular structures labeled with Pdots, indicating high specificity and photon output. Fig 4 validates the isotropy of FLEM imaging, showing negligible distortion and high resolution. Fig 5 illustrates dual-color FLEM imaging, resolving subcellular structures with enhanced resolution.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of subcellular structures with high specificity and resolution using fluorescence lifetime multiplex imaging in expansion microscopy. The use of tunable donor-acceptor polymer dots allowed for lifetime-based multiplexing, enhancing the spatial resolution of FLIM systems to ∼49 nm, which is unattainable by conventional methods.
novelty: This study introduces the use of semiconducting polymer dots with tunable lifetimes for fluorescence lifetime multiplex imaging in expansion microscopy. Compared to prior ExM variants, this approach achieves a spatial resolution of ∼49 nm, surpassing conventional FLIM limitations. The novel use of donor-acceptor polymer dots provides a high photon budget and distinct lifetime distributions, enabling lifetime multiplexing and enhancing the resolution of subcellular imaging. This work represents a significant advancement in combining ExM with FLIM, offering new possibilities for super-resolution imaging.

title: Expansion microscopy reveals neural circuit organization in genetic animal models
authors: Shakila Behzadi, Jacquelin Ho, Zainab Tanvir, Gal Haspel, Limor Freifeld, Kristen E. Severi
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the major steps of an expansion microscopy protocol, highlighting the anchoring, gelation, digestion, and expansion phases. Fig 2 presents variations of ExM, including proExM, iExM, and 20ExM, showcasing their applications in different model organisms. The paper reviews the application of ExM in zebrafish to resolve synaptic connectivity and protein organization, in mice for deep brain region mapping, in Drosophila for high-resolution brain imaging, and in C. elegans for resolving synaptic structures. The study emphasizes the versatility of ExM in enhancing resolution and accessibility of neural structures across species.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of previously unresolvable subcellular and nano-structures associated with synapses and neuronal processes, enhancing the understanding of neural circuit organization and function across various model organisms.
novelty: This work places ExM in context by comparing it with prior super-resolution methods like STED and STORM, highlighting its accessibility and scalability. The study introduces new chemistry and anchoring strategies, such as the use of AcX and DMAA, and demonstrates significant resolution gains, achieving up to 20x expansion. The ability to apply ExM to large tissue volumes and various organisms without specialized equipment marks a significant advancement in the field.

title: Following the cellular itinerary of renal aquaporin-2 shuttling with 4.5x expansion microscopy
authors: Frédéric H. Login, Vibeke S. Dam, Lene N. Nejsum
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the use of 4.5x ExM to visualize AQP2 vesicular structures, highlighting the method's resolution. Fig 2 shows AQP2 localization changes in response to forskolin, indicating cAMP-mediated shuttling. Fig 3 quantifies AQP2 vesicle sizes, revealing the smallest detectable structures. Fig 4 explores AQP2 association with endosomal markers before cAMP elevation, showing colocalization with early and recycling endosomes. Fig 5 illustrates AQP2 targeting to the plasma membrane upon forskolin treatment, with limited endosomal association. Fig 6 and 7 detail AQP2 endocytosis and sorting to late endosomes and lysosomes following forskolin washout, emphasizing the dynamic trafficking process.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed visualization of AQP2 shuttling between intracellular vesicles and the plasma membrane in response to cAMP level changes, providing insights into the regulation of renal water reabsorption at a nanoscale level.
novelty: This study leverages 4.5x expansion microscopy to achieve a resolution of 60-70 nm, surpassing conventional fluorescence microscopy's limitations. The work provides unprecedented detail on AQP2 vesicular trafficking, particularly in visualizing small transport vesicles and their dynamic interactions with endosomal compartments. Compared to prior ExM variants, this approach offers enhanced visualization of protein localization and trafficking pathways, contributing to a deeper understanding of cellular processes involved in water reabsorption regulation.

title: Expansion microscopy of apicomplexan parasites
authors: Benjamin Liffner, Sabrina Absalon
summary: Fig 1: Introduction of U-ExM technique for apicomplexan parasites, highlighting its utility in studying small-scale structures. Fig 2: Application of U-ExM to Toxoplasma gondii, demonstrating improved visualization of rhoptries. Fig 3: Use of U-ExM in Plasmodium species, showing enhanced imaging of merozoite nuclei. Fig 4: Overview of U-ExM studies in Apicomplexa, summarizing findings across multiple species and lifecycle stages.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed visualization of subcellular structures in apicomplexan parasites, which are otherwise challenging to study due to their small size. By physically expanding the samples, U-ExM allows researchers to use standard fluorescence microscopy to investigate cellular components that are typically below the resolution limit of conventional light microscopy.
novelty: This work places U-ExM as a pivotal tool in parasitology, offering a cost-effective and accessible alternative to super-resolution techniques like STED or SMLM. Unlike previous methods that require specialized equipment, U-ExM uses commercially available reagents and standard lab equipment, making it widely adoptable. The study highlights the technique's ability to maintain isotropic expansion and structural integrity, providing new insights into the cell biology of parasites such as Toxoplasma and Plasmodium, which were previously difficult to achieve with traditional microscopy.

title: Expansion microscopy-based imaging of nuclear structures in cultured cells
authors: Antoine Gaudreau-Lapierre, Kirk Mulatz, Jean-Claude Be´ ı¨que, Laura Trinkle-Mulcahy
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the tenfold expansion of fixed and stained cultured cells with concurrent DNA staining, highlighting the use of a custom 3D-printed gel cutter to minimize drift. Fig 2 shows Airyscan and Imaris-based imaging and volume rendering of nuclear structures, emphasizing the nanoscale resolution achieved. Fig 3 details the approach to calculate the expansion factor using Fiji open-source software, providing a method for accurate measurement. Fig 4 illustrates the imaging of expansion gels using various microscopy systems, showcasing the enhanced detail and resolution. Fig 5 presents the 3D visualization of nuclear substructures, confirming the spatial relationships between fluorophore-labeled proteins.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of nuclear structures in cultured human cells at nanoscale resolution, allowing for detailed analysis of the spatial relationships between fluorophore-labeled proteins. The use of a custom gel cutter and chambered slides minimized gel drift, facilitating high-resolution imaging with conventional and Airyscan confocal microscopy.
novelty: This study employs the X10 expansion microscopy method, achieving a tenfold expansion of U2OS cells, which is a significant improvement over the original 4.5x expansion factor. The integration of a custom 3D-printed gel cutter to minimize drift during imaging is a novel approach that enhances the stability and accuracy of the imaging process. Compared to prior ExM variants, this protocol offers a streamlined workflow with improved resolution and compatibility with Airyscan imaging, providing a powerful tool for super-resolution microscopy of nuclear structures.

title: Protein-retention expansion microscopy for visualizing subcellular organelles in fixed brain tissue
authors: Logan A. Campbell, Katy E. Pannoni, Niesha A. Savory, Dinesh Lal, Shannon Farris
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the proExM workflow for visualizing organelles in fixed brain tissue, highlighting the importance of IHC timing. Fig 2 compares COX4-mitochondria labeling under different digestion conditions, showing that IHC-pre with proteinase K preserves fluorescence best. Fig 3 evaluates GOLGA5-Golgi labeling, confirming that IHC-pre with proteinase K is optimal for both Golgi and reporter labeling. Fig 4 presents a digestion time course, indicating that 8-hour digestion balances expansion and fluorescence retention. Fig 5 demonstrates minimal distortion and enhanced resolution of Golgi structures post-expansion.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of subcellular organelles such as mitochondria and Golgi apparatus in fixed mouse brain tissue with improved resolution, allowing for more accurate quantification of organelle size and number, and better visualization of ultrastructural details.
novelty: This study optimizes a 4x proExM protocol for fixed brain tissue, achieving ~70 nm resolution without requiring super-resolution microscopy. Compared to prior ExM variants, this protocol balances fluorescence retention and expansion factor, using proteinase K digestion to enhance visualization of densely packed organelles. The work advances the field by providing a robust method for organelle imaging in complex tissues, addressing challenges of fluorescence loss and sample distortion.

title: Quantifying Expansion Microscopy with DNA Origami Expansion Nanorulers
authors: Max B. Scheible, Philip Tinnefeld
summary: Fig 1: DNA origami nanorulers are modified with ATTO 647N dyes and acrydite groups to crosslink to a polymer matrix, enabling expansion microscopy. Fig 2: The expansion factor is determined by comparing pre- and post-expansion distances of nanoruler marks, showing a macroscopic expansion factor of 3.6. Fig 3: Quantitative analysis of expanded nanorulers reveals a microscopic expansion factor of 2.8, highlighting deviations from macroscopic measurements and the homogeneity of expansion.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the quantification of expansion microscopy by using DNA origami nanorulers as in situ measurement standards. This approach allows for the determination of microscopic expansion factors and provides insights into the homogeneity and isotropy of the expansion process, which is crucial for accurate interpretation of expansion microscopy data.
novelty: This work introduces DNA origami nanorulers as a novel tool for quantifying expansion in expansion microscopy, addressing the challenge of correlating macroscopic and microscopic expansion factors. Unlike previous ExM techniques, this study provides a method to evaluate the homogeneity and isotropy of expansion, which is essential for accurate quantitative analysis. The use of DNA nanotechnology in this context is innovative, offering a new standard for measuring expansion and potentially improving the resolution and reliability of ExM data.
source_file: Quantifying Expansion Microscopy with DNA Origami Expansion Nanorulers.pdf

title: Pre-gelation staining expansion microscopy for visualisation of the Plasmodium liver stage
authors: Kodzo Atchou, Bianca Manuela Berger, Volker Heussler, Torsten Ochsenreiter
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the PS-ExM workflow and quantifies the expansion factor, showing a 5-fold isotropic expansion of Plasmodium liver stage parasites. Fig 2 illustrates the entire Plasmodium liver stage development using PS-ExM, highlighting the interaction between host lysosomes and the parasitophorous vacuole membrane. Fig 3 provides detailed images of the interaction between host lysosomes and the parasite PVM, revealing lysosome fusion with the PVM. Fig 4 showcases the preservation of mitochondrial networks in Plasmodium parasites post-expansion, using antibodies against TgHSP70.
application_goal: The PS-ExM protocol enabled the visualization of intracellular Plasmodium parasites during the liver stage, preserving the structural integrity of host and parasite organelles, and allowing for detailed studies of host-pathogen interactions, particularly the fusion of host lysosomes with the parasitophorous vacuole membrane.
novelty: This study introduces a pre-gelation staining expansion microscopy (PS-ExM) protocol that significantly reduces the time required for expansion microscopy while preserving epitope integrity better than traditional U-ExM. Unlike previous methods, PS-ExM allows for simultaneous preparation of expanded and non-expanded samples, facilitating direct comparisons. The protocol's ability to maintain the structural integrity of both host and parasite organelles, such as mitochondria and lysosomes, offers a new avenue for studying host-pathogen interactions in the Plasmodium liver stage, which was not possible with previous ExM protocols.

title: Improving the resolution of fluorescence nanoscopy using post-expansion labeling microscopy
authors: Virginie Hamel, Paul Guichard

title: Single cell analysis of PANoptosome cell death complexes through an expansion microscopy method
authors: Yaqiu Wang, Nagakannan Pandian, Joo-Hui Han, Balamurugan Sundaram, SangJoon Lee, Rajendra Karki, Clifford S. Guy, Thirumala-Devi Kanneganti
summary: Fig 1: Optimized immunofluorescence staining for ASC, CASP8, and RIPK3 in mouse BMDMs, highlighting antibody specificity. Fig 2: Demonstrated ASC speck heterogeneity in IAV-infected BMDMs, showing colocalization with CASP8 and RIPK3. Fig 3: Expansion microscopy revealed detailed ASC speck structures in LPS+ATP-stimulated BMDMs, showing colocalization of RIPK3 and CASP8. The study provides a validated protocol for visualizing PANoptosome assembly in single cells under various conditions.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of PANoptosome assembly in single cells, providing insights into the dynamics of multiprotein complex formation during innate immune cell death. This method allows for the study of cell death complexes and their regulation, facilitating a deeper understanding of PANoptosis and its role in health and disease.
novelty: This study presents a validated immunofluorescence protocol combined with expansion microscopy to visualize PANoptosome complexes at the single-cell level. Unlike previous methods, this approach allows for the detailed examination of ASC speck heterogeneity and the colocalization of key proteins like CASP8 and RIPK3. The use of expansion microscopy offers improved resolution without the need for super-resolution equipment, making it accessible for broader research applications. This work advances the understanding of PANoptosome dynamics and their role in innate immune cell death, providing a foundation for future studies on therapeutic targeting.

title: Expansion enhanced nanoscopy
authors: Rongqin Li, Xuanze Chen, Zixi Lin, Yao Wang, Yujie Sun
summary: Fig 1: ExSTED imaging of microtubules in BS-C-1 cells showed improved resolution with a novel re-labeling strategy. Fig 2: ExSTED resolved the ring-like arrangement of Nup133 in nuclear pore complexes and improved visualization of synaptic structures in mouse brain slices. Fig 3: ExSOFI using quantum dots achieved high-resolution imaging of microtubules and clathrin-coated pits, demonstrating multiplexed imaging capabilities.
application_goal: The protocol enabled enhanced resolution imaging of cellular and tissue structures by combining expansion microscopy with super-resolution techniques like STED and SOFI, allowing for detailed visualization of subcellular components and complex molecular arrangements.
novelty: This work introduces a novel re-labeling strategy post-expansion to enhance fluorescence signal retention, enabling effective combination of ExM with STED and SOFI. Compared to previous ExM methods, this approach achieves significant resolution enhancement without the need for high-power depletion lasers, thus avoiding potential hydrogel distortion. The use of quantum dots in ExSOFI further extends the method's applicability, offering multiplexed imaging with high brightness and stability.

title: Enzymatically enhanced ultrastructure expansion microscopy unlocks expansion of in vitro Toxoplasma gondii cysts
authors: Kseniia Bondarenko, Floriane Limoge, Kayvon Pedram, Mathieu Gissot, Joanna C. Young
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates that standard U-ExM protocols fail to fully expand T. gondii cysts, achieving only a 2.5x expansion factor. Fig 2 shows that adding StcE mucinase allows full expansion of cysts, achieving a 4.0-4.5x expansion factor, crucial for accurate protein localization. Fig 3 confirms that the StcE-enhanced protocol preserves protein signals in cysts, with expected localization patterns for GAP45 and GRA2. Fig 4 reveals that GRA2 is distributed as puncta across the CST1-positive layer, providing new insights into its localization within the cyst wall.
application_goal: The protocol enabled precise localization of proteins within Toxoplasma gondii cysts, overcoming the limitations of standard U-ExM protocols. By incorporating an enzymatic digestion step with StcE mucinase, the study achieved full expansion of cysts, facilitating detailed investigations of cyst wall components and their spatial organization.
novelty: This study introduces an enzymatic enhancement to the U-ExM protocol, specifically targeting the glycosylated mucin domains of CST1 with StcE mucinase. This approach resolves the challenge of incomplete expansion in T. gondii cysts, a limitation of previous ExM variants. The enhanced protocol allows for nanoscale resolution of protein localization within the cyst wall, providing insights that were previously unattainable with standard super-resolution methods. This advancement is particularly significant for studying the chronic stage of Toxoplasma infection, where precise protein localization is crucial for understanding cyst formation and potential vulnerabilities.
source_file: Enzymatically enhanced ultrastructure expansion microscopy unlocks expansion of in vitro Toxoplasma gondii cysts.pdf

title: Imaging Giardia intestinalis cellular organisation using expansion microscopy reveals atypical centrin localisation
authors: J. Soukup, M. Zelen´a, F. Weisz, M. Kostelansk´a, E. Nohýnkov´a, P. Tůmov´a
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the ExM workflow for Giardia cells, emphasizing the adherence to coverslips and expansion steps. Fig 2 shows the resolution of cellular structures, highlighting microtubules and organelles using antibody and NHS ester staining. Fig 3 compares centrin localization in expanded versus non-expanded cells, demonstrating improved detail in expanded samples. Fig 4 provides 3D reconstructions of centrin localization, revealing non-luminal positioning at basal bodies.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution imaging of Giardia intestinalis cellular structures, particularly the precise localization of centrin, without the need for superresolution microscopy equipment. This approach allows for detailed visualization of microtubules and organelles, facilitating studies on cellular organization and protein localization in protists.
novelty: This study presents a modified ExM protocol for Giardia intestinalis that does not require superresolution microscopy, offering a simpler and more accessible method for high-resolution imaging. The work highlights the use of post-expansion labeling to improve epitope accessibility and resolution, achieving a 3.4x expansion factor. The study provides new insights into centrin localization, revealing a non-luminal arrangement at basal bodies, which contrasts with previous findings in other eukaryotic cells. This advancement in ExM application to protists enhances our understanding of their cellular architecture.

title: Cell Cycle Oscillators: Methods and Protocols
authors: Amanda S. Coutts, Louise Weston
summary: Fig 1: Discusses the cell cycle control system of interlinking oscillators, highlighting the importance of protein kinases. Fig 2: Describes substrate phosphorylation rates as a measure of kinase activity, providing insights into cell cycle regulation. Fig 3: Explores real-time monitoring of APC/C-mediated substrate degradation using Xenopus laevis egg extracts, crucial for understanding cell cycle transitions. Fig 4: Introduces fluorescent peptide biosensors for probing CDK kinase activity, enhancing the study of cell cycle dynamics. Fig 5: Details phosphatase and kinase substrate specificity profiling with synthetic peptides and mass spectrometry, offering a comprehensive view of cell cycle regulation.
application_goal: The protocols in this study enable detailed analysis of cell cycle oscillators, providing methods to monitor and manipulate key regulatory proteins and pathways. This facilitates a deeper understanding of cell cycle dynamics and the development of potential therapeutic strategies for proliferative diseases.
novelty: This work compiles a comprehensive set of protocols for studying cell cycle oscillators, integrating both novel and established techniques. It emphasizes the use of advanced biochemical and molecular biology methods to dissect the complex regulatory networks of the cell cycle. Compared to previous studies, this edition offers updated methodologies and insights into the dynamic interactions of cell cycle regulators, contributing to the field's understanding of cell division and its implications in disease.

title: Expansion microscopy with trypsin digestion and tyramide signal amplification (TT-ExM) for protein and lipid staining
authors: Ueh-Ting Tim Wang, Xuejiao Tian, Yae-Huei Liou, Sue-Ping Lee, Chieh-Han Lu, Peilin Chen, Bi-Chang Che
sample: COS-7 cell cultures, primary cultured neurons
summary: Figure 1 introduces TT-ExM, highlighting trypsin digestion and tyramide signal amplification to enhance fluorescence. Figure 2 demonstrates the retention of fluorescent signals in COS-7 cells using TT-ExM, showing improved protein retention and visualization of cellular structures. Figure 3 compares trypsin and proteinase K treatments, showing superior signal retention with trypsin. Figure 4 applies TT-ExM to lipid staining, revealing detailed cellular membrane structures. Figure 5 extends TT-ExM to cultured neurons, visualizing mitochondria and nuclear structures.
application_goal: The protocol enabled enhanced visualization of protein and lipid structures in cells, overcoming the limitations of signal dilution and protein loss in traditional expansion microscopy. By using trypsin digestion and tyramide signal amplification, TT-ExM significantly improved fluorescence signal retention and resolution, allowing detailed imaging of cellular components such as the endoplasmic reticulum, mitochondria, and lipid-rich structures.
novelty: This study introduces TT-ExM, a novel expansion microscopy protocol that combines trypsin digestion and tyramide signal amplification to address the challenges of protein loss and signal dilution in traditional ExM. Compared to previous ExM variants, TT-ExM offers improved signal retention and resolution without the need for sophisticated microscopy equipment. The use of trypsin, which has fewer cleavage sites than proteinase K, enhances fluorophore retention, while tyramide amplification boosts fluorescence intensity. This approach is particularly advantageous for visualizing lipid-rich structures, which were previously difficult to image due to detergent treatments in other ExM protocols.

title: Optimized expansion microscopy reveals species-specific spindle microtubule organization in Xenopus egg extracts
authors: Gabriel Guilloux, Maiko Kitaoka, Karel Mocaer, Claire Heichette, Laurence Duchesne, Rebecca Heald, Thierry Pecot, Romain Gibeaux
summary: Fig 1: Developed a workflow for ExM of Xenopus egg extract spindles, optimizing fixation and gelation. Fig 2: Compared expansion factors and distortions across different protocols, selecting U-ExM gel with thermal denaturation for minimal distortion. Fig 3: Demonstrated resolution improvement, showing clearer microtubule bundles post-expansion. Fig 4: Evaluated effects of different fixation methods, finding MAD fixation better preserves microtubule integrity. Fig 5: Reduced fixation duration to improve microtubule straightness and spindle integrity. Fig 6: Developed analysis workflow to segment and quantify microtubule bundles, revealing species-specific differences. Fig 7: Analyzed organizational differences, showing X. laevis spindles have broader bundle size range compared to X. tropicalis.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution imaging of spindle microtubule organization in Xenopus egg extracts, revealing species-specific differences in spindle architecture. This approach allows for detailed analysis of microtubule bundles and their distribution, providing insights into spindle morphology and function.
novelty: This study presents an optimized ExM protocol tailored for Xenopus egg extract spindles, achieving a resolution of 77.23 nm. Unlike previous ExM variants, this protocol preserves rhodamine-labeled tubulin signals and allows pre-expansion immunofluorescence, enabling detailed analysis of spindle microtubule organization. The work reveals species-specific differences in spindle architecture between X. laevis and X. tropicalis, highlighting the adaptability of spindle structures to different sizes and chromatin amounts. This advancement provides a robust tool for studying large cellular assemblies with unprecedented clarity.

title: Visualization of Single Escherichia coli Cells in the State of SOS Response using Expansion Microscopy
authors: N. A. Rumyantseva, D. M. Golofeeva, I. E. Vishnyakov, A. D. Vedyaykina
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the general principle of expansion microscopy using a bacterial cell model. Fig 2 shows the isotropic expansion of the gel in deionized water. Fig 6 demonstrates the uneven distribution of FtsZ protein in E. coli cells during the SOS response, highlighting the absence of Z-rings. Fig 7 visualizes the distribution of DNA in E. coli cells, showing more uniform distribution during the SOS response compared to normal division.
application_goal: The protocol enabled visualization of the uneven distribution of FtsZ protein and DNA in E. coli cells during the SOS response, providing insights into the incomplete disassembly of FtsZ polymers and the spatial organization of DNA.
novelty: This study applies expansion microscopy to visualize single bacterial cells, specifically E. coli, during the SOS response. Unlike previous methods, this approach does not require complex super-resolution microscopy equipment, offering a simpler and cost-effective alternative. The use of Acryloyl-X for anchoring and the visualization of FtsZ protein distribution provides new insights into bacterial cell division under stress conditions, which were previously observed using more complex single-molecule localization microscopy.

title: High-Resolution Imaging Mass Spectrometry of Human Donor Eye: Photoreceptors Cells and Basal Laminar Deposit of Age-Related Macular Degeneration
authors: David M. G. Anderson, Ankita Kotnala, Jeffrey D. Messinger, Nathan Heath Patterson, Jeffrey M. Spraggins, Christine A. Curcio, Richard M. Caprioli, Kevin L. Schey
summary: Fig 1: MALDI IMS was used to localize molecular species in photoreceptor cells and basal laminar deposits, providing insights into AMD pathology. Fig 2: Sphingomyelin-related lipid localization to BLamD and RPE was demonstrated, highlighting lipid accumulation in AMD. The study emphasizes the utility of MALDI IMS in identifying molecular compositions in retinal diseases.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the localization and identification of molecular species in retinal tissues, particularly in photoreceptor cells and basal laminar deposits, which are crucial for understanding the molecular underpinnings of age-related macular degeneration.
novelty: This work leverages MALDI IMS to achieve cellular resolution imaging of molecular species in retinal tissues, offering a non-destructive alternative to traditional methods like immunohistochemistry. The study provides new insights into lipid accumulation in AMD, a feature not easily discernible with other techniques, thus advancing the understanding of retinal disease pathology.

title: Multiplexed imaging of high-density libraries of RNAs with MERFISH and expansion microscopy
authors: Guiping Wang, Jeffrey R. Moffitt, Xiaowei Zhuang
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the effect of RNA density on MERFISH detection efficiency, showing reduced efficiency in high-density samples. Fig 2 illustrates the improvement in detection efficiency with expansion microscopy, achieving near 100% efficiency. Fig 3 combines MERFISH with immunofluorescence, showing successful protein and RNA imaging in expanded samples. The study highlights the ability to measure high-abundance RNA libraries with improved accuracy and efficiency using expansion microscopy.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the accurate identification and counting of high-abundance RNA libraries in single cells, overcoming the limitations of signal overlap in high-density samples. By combining MERFISH with expansion microscopy, the study achieved near 100% detection efficiency, allowing for the profiling of a larger number of RNA species and higher total RNA abundance levels in single cells.
novelty: This work combines MERFISH with expansion microscopy to address the challenge of signal overlap in high-density RNA samples, achieving a significant increase in detection efficiency. Unlike previous methods, this approach anchors RNAs to the gel at a single location, improving separation without stretching. The study demonstrates the compatibility of expansion microscopy with MERFISH, enabling the measurement of high-abundance RNA libraries with near 100% efficiency, a substantial improvement over previous MERFISH measurements. Additionally, the integration of immunofluorescence expands the scope of applications, allowing for simultaneous RNA and protein imaging in expanded samples.
source_file: Multiplexed imaging of high-density libraries of RNAs with MERFISH and expansion microscopy.pdf

title: Atlas of Plasmodium falciparum intraerythrocytic development using expansion microscopy
authors: Benjamin Liffner, Ana Karla Cepeda Diaz, James Blauwkamp, David Anaguano, Sonja Frolich, Vasant Muralidharan, Danny W Wilson, Jeffrey D Dvorin, Sabrina Absalon
summary: Fig 1: U-ExM workflow is outlined, showing the expansion process and imaging of P. falciparum structures. Fig 2: Centriolar plaque dynamics are detailed, highlighting its role in mitosis. Fig 3: Microtubule organization is characterized, showing their role in nuclear division. Fig 4: Basal complex development is tracked, showing its role in segmentation. Fig 5: Mitochondrial growth and fission are described, highlighting their association with the centriolar plaque. Fig 6: Apicoplast growth and fission are detailed, showing its segregation during schizogony. Fig 7: Cytostome structures are identified, showing their role in endocytosis. Fig 8: Rhoptry biogenesis is tracked, showing its association with the centriolar plaque. Fig 9: Microneme heterogeneity is described, showing distinct localization of AMA1 and EBA175.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed visualization of P. falciparum organelle biogenesis and segregation during the asexual blood stage, providing insights into the spatial organization and dynamics of key cellular structures.
novelty: This study applies U-ExM to P. falciparum, offering unprecedented insights into its intraerythrocytic development. Unlike previous ExM variants, this work provides a comprehensive atlas of organelle organization, revealing new aspects of parasite cell biology. The use of U-ExM allows for visualization of structures previously only accessible by electron microscopy, offering a more accessible and scalable approach to studying malaria parasites.
source_file: Atlas of Plasmodium falciparum intraerythrocytic development using expansion microscopy.pdf

title: Visualizing the trans-synaptic arrangement of synaptic proteins by expansion microscopy
authors: Stefan Sachs, Sebastian Reinhard, Janna Eilts, Markus Sauer, Christian Werner
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the ∼8x expansion of samples using the TREx protocol, crucial for achieving high-resolution imaging. Fig 2 shows the improved clarity and resolution of synaptic proteins using ExM-AS, highlighting the decrowding effect. Fig 3 quantifies the alignment of nanocolumns at synapses, revealing the arrangement of RIM 1/2 and PSD95. Fig 4 explores the colocalization of LGI1 with synaptic proteins, indicating its role in synaptic clefts. These figures collectively illustrate the enhanced visualization and analysis of synaptic structures enabled by the ExM-AS approach.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of nanoscale trans-synaptic nanocolumns and their arrangement, providing insights into the structural organization of synaptic proteins. This approach is particularly useful for studying pathological impacts on synaptic structures, such as in limbic encephalitis.
novelty: This study combines ∼8x expansion microscopy with Airyscan super-resolution imaging, offering a significant improvement in resolution and labeling efficiency over previous methods. The post-gelation immunolabeling strategy reduces linkage errors and enhances antigen accessibility, allowing for detailed visualization of synaptic nanocolumns. Compared to prior ExM variants, this approach provides a more straightforward and effective method for studying synaptic protein arrangements, without the need for complex iterative expansion processes.

title: Proximity labeling expansion microscopy (PL-ExM) evaluates interactome labeling techniques
authors: Sohyeon Park, Xiaorong Wang, Yajin Mo, Sicheng Zhang, Xiangpeng Li, Katie C. Fong, Clinton Yu, Arthur A. Tran, Lorenzo Scipioni, Zhipeng Dai, Xiao Huang, Lan Huang, Xiaoyu Shi
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the PL-ExM workflow, highlighting its ability to visualize protein interactions with high resolution. Fig 2 demonstrates the super-resolution capability of PL-ExM by comparing expanded and non-expanded samples, revealing detailed mitochondrial structures. Fig 3 evaluates the labeling efficiency and precision of APEX2 and HRP, showing HRP's superior performance. Fig 4 applies PL-ExM to visualize microtubules and cilia, revealing spatial relationships between proteins. Fig 5 extends PL-ExM to mouse brain tissues, showcasing its compatibility with complex samples.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of protein interactions at a resolution of up to 17 nm using widely accessible microscopes, providing a reliable method to assess the quality of proximity labeling techniques and optimize interactome labeling.
novelty: This study introduces PL-ExM, a method that combines expansion microscopy with proximity labeling to achieve super-resolution imaging of protein interactions. Compared to previous ExM variants, PL-ExM offers a significant resolution improvement, reaching 17 nm, and is compatible with standard light microscopes. The method's ability to evaluate labeling precision and efficiency addresses a critical challenge in proteomic studies, providing a more accessible alternative to advanced super-resolution techniques like STORM and STED.

antibodies_and_dyes.name: ImmPRESS HRP Horse anti-Goat IgG Polymer Detection Kit

title: Visualization of the membrane surface and cytoskeleton of oligodendrocyte progenitor cell growth cones using a combination of scanning ion conductance and four times expansion microscopy
authors: Annika Haak, Heiko M. Lesslich, Irmgard D. Dietzel
summary: Figure 1 outlines the experimental workflow, showing the process from brightfield imaging to SICM and ExM imaging of OPC growth cones. Figure 2 presents SICM recordings of OPC growth cones, highlighting membrane topographies and potential filopodia. Figure 3 displays ExM images of OPC cultures, demonstrating the resolution achieved post-expansion. Figure 4 correlates SICM and ExM images, showing the alignment of membrane topography with tubulin labeling. Figure 5 further correlates SICM and ExM images, focusing on actin and tubulin distribution in growth cones.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of the relative position of actin and tubulin fibers with respect to membrane protrusions in OPC growth cones, providing insights into the cytoskeletal organization and membrane topography at a resolution below 200 nm.
novelty: This study presents a novel combination of scanning ion conductance microscopy (SICM) and expansion microscopy (ExM) to achieve high-resolution imaging of oligodendrocyte progenitor cell growth cones. Unlike previous methods that required complex setups, this approach allows for detailed visualization of cytoskeletal structures and membrane topography using standard widefield microscopy. The integration of SICM with ExM offers a cost-effective alternative to super-resolution techniques like STED or SOFI, providing comparable resolution without the need for specialized equipment. This work expands the applicability of ExM by demonstrating its compatibility with SICM, a non-optical technique, to overcome the limitations of diffraction-limited microscopy.

title: Expansion microscopy of Plasmodium gametocytes reveals the molecular architecture of a bipartite microtubule organisation centre coordinating mitosis with axoneme assembly
authors: Ravish Rashpa, Mathieu Brochet
summary: Fig 1: U-ExM was used to reconstruct the 3D subpellicular microtubule network in P. falciparum gametocytes, highlighting the microtubule organisation. Fig 2: Upon activation, the microgametocyte undergoes endomitosis and assembles axonemes, visualised by U-ExM. Fig 3: In P. berghei, the bipartite MTOC was observed, showing the spatial dynamics of microtubule organisation. Fig 4: Pan-ExM provided further resolution, revealing individual microtubules and kinetochores. Fig 5: The dynamic localisation of γ-tubulin was mapped, showing its role in microtubule nucleation. Fig 6: The molecular organisation of basal bodies was detailed, showing the roles of SAS4 and SAS6. Fig 7: 3D reconstruction highlighted the structural organisation of the MTOC. Fig 8: SAS4 and SAS6 were shown to have differential roles in basal body assembly and axoneme formation.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the detailed visualisation of the molecular architecture of the bipartite microtubule organisation centre in Plasmodium gametocytes, providing insights into the coordination of mitosis with axoneme assembly. This approach allowed for the observation of cellular structures previously only accessible by electron microscopy, facilitating a better understanding of the molecular organisation and dynamics of the MTOC in malaria parasites.
novelty: This study presents a novel application of expansion microscopy (ExM) to Plasmodium gametocytes, revealing the molecular architecture of a bipartite microtubule organisation centre. Unlike previous ExM variants, this approach combines ultrastructure expansion microscopy (U-ExM) with bulk proteome labelling, allowing for nanoscale imaging of cellular structures. The study highlights the dynamic localisation of γ-tubulin and the roles of SAS4 and SAS6 in basal body assembly, providing new insights into the coordination of mitosis and axoneme formation. This work advances the understanding of MTOC organisation in Plasmodium, offering a new perspective on the evolution of microtubule organisation centres in eukaryotes.

title: Trifunctional Linkers Enable Improved Visualization of Actin by Expansion Microscopy
authors: Gang Wen, Matthew Domenic Lycas, Yuqing Jia, Volker Leen, Markus Sauer, Johan Hofkens
summary: Fig 1 illustrates three phalloidin-actin complex anchoring strategies, highlighting the TRITON linker. Fig 2 compares signal retention of TRITON molecules, showing improved retention with multiple acryloyl units. Fig 3 optimizes TRITON grafting strategies, demonstrating enhanced signal retention with AcX. Fig 4 combines ExM with SIM, achieving higher resolution of actin filaments. Fig 5 resolves actin periodicity in neurons using TREx protocol. Fig 6 visualizes actin filaments in mouse brain tissues, confirming TRITON's efficacy in tissue samples.
application_goal: The protocol enabled visualization of actin filaments with improved signal retention and resolution, allowing detailed imaging of actin organization in both cellular and tissue samples. The optimized TRITON linkers, combined with immunolabeling, facilitated multicolor imaging and enhanced the applicability of ExM for studying complex biological structures.
novelty: This study introduces optimized trifunctional linkers (TRITON) that significantly improve the visualization of actin filaments in expansion microscopy. Compared to previous ExM variants, the TRITON linkers offer enhanced signal retention and reduced linkage error, enabling high-resolution imaging of actin structures. The work also demonstrates the compatibility of TRITON with various labeling strategies and its potential for multicolor imaging, setting a new standard for actin visualization in ExM.

title: Proteus mirabilis biofilm expansion microscopy yields over 4-fold magnification for super-resolution of biofilm structure and subcellular DNA organization
authors: Dante Castagnini, Karina Palma, Jorge Jara-Wilde, Nicolás Navarro, María José González, Jorge Toledo, Nicole Canales-Huerta, Paola Scavone, Steffen Härtel
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the expansion of planktonic P. mirabilis using a modified μExM protocol, achieving an expansion factor of 4.8. Fig 2 applies a three-step enzymatic protocol to expand P. mirabilis biofilms, achieving a 5.1-fold expansion. Fig 3 confirms the preservation of morphology and spatial organization in expanded biofilms, with an expansion factor of 4.3. Fig 4 shows improved resolution of biofilm architecture, revealing multiple bacterial layers. Fig 5 reveals novel spatial DNA organization patterns in expanded biofilms, not observable in non-expanded samples.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed visualization of P. mirabilis biofilm architecture and subcellular DNA organization, overcoming the diffraction limit of conventional microscopy. This allows for a better understanding of biofilm structure and potential insights into bacterial behavior and resistance mechanisms.
novelty: This study presents a novel expansion microscopy protocol tailored for P. mirabilis biofilms, achieving near-theoretical maximum expansion factors without pre-gelation digestion. This contrasts with previous ExM variants that required pre-gelation digestion and often achieved lower expansion factors. The use of glycoside-hydrolases alongside mutanolysin and proteinase K represents a new approach to overcoming the challenges posed by the bacterial cell wall and EPS matrix, enabling high-resolution imaging of biofilm structures and intracellular components.

title: Expansion and fluctuations-enhanced microscopy for nanoscale molecular profiling of cells and tissues
authors: Dominik Kylies, Hannah S. Heil, Arturo G. Vesga, Mario Del Rosario, Maria Schwerk, Malte Kuehl, Milagros N. Wong, Victor G. Puelles, Ricardo Henriques
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the ExSRRF workflow, highlighting the integration of expansion microscopy with eSRRF for enhanced resolution. Fig 2 demonstrates the identification and correction of artifacts, crucial for maintaining image fidelity. Fig 3 presents the parameter optimization process for eSRRF, ensuring high-quality reconstructions. Fig 4 evaluates the reconstruction performance using quantitative metrics, confirming the resolution enhancement achieved by the protocol.
application_goal: The protocol enables nanoscale molecular profiling of cells and tissues using conventional microscopes by combining expansion microscopy with enhanced super-resolution radial fluctuations analysis. This approach allows for high-resolution imaging of biological samples, facilitating the study of cellular ultrastructure and protein localization without the need for specialized equipment.
novelty: This work introduces a novel combination of expansion microscopy with eSRRF, achieving a resolution of 25 nm using conventional microscopes. Compared to previous ExM variants, this method offers improved accessibility and flexibility, allowing for high-resolution imaging of large-scale tissue samples. The integration of eSRRF provides enhanced image fidelity and resolution, surpassing traditional super-resolution methods that require specialized equipment.

title: Challenges of Using Expansion Microscopy for Super-resolved Imaging of Cellular Organelles
authors: Maximilian Büttner, Christoffer B. Lagerholm, Dominic Waithe, Silvia Galiani, Wolfgang Schliebs, Ralf Erdmann, Christian Eggeling, Katharina Reglinski
summary: Figure 1 outlines the procedure for expansion microscopy of intracellular organelles in HEK293 cells, highlighting the steps from fixation to imaging. Figure 2 compares the expansion of the nucleus in expanded and unexpanded cells, showing significant variance in expansion factors. Figure 3 examines the expansion of cell area and mitochondria, revealing discrepancies in expansion factors between these structures. Figure 4 focuses on peroxisomes, demonstrating differential expansion between the peroxisomal membrane and matrix, emphasizing the need for careful validation of expansion factors in subcellular structures.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the study of intracellular organelles with improved resolution by combining expansion microscopy with STED, allowing for detailed analysis of protein distribution and interactions within cellular compartments.
novelty: This study highlights the challenges of using expansion microscopy for subcellular structures, particularly the variability in expansion factors across different organelles and even within the same organelle. Unlike previous ExM variants, this work emphasizes the need for careful validation of expansion factors for accurate size determination, especially in complex structures like peroxisomes with dense protein matrices. The combination with STED microscopy provides enhanced resolution, offering insights into protein localization and interactions that were previously difficult to achieve with standard super-resolution methods.
source_file: ChemBioChem - 2020 - Büttner - Challenges of Using Expansion Microscopy for Super‐resolved Imaging of Cellular Organelles.pdf

title: From Trypomastigotes to Trypomastigotes: Analyzing the One-Way Intracellular Journey of Trypanosoma cruzi by Ultrastructure Expansion Microscopy
authors: Ramiro Tomasina, Fabiana C. González, Andrés Cabrera, Yester Basmadjián, Carlos Robello
summary: Fig 1 shows the initial stages of T. cruzi infection in Vero cells, highlighting the morphological changes from trypomastigotes to intermediate forms. Fig 2 details the amastigogenesis process, emphasizing the repositioning of basal bodies and kinetoplast. Fig 3 presents the diversity of dividing forms at 24 hours post-infection, revealing distinct morphologies among amastigotes. Fig 4 explores the intermediate stages of trypomastigogenesis, identifying epimastigote-like forms and their transition to trypomastigotes. Fig 5 illustrates the semi-closed nuclear mitosis in amastigotes, showing mitotic spindle formation independent of basal bodies.
application_goal: This study enabled the detailed visualization of the intracellular life cycle of Trypanosoma cruzi, particularly the transitions between trypomastigote and amastigote forms within host cells. By employing Ultrastructure Expansion Microscopy, the research provided insights into the morphological and cytoskeletal changes that occur during these transitions, enhancing the understanding of T. cruzi's intracellular differentiation processes.
novelty: This work advances the understanding of T. cruzi's intracellular life cycle by employing Ultrastructure Expansion Microscopy, which offers a higher resolution than traditional immunofluorescence techniques. The study reveals previously unobserved intermediate forms and provides a detailed model of amastigogenesis and trypomastigogenesis. Unlike prior studies, this research highlights the presence of non-replicative epimastigote-like forms within host cells, suggesting a more complex differentiation process than previously understood. The use of UExM allows for a more comprehensive analysis of the parasite's morphological changes, setting a new standard for studying intracellular stages of T. cruzi.

title: Molecular Decrowding by Tissue Expansion Allows Precise Determination of the Spatial Distribution of Synaptic Proteins at a Nanometer Scale by exTEM
authors: Kang-Hoon Kim, Jubeen Yoon, Christian P. Macks, Han-Eol Park, Jihyun Youn, Jung-uk Lee, Minji An, Jongseong Park, Jaewon Ko, Chang Ho Sohn
summary: Fig 1: Optimization of fixation and immunostaining conditions for synaptic CAMs in tissue-hydrogel hybrids, showing improved staining over conventional methods. Fig 2: Workflow of exTEM method, detailing sample preparation and imaging processes for enhanced immunolabeling. Fig 3: Validation of lipid labeling specificity using pGK5a and FM 1−43FX probes, confirming colocalization in various brain regions. Fig 4: Demonstration of immunogold labeling specificity and isotropic expansion stability in cryo-sampling. Fig 5: TEM imaging of exTEM samples reveals nanoscale distribution of synaptic proteins, providing precise localization of synaptic CAMs.
application_goal: The exTEM protocol enables precise localization of synaptic CAMs in mouse brain tissue using commercially available antibodies, achieving super-resolution imaging with conventional confocal microscopy and nanometer resolution with TEM. This method facilitates the study of synaptic protein architectures and densely packed environments at a nanometer scale.
novelty: exTEM combines tissue expansion with TEM to overcome limitations of conventional electron microscopy, such as limited epitope accessibility and signal dilution in expanded tissues. Unlike previous methods, exTEM provides high antibody compatibility for synaptic proteins and allows for precise localization of synaptic CAMs without genetic labeling. This approach bridges the gap between super-resolution fluorescence imaging and TEM, offering a powerful tool for studying protein-specific localization at nanometer scales.

title: Expansion microscopy with conventional antibodies and fluorescent proteins
authors: Tyler J Chozinski, Aaron R Halpern, Haruhisa Okawa, Hyeon-Jin Kim, Grant J Tremel, Rachel O L Wong, Joshua C Vaughan
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the difference between the original DNA method and the new MA-NHS/GA methods for label retention in ExM. Fig 2 shows confocal images of expanded cultured cells, demonstrating improved fluorescence retention with MA-NHS and GA treatments. Fig 3 presents images of expanded mouse brain tissue, highlighting the resolution of synaptic structures and the retention of intrinsic YFP fluorescence. The study demonstrates that conventional antibodies and fluorescent proteins can be used in ExM, simplifying the procedure and expanding the range of compatible labels.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the use of conventional fluorophore-labeled antibodies and fluorescent proteins in expansion microscopy, simplifying the procedure and expanding the palette of compatible labels, which allows for rapid dissemination of the technique.
novelty: This work introduces new polymer-linking methods for ExM that allow the use of conventional antibodies and fluorescent proteins, unlike previous methods that required custom DNA-labeled antibodies. The study demonstrates improved brightness and retention of fluorescence signals, making ExM more accessible and versatile. The use of MA-NHS and GA as linking agents is faster and more efficient than previous methods, such as the DNA method, and provides flexibility in multichannel imaging situations.
source_file: Expansion microscopy with conventional antibodies and fluorescent proteins.pdf

title: The Plant Cytoskeleton
authors: Patrick J. Hussey, Pengwei Wang
summary: Fig 1 describes the quantification of microtubule-bundling activity using TIRF microscopy, highlighting its importance in understanding microtubule dynamics. Fig 2 focuses on actin studies, emphasizing the static and dynamic aspects of actin in plant cells. Fig 3 presents 3D visualization techniques for microtubules in epidermal pavement cells, crucial for understanding cell structure. Fig 4 provides a quantitative analysis of microtubule organization in leaf epidermis, which is vital for studying plant cell architecture. Fig 5 introduces single-cell confinement methods to study the plant cytoskeleton, offering insights into cellular responses to environmental changes.
application_goal: The protocols in this study enable detailed visualization and quantification of the plant cytoskeleton, facilitating the study of microtubule and actin dynamics in various plant cells and tissues. This is crucial for understanding cellular processes such as cell division, expansion, and response to environmental stimuli.
novelty: This work provides a comprehensive set of protocols for studying the plant cytoskeleton, focusing on both microtubules and actin filaments. Compared to previous methods, this volume emphasizes the importance of sample preparation and offers detailed protocols for various plant systems. The inclusion of expansion microscopy for plant cells is a novel approach, allowing for enhanced visualization of microtubule arrays. The work stands out by integrating bioinformatics tools for analyzing large cytoskeletal gene families, which is a significant advancement over traditional microscopy techniques.

title: TEMI: tissue-expansion mass-spectrometry imaging
authors: Hua Zhang, Lang Ding, Amy Hu, Xudong Shi, Penghsuan Huang, Haiyan Lu, Paul W. Tillberg, Meng C. Wang, Lingjun Li
summary: Fig 1: TEMI was developed to map biomolecules with improved spatial resolution, revealing lipid distribution across cerebellar layers. Fig 2: Single-cell-resolution TEMI mapping of Purkinje cells showed specific lipid enrichment. Fig 3: TEMI mapped small metabolites in mouse cerebellum, highlighting spatial metabolic heterogeneity. Fig 4: TEMI was used to image proteins and N-glycans, revealing distinctive distributions. Fig 5: TEMI revealed metabolic heterogeneity in mouse tumors, segmenting tissue into more regions than unexpanded samples. Fig 6: TEMI was applied to mouse kidney and pancreas, mapping lipid distribution.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution spatial mapping of diverse biomolecules, including lipids, metabolites, peptides, and N-glycans, in various tissues. This method allows for the profiling of biomolecular heterogeneity and structural organization in tissues, advancing spatial multi-omics profiling in biological and medical research.
novelty: This study introduces TEMI, a tissue-expansion method compatible with mass-spectrometry imaging, achieving single-cell spatial resolution without harsh denaturation treatments. Unlike previous methods that used high temperature or proteolysis, TEMI preserves biomolecules in their native state, enhancing spatial resolution and chemical sensitivity. The iterative expansion strategy allows for higher expansion factors, revealing detailed biomolecular distributions. TEMI's compatibility with standard MSI processing and its ability to map a wide range of biomolecules, including proteins and N-glycans, distinguishes it from prior ExM variants and super-resolution methods.

title: Unveiling the Molecular Architecture of T Cells and Immune Synapses with Cryo-Expansion Microscopy
authors: Florent Lemaître, Olivier Mercey, Isabelle Mean, Elise Paulin, Valérie Dutoit, Jan Rath, Denis Migliorini, Caroline Arber, Paul Guichard, Virginie Hamel, Benita Wolf
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the preservation of T cell ultrastructure using Cryo-ExM, highlighting actin and microtubule networks. Fig 2 explores centriolar architecture in T cells, revealing differences in centriole length and protein composition. Fig 3 details the 3D distribution of CD2 during immune synapse formation, showing its dynamic localization. Fig 4 visualizes lytic granules in T cells, providing insights into their structure and content. Fig 5 applies Cryo-ExM to TCR-engineered T cell-target cell pairs and glioblastoma tissue, showcasing nanoscale imaging of immune synapses and lytic granules in situ.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution visualization of T cell architecture and immune synapse formation, preserving fragile structures and allowing detailed 3D imaging of cytoskeletal dynamics and protein localization. It also extended to FFPE tumor tissues, providing nanoscale resolution in clinical samples.
novelty: This study introduces Cryo-ExM, combining cryo-fixation with expansion microscopy, to preserve and visualize the near-native nanoscale organization of T cells. Compared to prior ExM variants, Cryo-ExM offers improved preservation of cytoskeletal structures and membrane-based features, enabling detailed 3D imaging of immune synapses. The method's application to FFPE tissues bridges single-cell immunology with human pathology, offering new insights into T cell interactions within tumor environments.

title: Improving resolving ability of expansion microscopy by varying crosslinker concentration
authors: Yanlei Hu, Ximing Chu, Ting-ting Chen, Qingshan Pan, Chang Liu, Jintao Yi, Xia Chu
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the expansion microscopy process and highlights the effect of varying crosslinker concentrations on hydrogel expansion. Fig 2A shows the expansion capacity of cell-embedded hydrogels as a function of crosslinker concentration, while Fig 2B demonstrates the resolving power improvement with decreasing MBAA concentration. Fig 3 reveals detailed microtubule structures post-expansion, achieving a resolution of B50 nm. Fig 4 displays the clear resolution of clathrin-coated pits in post-expansion images, which were not visible pre-expansion.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the enhancement of expansion microscopy's resolving power by adjusting the crosslinker concentration, achieving a lateral resolution of B50 nm with a common confocal microscope. This improvement allows for detailed visualization of cellular structures such as microtubules and clathrin-coated pits, which are otherwise challenging to resolve.
novelty: This study introduces a systematic approach to improving the resolving ability of expansion microscopy by varying the concentration of the crosslinker MBAA. Unlike previous ExM methods that achieved a maximum expansion factor of B4.5x, this approach achieves a 5.7x expansion factor, resulting in a lateral resolution of B50 nm. This method provides a simpler alternative to more complex super-resolution techniques like STED and SMLM, which require sophisticated hardware and software. The study extends the hydrogel selection for ExM, potentially facilitating its combination with traditional super-resolution microscopy technologies.

title: Expansion microscopy reveals subdomains in C. elegans germ granules
authors: Kin M Suen, Thomas MD Sheard, Chi-Chuan Lin, Dovile Milonaityte, Izzy Jayasinghe, John E Ladbury
resolution: 40 nm in plane and 100 nm axial
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates the workflow of expansion microscopy on C. elegans germline, achieving a 3x expansion factor. Fig 2: Shows pan-protein staining revealing P granules as protein-dense perinuclear structures, confirming DEPS-1 localization. Fig 3: Illustrates that Mutator foci are juxtaposed to PRG-1 condensates, highlighting distinct areas occupied by MUT-16. Fig 4: Depicts ZNFX-1 and PRG-1 as subdomains within the same germ granules, indicating distinct and overlapping areas. Fig 5: Shows malformed P granules in deps-1 and mut-16 mutants, indicating the role of small RNA pathways in granule morphology.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of subdomains within C. elegans germ granules at nanoscale resolution, allowing the study of protein localization and the effects of small RNA pathway mutations on germ granule morphology.
novelty: This study applies enhanced expansion microscopy (EExM) with pan-protein staining to C. elegans germ granules, achieving a resolution of ~40 nm in plane and ~100 nm axial. Unlike previous methods, this approach allows for the unbiased visualization of entire organelles without relying on specific protein markers. The study reveals that P granules, Z granules, and Mutator foci are subdomains within the same germ granule, challenging the traditional view of these structures as separate entities. This work provides a new perspective on the organization of germ granules and their role in small RNA pathways, offering insights that were not possible with conventional microscopy techniques.

title: Mapping the neuronal cytoskeleton using expansion microscopy
authors: Daphne Jurriens, Vincent van Batenburg, Eugene A. Katrukha, Lukas C. Kapitein

title: Expansion mini-microscopy: An enabling alternative in point-of-care diagnostics
authors: Yu Shrike Zhang, Grissel Trujillo-de Santiago, Mario Moisés Alvarez, Steven J. Schiff, Edward S. Boyden, Ali Khademhosseini
summary: Figure 1 illustrates the ExM process, showing how embedding samples in a swellable polymer matrix allows for physical expansion and improved resolution. Figure 2 demonstrates the application of proExM and ExFISH, highlighting the retention of fluorescent proteins and RNA imaging in expanded samples. Figure 3 showcases various portable microscopes, emphasizing their compactness and potential for integration with ExM. Figure 4 presents ExMM, showing enhanced imaging of HEK293 cells and E. coli post-expansion, achieving resolutions comparable to high-end microscopes.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the integration of expansion microscopy with mini-microscopy, termed ExMM, to achieve high-resolution imaging of biological samples at a significantly reduced cost. This approach is particularly beneficial for point-of-care diagnostics in resource-limited settings, allowing for the detection of pathogens and subcellular structures that are otherwise challenging to resolve with low-cost imaging devices.
novelty: This work introduces expansion mini-microscopy (ExMM), combining expansion microscopy with portable mini-microscopes to achieve resolutions comparable to conventional high-end microscopes at a fraction of the cost. Unlike previous ExM variants, ExMM leverages the physical expansion of samples to overcome the resolution limitations of low-cost imaging devices, making it a promising tool for point-of-care diagnostics. The study also explores the use of sodium polyacrylate for sample expansion, highlighting its potential for widespread application in low-resource settings.

title: Expansion microscopy allows quantitative characterization of structural organization of platelet aggregates
authors: Emma L. Faulkner, Jeremy A. Pike, Evelyn Garlick, Robert K. Neely, Iain B. Styles, Stephen P. Watson, Natalie S. Poulter, Steven G. Thomas
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the preparation of platelet samples for expansion microscopy, highlighting the increase in resolution and imaging depth. Fig 2 explores the 3D organization of membrane and cytoskeletal components in platelet aggregates, revealing structural heterogeneity. Fig 3 introduces a custom analysis workflow to quantitatively describe platelet aggregates, providing insights into platelet volume and morphology. Fig 4 classifies actin localization within platelets, showing a distribution between membrane and cytoplasmic regions. Fig 5 and 6 assess the impact of actin inhibitors on platelet aggregates, demonstrating structural disruptions and changes in actin distribution. Fig 7 examines the effect of aggregate position on platelet morphology, indicating differences in size and shape based on location.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization and quantitative analysis of the structural organization of platelet aggregates at nanoscale resolution. This approach provided insights into the heterogeneous distribution of cytoskeletal components and the impact of actin dynamics on platelet morphology and aggregate stability. The study demonstrated the potential of expansion microscopy to overcome limitations in resolving subcellular features within dense biological samples, offering a valuable tool for studying thrombus architecture and its implications in hemostasis and cardiovascular diseases.
novelty: This work advances the application of expansion microscopy to platelet aggregates, a sample type that poses challenges due to its dense and optically opaque nature. Compared to prior ExM variants, this study highlights the ability to achieve nanoscale resolution and detailed volumetric imaging of platelet aggregates, which is not feasible with traditional fluorescence microscopy. The study introduces a custom analysis workflow that allows for comprehensive quantitative descriptions of platelet morphology and cytoskeletal organization. This approach provides new insights into the role of actin dynamics in thrombus stability, offering a significant improvement over existing super-resolution methods in terms of ease and speed of data acquisition and analysis.
