Actin ExM probe conjugated with 561 dye

title: Super-Resolution Three-Dimensional Imaging of Actin Filaments in Cultured Cells and the Brain via Expansion Microscopy
authors: Chan E Park, Youngbin Cho, In Cho, Hyunsu Jung, Byeongyeon Kim, Jennifer H. Shin, Sungyoung Choi, Seok-Kyu Kwon, Young Ki Hahn, Jae-Byum Chang
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the ExM imaging of actin filaments in BS-C-1 cells, showing the retention of actin structures post-expansion. Fig 2 validates the method by comparing actin filament structures with previous super-resolution studies, highlighting the two-layered actin organization. Fig 3 explores the 3-D organization of actin in overlapping cells, revealing stress fibers and actin invaginations. Fig 4 applies the technique to mouse brain slices, identifying actin structures in the CA1 region. Fig 5 extends the method to multiplex imaging with synaptic proteins, illustrating actin's role in synaptic architecture.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-throughput, super-resolution imaging of actin filaments in both cultured cells and thick tissue slices, providing insights into the nanoscale organization of actin in various biological contexts, including synaptic structures in the brain.
novelty: This study introduces a simple labeling process using anti-fluorophore antibodies to anchor phalloidin-labeled actin filaments to a swellable hydrogel, enabling ExM imaging with 60 nm resolution. Compared to previous ExM variants, this method allows for the visualization of actin in dense networks and thick tissues without custom conjugation, offering a practical approach for typical biology labs. The work advances the field by facilitating multiplexed imaging of actin and other proteins, providing a powerful tool for studying actin's role in neurological phenomena and diseases.

title: Revealing nanostructures in brain tissue via protein decrowding by iterative expansion microscopy
authors: Deblina Sarkar, Jinyoung Kang, Asmamaw T. Wassie, Margaret E. Schroeder, Zhuyu Peng, Tyler B. Tarr, Ai-Hui Tang, Emily D. Niederst, Jennie Z. Young, Hanquan Su, Demian Park, Peng Yin, Li-Huei Tsai, Thomas A. Blanpied, Edward S. Boyden
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the ExR technique, showing how iterative expansion allows for protein decrowding and enhanced imaging resolution. Fig 2 validates ExR's resolution by comparing it with DNA-PAINT, showing similar nanoscale precision. Fig 3 explores synaptic protein visualization, revealing nanostructures not visible without decrowding. Fig 4 investigates synaptic nanocolumns, highlighting the alignment of calcium channels with synaptic proteins. Fig 5 applies ExR to Alzheimer's model mice, uncovering periodic amyloid nanostructures. Fig 6 shows co-localization of amyloid with ion channels, suggesting a role in neural excitability.
application_goal: The protocol enabled visualization of previously inaccessible nanostructures in brain tissue by decrowding proteins, allowing for detailed imaging of synaptic architecture and amyloid structures in Alzheimer's disease models.
novelty: This study introduces ExR, an iterative expansion microscopy technique that achieves 20 nm resolution while preserving protein structures. Unlike previous ExM methods, ExR allows for post-expansion antibody staining, enhancing epitope accessibility and revealing nanostructures in crowded environments. The technique's ability to decrowd proteins and maintain low distortion offers a significant advancement over traditional super-resolution methods, providing new insights into synaptic and pathological structures.
source_file: Revealing nanostructures in brain tissue via protein decrowding by iterative expansion microscopy.pdf

title: Superresolution expansion microscopy reveals the three-dimensional organization of the Drosophila synaptonemal complex
authors: Cori K. Cahoon, Zulin Yu, Yongfu Wang, Fengli Guo, Jay R. Unruh, Brian D. Slaughter, R. Scott Hawley
resolution: 25 nm in XY, 60 nm in Z
summary: Fig 1 shows the Drosophila SC structure and the expansion protocol. Fig 2 presents ExM SIM images revealing the SC's dual-layered structure. Fig 3 provides analysis of SC protein positions, showing two mirrored SC layers. Fig 4 compares the relative positions of CONA, Corolla, and N-C(3)G. Fig 5 offers a 3D model of the SC, suggesting each layer connects one sister chromatid from each homologous chromosome.
application_goal: This study enabled the visualization of the Drosophila synaptonemal complex in three dimensions, revealing a dual-layered structure that was previously unresolved. By combining expansion microscopy with structured illumination microscopy, the researchers could achieve a resolution that allowed them to propose a new model of the SC, suggesting that each layer connects one sister chromatid from each homologous chromosome.
novelty: This work advances the field by combining expansion microscopy with SIM to achieve a resolution of 25 nm in XY and 60 nm in Z, surpassing the limits of traditional superresolution methods. The study reveals a dual-layered structure of the Drosophila SC, a feature not previously resolved, and suggests a new model where each SC layer connects one sister chromatid from each homolog. This approach provides a significant improvement over previous methods, offering new insights into the 3D organization of the SC and its components.
source_file: Superresolution expansion microscopy reveals the three-dimensional organization of the Drosophila synaptonemal complex.pdf

title: Nanoscale fluorescence imaging of biological ultrastructure via molecular anchoring and physical expansion
authors: Wei Wang, Yat Ho Chan, SoYoung Kwon, Jamuna Tandukar, Ruixuan Gao
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the principle of super-resolution microscopy techniques like STED, SIM, and SMLM, highlighting their ability to achieve sub-diffraction-limit resolution. Fig 2 outlines the general workflow of expansion microscopy (ExM), emphasizing the steps of anchoring, polymerization, homogenization, and expansion. Fig 3 demonstrates the application of proExM to visualize microtubules in HeLa cells at ~70 nm resolution. Fig 4 shows the imaging of the entire Drosophila brain using a modified proExM, achieving sub-100 nm resolution. Fig 5 presents the visualization of synaptic markers in mouse brain slices using MA-NHS anchoring, achieving sub-100 nm resolution.
application_goal: The protocol enabled nanoscale fluorescence imaging of biological ultrastructure by physically expanding preserved cells and tissues, allowing for improved resolution and visualization of biomolecules such as proteins, nucleic acids, and membranes.
novelty: This work reviews the development of expansion microscopy (ExM) as a method to achieve nanoscale resolution without the need for advanced optics, by physically expanding the sample. Compared to prior ExM variants, this review highlights the use of various anchoring strategies, such as AcX and MA-NHS, to retain a wide range of biomolecules. The work also discusses the compatibility of ExM with existing super-resolution techniques, offering a versatile approach to enhance imaging resolution and accuracy.

title: Expansion Microscopy of Lipid Membranes
authors: Emmanouil D. Karagiannis, Jeong Seuk Kang, Tay Won Shin, Amauche Emenari, Shoh Asano, Leanne Lin, Emma K. Costa, IMAXT Grand Challenge Consortium, Adam H. Marblestone, Narayanan Kasthuri, Edward S. Boyden
summary: Fig 1: Introduces mExM workflow, validating membrane labeling with electron microscopy. Fig 2: Demonstrates mExM on fixed brain tissue, highlighting axonal lipid concentration. Fig 3: Shows mExM's ability to co-visualize lipids and proteins, detailing organelle-specific protein-lipid interactions. The figures collectively illustrate mExM's capability to resolve nanoscale membrane structures and protein associations in biological samples.
application_goal: The protocol enables the imaging of lipid membranes at nanoscale resolution using ordinary microscopes, allowing for the detailed study of protein-lipid interactions in organelles such as mitochondria, the endoplasmic reticulum, the nuclear membrane, and the Golgi apparatus.
novelty: This study introduces membrane expansion microscopy (mExM), a novel form of expansion microscopy optimized for lipid membranes. Unlike traditional ExM, which primarily focuses on proteins and nucleic acids, mExM incorporates a lipid-optimized chemical tag, enabling nanoscale optical imaging of lipid membranes. The work also presents a post-expansion antibody labeling protocol, allowing for the simultaneous visualization of proteins and lipids. This approach provides a significant advancement over previous ExM variants by enabling detailed imaging of lipid-protein interactions, which were previously challenging to observe with conventional microscopy techniques.

title: Enhanced expansion microscopy to measure nanoscale structural and biochemical remodeling in single cells
authors: Thomas M.D. Sheard, Izzy Jayasinghe
summary: Fig 1: Introduction to enhanced expansion microscopy and its application to cardiac nanodomains. Fig 2: Detailed methods for preparing cells and immunolabeling. Fig 3: Anchoring and gelation processes are described. Fig 4: Digestion and expansion steps are outlined, emphasizing isotropy verification. Fig 5: Comparison of EExM with DNA-PAINT for structure verification. Fig 6: 3D imaging techniques for biological samples at moderate depth. Fig 7: Visualization of pathological and physiological alterations using EExM.
application_goal: The protocol enables detailed visualization of nanoscale structural and biochemical changes in single cells, providing insights into cellular remodeling processes.
novelty: This work enhances traditional expansion microscopy by focusing on single-cell analysis, allowing for the measurement of nanoscale changes. Compared to prior ExM variants, this approach emphasizes isotropy and structural verification, particularly in cardiac nanodomains. The study does not introduce new chemistry but refines existing methods for improved resolution and application in single-cell contexts.

title: One step 4x and 12x 3D-ExM: robust super-resolution microscopy in cell biology
authors: Roshan X Norman, Yu-Chia Chen, Emma E Recchia, Jonathan Loi, Quincy Rosemarie, Sydney L Lesko, Smit Patel, Nathan Sherer, Motoki Takaku, Mark E Burkard, Aussie Suzuki
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the workflow of 4x and 12x 3D-ExM, highlighting the single-step expansion process. Fig 2 validates isotropic nuclear expansion, showing that the nucleus expands proportionally to the gel. Fig 3 confirms isotropic expansion by comparing pre- and post-expansion images. Fig 4 demonstrates the application of 12x 3D-ExM to 3D organoids, achieving significant expansion. Fig 5 assesses resolution using cellular rulers, achieving sub-30 nm resolution. Fig 6 explores the visualization of viral and genomic structures, revealing detailed architectures. Fig 7 applies 12x 3D-ExM to determine karyotypes in intact cells, showcasing its potential in chromosomal studies.
application_goal: The protocol enables robust and reproducible 3D isotropic expansion of biological samples, allowing for detailed visualization of nanoscale structures such as chromosomes, kinetochores, and viral particles. This method provides a cost-effective and user-friendly approach to super-resolution microscopy, making it accessible for a wide range of cell biology research.
novelty: This study introduces a single-step 4x and 12x 3D-ExM method that achieves sub-30 nm resolution without the need for specialized equipment or iterative processes. Compared to previous ExM variants, this approach simplifies the expansion process while maintaining isotropy and structural integrity. The use of DMAA-based polymerization and glutaraldehyde as a crosslinker represents a novel chemistry that enhances expansion efficiency and resolution, enabling detailed visualization of complex biological structures.

title: Plasmonic nanoparticle-based expansion microscopy with surface-enhanced Raman and dark-field spectroscopic imaging
authors: CAMILLE G. ARTUR, TASHA WOMACK, FUSHENG ZHAO, JASON L. ERIKSEN, DAVID MAYERICH, WEI-CHUAN SHIH
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the use of plasmonic nanoparticles for multimodal imaging, enhancing photostability and contrast. Fig 2 shows the application of surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) for improved signal detection. Fig 3 highlights the use of dark-field spectroscopy to address signal intensity reduction post-expansion.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the use of plasmonic nanoparticles to enhance imaging capabilities in expansion microscopy, providing improved photostability, contrast, and brightness through multimodal imaging techniques.
novelty: This study introduces the use of plasmonic nanoparticles in expansion microscopy, offering a solution to the limitations of fluorescence-based ExM, such as photostability and signal intensity reduction. By integrating surface-enhanced Raman scattering and dark-field spectroscopy, the work provides a novel approach to achieve nanoscale resolution with enhanced imaging capabilities, setting it apart from traditional ExM and super-resolution methods.

title: Root expansion microscopy: A robust method for super resolution imaging in Arabidopsis
authors: Magali S. Grison, Guillaume Maucort, Amandine Dumazel, Dorian Champelovier, Yutaro Shimizu, Yohann Boutté, Mónica Fernández-Monreal, Emmanuelle M. Bayer
summary: Fig 1: ROOT-ExM method description and expansion factor quantification, showing 4-5x expansion of Arabidopsis root tips. Fig 2: Distortion analysis confirms minimal errors in expanded samples, ensuring accurate representation of cellular structures. Fig 3: ROOT-ExM achieves resolution comparable to STED microscopy, enhancing visualization of Golgi cisternae. Fig 4: Demonstrates versatility of ROOT-ExM in imaging various subcellular structures, including microtubules and cell walls. Fig 5: Combines ROOT-ExM with NHS-ester labeling and STED/LLSM for detailed ultrastructural imaging, revealing nanoscale features like plasmodesmata.
application_goal: The protocol enabled super-resolution imaging of Arabidopsis root cells, allowing detailed visualization of subcellular structures such as the Golgi apparatus, microtubules, and plasmodesmata. This method provides a cost-effective solution for achieving nanoscale resolution in plant tissues, which are typically challenging due to their rigidity and complexity.
novelty: ROOT-ExM represents a significant advancement in plant imaging by adapting expansion microscopy to the rigid structure of plant tissues, specifically Arabidopsis roots. Unlike previous ExM applications, ROOT-ExM achieves a 4x expansion factor, enabling resolution comparable to STED microscopy without the need for specialized equipment. This method overcomes the challenges of antibody penetration and tissue expansion in plant cells, providing a robust and versatile tool for plant biologists to explore subcellular architecture at nanoscale resolution.

title: Ten-fold Robust Expansion Microscopy
authors: Hugo G. J. Damstra, Boaz Mohar, Mark Eddison, Anna Akhmanova, Lukas C. Kapitein, Paul W. Tillberg
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the gelation chamber setup for cell samples, crucial for ensuring proper gelation. Fig 2 demonstrates the expansion process, highlighting the importance of water exchange for full expansion. The protocol details the fixation, immunofluorescence, and anchoring steps necessary for robust expansion. The method allows for ten-fold expansion, providing high-resolution imaging of subcellular structures. The paper emphasizes the compatibility of TREx with standard microscopy techniques, enabling detailed visualization of protein and membrane structures.
application_goal: The protocol enables ten-fold expansion of biological samples, allowing for high-resolution imaging of subcellular structures without the need for specialized equipment. This expansion provides sufficient de-crowding of specimens to visualize local protein densities using general protein and membrane stains, offering ultrastructural context to subcellular protein localization.
novelty: This work introduces Ten-fold Robust Expansion Microscopy (TREx), which achieves a ten-fold expansion in a single step, surpassing previous ExM methods that typically achieve four-fold expansion. Unlike iterative ExM, TREx maintains simplicity by using a single expansion step, making it accessible to users familiar with standard ExM protocols. The method retains the original ExM chemistry, ensuring ease of adoption while providing significant resolution enhancement. The study highlights the robustness of TREx in expanding both thick tissue sections and cultured cells, offering a versatile tool for high-resolution imaging.

title: Practical method for superresolution imaging of primary cilia and centrioles by expansion microscopy using an amplibody for fluorescence signal amplification
authors: Yohei Katoh, Shuhei Chiba, Kazuhisa Nakayama
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates the expansion of primary cilia and centrioles using proExM, showing improved resolution over conventional microscopy. Fig 2: Compares nonexpanded and expanded cells using SR microscopy, highlighting the enhanced visualization of ciliary structures. Fig 3: Introduces amplibodies for fluorescence signal amplification, addressing signal loss in expanded samples. Fig 4: Uses amplibody-proExM with Airyscan to analyze centriolar and ciliary protein localization, revealing detailed structural insights. Fig 5: Employs three-color amplibody-proExM to track IFT88 dynamics during ciliogenesis, illustrating molecular changes in ciliary development.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the practical observation of primary cilia and centrioles with high brightness and resolution, overcoming the limitations of fluorescence signal loss due to sample expansion. By combining proExM with Airyscan microscopy and introducing amplibodies, the study achieved subdiffraction imaging of ciliary structures, providing detailed insights into their organization and dynamics.
novelty: This study introduces amplibodies as a novel tool for fluorescence signal amplification in expansion microscopy, addressing a key limitation of signal loss in expanded samples. The combination of proExM with Airyscan microscopy offers a practical approach for high-resolution imaging of primary cilia and centrioles, surpassing the resolution of conventional SR methods like SIM and STED. The work advances the field by enabling detailed structural analysis of ciliary components, which was previously challenging due to diffraction limits and signal attenuation in expanded samples.

title: Expansion Microscopy Application for Calcium Protein Clustering Imaging in Cells and Brain Tissues
authors: Anastasiya Rakovskaya, Margarita Chigriai, Ilya Bezprozvanny, Ekaterina Pchitskaya
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the application of ExM to visualize STIM1 and IP3R protein clusters in HEK293T cells and mouse hippocampal neurons, highlighting the increase in cell area post-expansion. Fig 2 outlines the gelation chamber setup for ExM, crucial for maintaining sample integrity during expansion. Fig 3 shows pre- and post-processing images, emphasizing the importance of image processing for accurate cluster detection. Fig 4 and 5 detail the use of Icy software for cluster analysis, providing a method for quantifying protein clusters. Fig 6 and 7 compare STIM1 and IP3R clustering in different conditions, illustrating the method's utility in studying protein interactions in disease models.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization and quantitative analysis of protein clusters, specifically STIM1 and IP3R, in cultured cells and brain tissues. This approach allows for the study of protein interactions and clustering in cellular environments that are otherwise challenging to image with traditional microscopy techniques, providing insights into cellular processes and disease mechanisms.
novelty: This study presents an optimized ExM protocol for imaging protein clusters in both cultured cells and brain tissues, achieving nanometer resolution. The use of UV gel polish for sample fixation is a novel approach to improve imaging quality by reducing sample mobility. Compared to previous ExM variants, this protocol offers a straightforward method for studying protein clustering in deeper cellular structures, such as the ER, which are not accessible by TIRF microscopy. The study also provides a detailed analysis of STIM1 and IP3R clustering, contributing to the understanding of calcium signaling in normal and disease states.
source_file: Current Protocols - 2023 - Rakovskaya - Expansion Microscopy Application for Calcium Protein Clustering Imaging in Cells.pdf

title: Multiplexed and scalable super-resolution imaging of three-dimensional protein localization in size-adjustable tissues
authors: Taeyun Ku, Justin Swaney, Jeong-Yoon Park, Alexandre Albanese, Evan Murray, Jae Hun Cho, Young-Gyun Park, Vamsi Mangena, Jiapei Chen, Kwanghun Chung
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the MAP method's ability to expand tissues while preserving protein content and architecture. Fig 2 shows that MAP retains multiscale structural information, enabling super-resolution imaging of microtubules. Fig 3 highlights the compatibility of MAP with a wide range of antibodies, preserving the 3D proteome. Fig 4 illustrates the potential for highly multiplexed immunolabeling using MAP. Fig 5 explores MAP's utility in mapping neural projections, preserving continuity and enabling accurate tracing. Fig 6 demonstrates MAP's application to thick tissue staining and imaging, showing uniform staining and minimal signal attenuation.
application_goal: The MAP protocol enables super-resolution imaging of intact tissues by expanding them up to four- to fivefold while preserving their architecture and protein content. This allows for detailed visualization of multiscale organization, from subcellular structures to organ-wide connectivity, using standard antibodies and diffraction-limited microscopes.
novelty: MAP introduces a novel approach to tissue expansion by preventing intra- and interprotein crosslinking, allowing for natural expansion upon protein denaturation. This method preserves both fine subcellular details and organ-scale connectivity, overcoming limitations of previous ExM techniques that required tissue sectioning and protease treatment. MAP's compatibility with a wide range of antibodies and its ability to perform repeated rounds of immunolabeling without loss of antigenicity represent significant advancements over existing methods.
source_file: Multiplexed and scalable super-resolution imaging of three-dimensional protein localization in size-adjustable tissues.pdf

title: Ultrastructure Expansion Microscopy (U-ExM) of the Fission Yeast Schizosaccharomyces pombe
authors: Felix Mikus, Gautam Dey
summary: Fig 1: Introduction of dual luciferase reporter assay in S. pombe to study gene expression. Fig 2: High-throughput measurement of single-cell volume using fluorescence exclusion. Fig 3: Machine learning applied to measure cell dimensions in fission yeast. Fig 4: Ultrastructure expansion microscopy (U-ExM) applied to S. pombe for detailed cellular imaging. Fig 5: Live imaging of single-cell lineages using microfluidic devices. Fig 6: Analysis of cell wall mechanics in fission yeast. Fig 7: Pil1 co-tethering assay for protein-protein interaction detection. Fig 8: Bimolecular fluorescence complementation for studying protein interactions.
application_goal: The protocol enables detailed imaging and analysis of cellular structures and interactions in Schizosaccharomyces pombe, facilitating advanced studies in cell biology and genetics.
novelty: This work presents a comprehensive set of protocols for advanced imaging and genetic manipulation in Schizosaccharomyces pombe, including the application of ultrastructure expansion microscopy (U-ExM). The integration of machine learning for cell dimension measurement and the use of CRISPR/Cas9 for genome editing highlight the adaptation of cutting-edge technologies to this model organism. Compared to previous methods, these protocols offer enhanced resolution and precision in studying cellular processes, providing a valuable resource for researchers in the field.

title: The Expandables: Cracking the Staphylococcal Cell Wall for Expansion Microscopy
authors: Tobias C. Kunz, Marcel Rühling, Adriana Moldovan, Kerstin Paprotka, Vera Kozjak-Pavlovic, Thomas Rudel, Martin Fraunholz
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the necessity of lysostaphin for the expansion of S. aureus, highlighting the challenges posed by its robust cell wall. Fig 2 shows the application of ExM to visualize intracellular pathogens, enhancing resolution and clarity. Fig 3 illustrates the interaction of S. aureus with host cell vesicles, using immunolabeling to identify LAMP-1 and LC3. Fig 4 combines ExM with SIM to achieve a resolution of ~30 nm, further improving visualization of bacterial structures.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the isotropic 4x expansion of S. aureus, allowing for high-resolution imaging of both planktonic and intracellular bacteria using conventional confocal laser scanning microscopy. This approach facilitates the study of host-pathogen interactions at a resolution beyond the diffraction limit.
novelty: This study presents a modified ExM protocol specifically tailored for the Gram-positive pathogen S. aureus, overcoming the challenges posed by its thick and highly cross-linked cell wall. The use of lysostaphin, in combination with lysozyme and proteinase K, was crucial for achieving isotropic expansion. This work extends the applicability of ExM to Gram-positive bacteria, which have been difficult to expand due to their robust cell walls, and provides a method to study bacterial interactions with host cells at high resolution using standard microscopy equipment.
source_file: The Expandables Cracking the Staphylococcal Cell Wall for Expansion Microscopy.pdf

title: A protocol to expand plant nuclei
authors: Ivona Kubalova´a, Marketa Schmidt Cernohorska´, Martina Huranova´, Klaus Weisshart, Andreas Houben, Veit Schubert

title: Imaging nanoscale nuclear structures with expansion microscopy
authors: Emma L. Faulkner, Jeremy A. Pike, Ruth M. Densham, Evelyn Garlick, Steven G. Thomas, Robert K. Neely, Joanna R. Morris
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates isotropic expansion of the nucleus using LabelX, showing minimal distortion at 120-130 nm resolution. Fig 2 characterizes the nanoscale organization of DNA damage proteins BRCA1 and 53BP1, revealing five classes of structures. Fig 3 explores chromatin regulation effects on 53BP1 and BRCA1 positioning, showing changes upon SMARCAD1 and USP48 depletion. Fig 4 illustrates four-color ExM imaging, highlighting RAD51 accumulations and their spatial relationship with BRCA1 and 53BP1. These results underscore ExM's capability to analyze nuclear structures at nanoscale resolution.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the isotropic expansion of the nucleus, allowing for high-resolution imaging of nuclear structures and the detailed analysis of DNA damage response proteins. This approach facilitates the study of chromatin-regulated events and the spatial organization of multiple proteins within the nuclear architecture.
novelty: This study demonstrates the use of LabelX for isotropic expansion of the nucleus, achieving a resolution of 120-130 nm, which is comparable to or better than traditional super-resolution methods like SIM. The work highlights the ability to perform four-color imaging and analyze thousands of nanoscale features, offering a significant advantage over previous ExM variants and super-resolution techniques. The approach provides a cost-effective and accessible method for studying nuclear processes at nanoscale resolution, overcoming limitations of equipment and throughput associated with other super-resolution modalities.
source_file: Imaging nanoscale nuclear structures with expansion microscopy.pdf

title: Bio-orthogonal Glycan Imaging of Cultured Cells and Whole Animal C. elegans with Expansion Microscopy
authors: Joe Chin-Hun Kuo, Marshall J. Colville, Michelle R. Sorkin, Jacky Lok Ka Kuo, Ling Ting Huang, Dana N. Thornlow, Gwendolyn M. Beacham, Gunther Hollopeter, Matthew P. DeLisa, Christopher A. Alabi, Matthew J. Paszek
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the synthesis of multifunctional linkers for ExM, enabling bio-orthogonal glycan imaging. Fig 2 validates the linker on mammalian cells, showing specific labeling and retention. Fig 3 combines ExM with proExM for multicolor imaging of glycans and proteins on MCF10A cells. Fig 4 applies the linker to C. elegans, achieving nanoscale resolution of anatomical features. Fig 5 maps O-glycosylation in C. elegans, revealing glycan-enriched structures like the grinder teeth and body wall furrows.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization and mapping of glycans at nanoscale resolution in both cultured cells and whole organisms, specifically C. elegans. This approach allowed for the detailed study of glycan distribution and its association with anatomical features, providing insights into glycan function in biological processes.
novelty: This study introduces a new class of multifunctional linkers for expansion microscopy, enabling the bio-orthogonal imaging of glycans with high specificity and resolution. Compared to previous ExM variants, this approach allows for the detailed mapping of glycans in whole organisms, such as C. elegans, which was previously challenging due to cuticle impermeability. The use of a DBCO-based linker facilitates copper-free click chemistry, enhancing tissue penetration and labeling efficiency. This work expands the applicability of ExM to include glycan imaging, offering a powerful tool for studying glycobiology in various model systems.

title: Trifunctional sphingomyelin derivatives enable nanoscale resolution of sphingomyelin turnover in physiological and infection processes via expansion microscopy
authors: Marcel Rühling, Louise Kersting, Fabienne Wagner, Fabian Schumacher, Dominik Wigger, Dominic A. Helmerich, Tom Pfeuffer, Robin Elflein, Christian Kappe, Markus Sauer, Christoph Arenz, Burkhard Kleuser, Thomas Rudel, Martin Fraunholz, Jürgen Seibel
summary: Fig 1: The design and synthesis of trifunctional sphingomyelin derivatives are presented, enabling visualization of sphingomyelin turnover. Fig 2: The metabolic acceptance of the derivatives by human cells is demonstrated, showing uptake and processing. Fig 3: The localization of the derivatives in cellular compartments and their use in measuring bacterial sphingomyelinase activity is shown. Fig 4: The application of the derivatives in expansion microscopy is illustrated, highlighting their compatibility and resolution enhancement. Fig 5: The visualization of sphingolipid metabolism during Chlamydia infection is detailed, showing differential processing in host cells and inclusions.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of sphingomyelin distribution and metabolism at nanoscale resolution, particularly during infection processes, providing insights into the metabolic state of sphingomyelin in host-pathogen interactions.
novelty: This study introduces trifunctional sphingomyelin derivatives that allow for the visualization of sphingomyelin turnover with nanoscale resolution, a significant advancement over previous methods that struggled with lipid retention and resolution. The use of these derivatives in combination with expansion microscopy and Förster resonance energy transfer provides a powerful tool for studying sphingolipid metabolism in cells, particularly during infections. This approach offers a new avenue for analyzing lipid metabolism with high spatial resolution, surpassing the limitations of traditional fluorescence microscopy and previous expansion microscopy techniques.

title: Tracking down the molecular architecture of the synaptonemal complex by expansion microscopy
authors: Fabian U. Zwettler, Marie-Christin Spindler, Sebastian Reinhard, Teresa Klein, Andreas Kurz, Ricardo Benavente, Markus Sauer
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the tripartite structure of the synaptonemal complex (SC) in mice, highlighting the lateral and central elements. Fig 2 compares SIM and dSTORM images of SYCP3, showing MAP-SIM's similar resolution. Fig 3 presents 3D multicolor MAP-SIM images of SCs, revealing detailed molecular architecture. Fig 4 explores the complex organization of the SC central region, showing multimodal distributions of SYCP1 and SYCE3. Fig 5 uncovers structural details of the SC lateral element, demonstrating bifurcation and fraying of SYCP3 strands.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed visualization of the molecular architecture of the synaptonemal complex in mouse spermatocytes, revealing previously hidden structural details and allowing for high-resolution imaging of protein distributions within the SC.
novelty: This study demonstrates the use of MAP-SIM to achieve isotropic expansion and high-resolution imaging of the synaptonemal complex, providing insights into its molecular organization. Compared to previous ExM variants, MAP-SIM offers improved epitope accessibility and reduced linkage error, resulting in enhanced ultrastructural resolution. The combination with SIM allows for multicolor imaging, surpassing the limitations of traditional super-resolution methods like dSTORM, which are restricted to two colors. This work highlights the potential of MAP-SIM for studying complex protein assemblies in biological samples.
source_file: Tracking down the molecular architecture of the synaptonemal complex by expansion microscopy.pdf

title: Subdiffraction-resolution fluorescence imaging of immunological synapse formation between NK cells and A. fumigatus by expansion microscopy
authors: Nora Trinks, Sebastian Reinhard, Matthias Drobny, Linda Heilig, Jürgen Löffler, Markus Sauer, Ulrich Terpitz
summary: Fig 1: Developed a protocol for simultaneous expansion of NK cells and fungi, enabling detailed visualization of immunological synapse formation. Fig 2: Demonstrated cytoskeleton rearrangement in NK cells upon interaction with A. fumigatus, highlighting MTOC migration. Fig 3: Visualized lytic granules in NK cells, showing colocalization of perforin and granulysin, and their impact on fungal mitochondria. Fig 4: Assessed NK-cell degranulation, showing surface LAMP1 and intracellular perforin distribution. Fig 5: Used ExM to reveal perforin surrounded by LAMP1, providing insights into granule size changes post-degranulation.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the simultaneous expansion and imaging of NK cells and A. fumigatus hyphae, allowing for unprecedented spatial resolution in studying the immunological synapse formation and the dynamics of NK-cell degranulation.
novelty: This study introduces a refined ExM protocol that allows for the simultaneous expansion of mammalian and fungal cells, overcoming previous challenges in studying interactions between different organisms. The work demonstrates a significant resolution gain, enabling detailed visualization of NK-cell cytoskeleton rearrangement and degranulation processes. Compared to prior ExM variants, this approach provides a more comprehensive understanding of immune cell-fungus interactions, with potential applications in studying other complex biological systems.

title: Expansion Microscopy for Beginners: Visualizing Microtubules in Expanded Cultured HeLa Cells
authors: Chi Zhang, Jeong Seuk Kang, Shoh M. Asano, Ruixuan Gao, Edward S. Boyden
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the key steps in expanding fixed HeLa cells with immunostained microtubules. Fig 2 shows the construction of the gelation chamber and humidified tip box, crucial for gelation. Fig 3 details the digestion, expansion, and mounting of the sample, highlighting the importance of maintaining sample integrity. Fig 4 compares imaging of HeLa cells before and after expansion, demonstrating the enhanced resolution achieved through ExM.
application_goal: This protocol enables beginners to perform expansion microscopy on cultured HeLa cells, allowing them to visualize microtubules with nanoscale resolution using conventional microscopes. It serves as a practical exercise to familiarize users with the core steps of ExM, making it accessible for educational and training purposes.
novelty: This work provides a beginner-friendly protocol for expansion microscopy, focusing on HeLa cells with immunostained microtubules. It simplifies the ExM process, making it accessible to newcomers and educational settings. Compared to previous ExM variants, this protocol emphasizes ease of use and reproducibility, without requiring specialized equipment. The use of AcX for protein anchoring and a straightforward gelation process distinguishes it from more complex iterative expansion methods.
source_file: Expansion Microscopy for Beginners Visualizing Microtubules in Expanded Cultured HeLa Cells.pdf

title: Application of expansion microscopy on developing Arabidopsis seeds
authors: Ping Kao, Michael D. Nodine
summary: Fig 1: Sample collection and fixation of Arabidopsis seeds to prepare for expansion microscopy. Fig 2: Cell wall digestion and membrane permeabilization to facilitate monomer access. Fig 3: Seed isolation and monomer incubation to initiate gelation. Fig 4: Gelation and expansion to achieve physical enlargement of the sample. Fig 5: Fluorescent immunostaining to visualize proteins within the expanded seeds. Fig 6: Laser confocal microscope imaging to capture detailed images of cellular activities and subcellular structures.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed visualization of cellular activities and subcellular structures in developing Arabidopsis seeds, providing insights into plant development processes.
novelty: This study applies expansion microscopy to plant seeds, specifically Arabidopsis, which is less common compared to animal tissues. The use of laser confocal microscopy in combination with expansion microscopy allows for enhanced visualization of subcellular structures, offering a new perspective on plant development. This approach may provide a resolution gain compared to traditional microscopy methods used in plant biology.

title: Combining single-molecule and expansion microscopy in fission yeast to visualize protein structures at the nanostructural level
authors: Ilijana Vojnovic, Oliver D. Caspari, Mehmet Ali Hoşkan, Ulrike Endesfelder
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the SExY protocol achieving a fivefold expansion of fission yeast cells, crucial for visualizing protein structures. Fig 2 shows the optimization of cell wall digestion and protein retention, highlighting the use of Lallzyme MMX and glutathione. Fig 3 presents the successful imaging of various proteins, including low-abundance targets like cnp1, using the SExY protocol. The study emphasizes the protocol's ability to retain 50% of the fluorescent signal, doubling the retention compared to previous methods.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of protein structures in fission yeast at a nanostructural level, particularly benefiting studies targeting low-abundance proteins or those relying on genetic labeling. The SExY method combines expansion microscopy with PALM, providing a robust approach for high-resolution imaging in microbiology.
novelty: This work introduces a novel combination of expansion microscopy with PALM, termed ExPALM, specifically optimized for fission yeast. The SExY protocol achieves a fivefold expansion, surpassing the typical threefold expansion of other ExM-SRM combinations like ExSTORM. The study also enhances protein retention by optimizing cell wall digestion and gelation steps, making it particularly suitable for low-abundance protein studies. This advancement provides a significant improvement over previous ExM protocols, offering a new tool for high-resolution imaging in microbial research.

title: Mechanical expansion microscopy
authors: Yuhang Fan, Youngbin Lim, Livia S. Wyss, Seongjin Park, Cancan Xue, Huikang Fu, Jingyi Fei, Yi Hong, Bo Wang

title: Nanoscale imaging of clinical specimens using conventional and rapid-expansion pathology
authors: Octavian Bucur, Feifei Fu, Mike Calderon, Geetha H. Mylvaganam, Ngoc L. Ly, Jimmy Day, Simon Watkin, Bruce D. Walker, Edward S. Boyden, Yongxin Zhao
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the ExPath and rExPath workflows for processing clinical specimens, highlighting the steps for expansion and imaging. Fig 2 compares ExPath with super-resolution methods, showing low distortion and effective resolution improvement. Fig 3 demonstrates the transparency and autofluorescence reduction achieved by ExPath. Fig 4 validates ExPath's ability to reduce autofluorescence in breast tissue. Fig 5 showcases ExPath imaging across various human tissue types, both normal and cancerous. Fig 6 presents rExPath imaging of lymph node specimens, demonstrating its application in clinical settings. Fig 7 compares ExPath and rExPath on H&E-stained and frozen tissue sections, confirming the rapid protocol's efficacy.
application_goal: The protocol enables nanoscale resolution imaging of human tissues using conventional microscopes, facilitating detailed analysis of clinical specimens without the need for specialized super-resolution equipment.
novelty: This study introduces a rapid variant of expansion pathology (rExPath) that significantly reduces processing time for thin tissue sections while maintaining low distortion and high resolution. Compared to traditional super-resolution methods, ExPath and rExPath offer a more accessible and cost-effective approach for imaging large clinical specimens, leveraging conventional microscopy setups. The iterative expansion strategy and optimized chemistry, including the use of sodium acrylate and AcX for anchoring, provide enhanced resolution and tissue transparency, setting this work apart from previous ExM variants.
source_file: Nanoscale imaging of clinical specimens using conventional and rapid-expansion pathology.pdf

title: Whole-brain imaging with ExLLSM
authors: Gao, R. et al.
summary: Fig 1: ExM combined with LLSM for super-resolution imaging of mouse cortical column and Drosophila brain. Fig 2: Development of tools for handling large image data and reconstructing image volumes from 25,000 subvolumes.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed super-resolution structural imaging of entire brains, allowing for comprehensive visualization of complex neural structures.
novelty: This study introduces ExLLSM, a novel combination of expansion microscopy with lattice light-sheet microscopy, enabling super-resolution imaging of large brain volumes. Compared to previous ExM methods, ExLLSM offers faster imaging with lower light doses, making it suitable for large-scale brain imaging. The development of bespoke data handling tools further enhances its applicability for high-throughput imaging.

title: Human skeletal muscle cell atlas: Unraveling cellular secrets utilizing ‘muscle-on-a-chip’, differential expansion microscopy, mass spectrometry, nanothermometry and machine learning
authors: Bhanu P. Jena, Domenico L. Gatti, Suzan Arslanturk, Sebastian Pernal, Douglas J. Taatjes
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the use of Differential Expansion Microscopy (DExM) to visualize the size and distribution of nuclei and myosin filaments in human skeletal muscle cells, highlighting the method's ability to maintain spatial relationships. Fig 2 shows a transmission electron microscope image of a human skeletal muscle cell, emphasizing the spatial localization of the nucleus and mitochondria. Fig 3 illustrates the use of deep learning models to predict muscle cell morphology and function from DExM images, aiming to infer biochemical and biophysical markers. Fig 4 summarizes the integration of various technologies to create a comprehensive understanding of the human skeletal muscle cell and develop a reference atlas.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the creation of a detailed reference atlas of human skeletal muscle cells, facilitating the precise deconvolution of intracellular organelle structures and their distribution. This atlas aids in the diagnosis of pathological samples and enhances the understanding of muscle cell dynamics in sedentary and exercised states, ultimately contributing to the development of precision therapeutics.
novelty: This study introduces Differential Expansion Microscopy (DExM) as an advancement over traditional Expansion Microscopy (ExM), addressing issues such as loss of cellular contents and retention of organelle integrity. DExM allows for nanometer-scale imaging while maintaining the spatial relationships of subcellular structures, which is critical for understanding muscle cell function. The integration of DExM with machine learning and other advanced techniques provides a comprehensive approach to studying human skeletal muscle cells, offering insights that surpass previous ExM variants and super-resolution methods.

title: Nanoscale imaging of tumor cell exosomes by expansion single molecule localization microscopy (ExSMLM)
authors: Jinxiu Wei, Siyao Zhang, Jiangnan Yuan, Zhuyuan Wang, Shenfei Zong, Yiping Cui
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the ExSMLM experimental setup for tumor cell exosomes, highlighting the immunofluorescence labeling and gel polymerization steps. Fig 2 characterizes the exosomes using TEM and NTA, confirming their size and concentration. Fig 3 demonstrates the expansion process, showing a 4.6-fold increase in gel size. Fig 4 presents dual-color ExSMLM imaging of HER2 and CD63 on SKBR3 exosomes, revealing nanoscale protein substructures. Fig 5 compares pre- and post-expansion imaging, emphasizing the resolution enhancement. Fig 6 provides detailed ExSMLM images of individual exosomes, showcasing the distribution of proteins. Fig 7 and Fig 8 extend the method to MDA-MB-231 and HeLa exosomes, demonstrating its versatility.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of nanoscale substructures of proteins on single exosomes, providing detailed insights into the distribution of HER2 and CD63 proteins. This high-resolution imaging technique allows for the study of exosomal heterogeneity and its implications in cancer diagnosis and treatment.
novelty: This study introduces ExSMLM, a novel combination of expansion microscopy and single molecule localization microscopy, to achieve unprecedented resolution in imaging tumor cell exosomes. Compared to prior ExM variants and super-resolution methods like STED and SIM, ExSMLM offers a significant resolution enhancement, down to the molecular level, by expanding exosomes 4.6 times. The use of a swellable polyelectrolyte gel and specific immunofluorescence labeling allows for detailed visualization of protein distributions on exosomes, which was not possible with previous techniques. This advancement opens new avenues for studying exosome-related biological processes and disease pathogenesis.

title: Expansion Microscopy with a Thermally Adjustable Expansion Factor Using Thermoresponsive Biospecimen−Hydrogel Hybrids
authors: Sunah Kang, Sohyun Park, Hojoon Song, Dongkil Choi, Han-Eol Park, Benjamin H. Ahn, Sung-Yon Kim, Yan Lee
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the T-RevExM process, highlighting the reversible expansion of cell-hydrogel hybrids. Fig 2 shows the thermoresponsive behavior of LCST hydrogels, demonstrating reversible expansion. Fig 3 details the preparation of cell-hydrogel hybrids, emphasizing the embedding and expansion process. Fig 4 presents CLSM images of HeLa cell-hydrogel hybrids, showcasing enhanced resolution at expanded states. Fig 5 analyzes image resolution improvements, comparing microtubule images at different expansion states. Fig 6 evaluates distortion levels, confirming minimal distortion in expanded images. Fig 7 applies T-RevExM to mouse brain tissue, revealing detailed dendritic structures. Fig 8 introduces UCST-based thermopositive hydrogels, expanding with temperature increase. Fig 9 displays CLSM images of UCST cell-hydrogel hybrids, highlighting resolution gains. Fig 10 and 11 further analyze image resolution and distortion in thermopositive RevExM, confirming effective resolution enhancement.
application_goal: The protocol enabled reversible control of the expansion factor, allowing for rapid wide-field imaging at a deswelled state and high-resolution imaging at an expanded state. This flexibility facilitates detailed visualization of subcellular structures and rapid observation of overall biospecimen shapes, overcoming limitations of traditional optical microscopy.
novelty: This study introduces a novel approach to expansion microscopy by incorporating thermoresponsive hydrogels, allowing reversible control of expansion factors through temperature changes. Unlike previous ExM methods focused on maximal expansion, T-RevExM offers adjustable expansion, providing both wide-field and high-resolution imaging in a single sample. The use of LCST and UCST hydrogels represents a significant advancement, enabling temperature-dependent reversible expansion without compromising image quality or introducing significant distortion. This method enhances imaging flexibility and resolution, offering a practical solution for detailed biological investigations.

title: Expansion Microscopy on Saccharomyces cerevisiae
authors: Artemis G. Korovesi, Leonor Morgado, Marco Fumasoni, Ricardo Henriques, Hannah S. Heil, Mario Del Rosario
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the workflow of the expansion microscopy protocol and shows images of yeast before and after expansion, highlighting the increase in size and retention of circularity. The protocol involves cell wall digestion, gelation, and isotropic expansion, allowing for detailed visualization of yeast ultrastructure. The study demonstrates the use of DAPI and NHS-Ester staining to provide an overview of cellular structures, offering a complementary approach to immunolabeling methods.
application_goal: The protocol enables the visualization of the ultrastructure of Saccharomyces cerevisiae by overcoming the challenges posed by the yeast cell wall, which is resistant to conventional expansion microscopy techniques. By employing a modified ExM protocol with a 3.5x expansion factor, the study allows for detailed imaging of yeast cells, facilitating the study of subcellular structures that are otherwise difficult to resolve due to the small size of yeast cells.
novelty: This work presents a modified expansion microscopy protocol specifically adapted for Saccharomyces cerevisiae, addressing the challenge of the yeast cell wall's resistance to expansion. Unlike previous protocols that rely on immunolabeling, this study employs pan-labelling with NHS-Ester and DAPI, providing a comprehensive view of the cellular ultrastructure. The protocol achieves a 3.5x expansion factor, offering a balance between resolution enhancement and sample integrity. This approach complements existing methods and can be combined with other super-resolution techniques like airyscan and SIM, providing a versatile tool for yeast cell imaging.

title: Ultrastructure expansion microscopy reveals the cellular architecture of budding and fission yeast
authors: Kerstin Hinterndorfer, Marine H. Laporte, Felix Mikus, Lucas Tafur, Clélia Bourgoint, Manoel Prouteau, Gautam Dey, Robbie Loewith, Paul Guichard, Virginie Hamel
summary: Fig 1 establishes a U-ExM workflow for yeast, optimizing cell wall digestion and fixation. Fig 2 visualizes the SPB organization in S. cerevisiae, resolving Tub4 signals at the SPB. Fig 3 resolves the Sfi1p–Cdc31p complex at the SPB, showing its spatial organization. Fig 4 quantifies NPCs in S. pombe throughout the cell cycle, demonstrating U-ExM's capability to resolve individual NPCs. Fig 5 compares cryo-fixation and chemical fixation, showing improved microtubule preservation with cryo-fixation. Fig 6 combines specific antibody labelling with NHS-ester staining to map cellular structures.
application_goal: The protocol enabled visualization of the microtubule cytoskeleton and nuclear pore complexes in yeast at nanoscale resolution, providing insights into cellular architecture and facilitating studies of macromolecular complexes using conventional microscopes.
novelty: This study extends U-ExM to yeast, overcoming challenges posed by the robust cell wall and enabling 4-fold expansion. Compared to previous ExM variants, this method maintains proteome integrity and reduces linkage errors by post-expansion labelling. The use of cryo-fixation further enhances structural preservation, offering a resolution comparable to or better than SIM, and allowing detailed visualization of structures like the Sfi1p–Cdc31p complex and NPCs, which were previously challenging to resolve in yeast.

title: Measurement of expansion factor and distortion for expansion microscopy using isolated renal glomeruli as landmarks
authors: Chen Zhu, Aidong Wang, Lili Chen, Liangsheng Guo, Jiajia Ye, Qilin Chen, Qi Wang, Guojia Yao, Qin Xia, Tianyu Cai, Jiayun Guo, Zhenyu Yang, Zhenglong Sun, Yuwei Xu, Guoyuan Lu, Zexin Zhang, Jingyuan Cao, Ying Liu, Huizhong Xu
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the use of renal glomeruli as landmarks for expansion microscopy, highlighting their visibility and structural integrity post-expansion. Fig 2 details the expansion properties of glomeruli, showing low distortion and reliable expansion factors. Fig 3 applies glomeruli landmarks to tissue sections, enabling accurate EF and distortion measurements without fluorescent labels. Fig 4 extends the method to adherent cell samples, using immunofluorescence to track expansion. Fig 5 explores multiple rounds of expansion, confirming the method's utility in iterative expansions with high EF accuracy.
application_goal: The protocol enabled precise measurement of expansion factors and distortion in expansion microscopy by using renal glomeruli as visible and structurally stable landmarks. This approach facilitates the relocation of regions of interest in expanded samples, allowing for accurate quantification of expansion without the need for fluorescent labeling.
novelty: This study introduces the use of renal glomeruli as landmarks in expansion microscopy, providing a robust method for measuring expansion factors and distortion. Unlike previous methods that rely heavily on fluorescent labeling, this approach allows for accurate measurements using bright field microscopy. The use of glomeruli, which are easily identifiable and expandable, offers a significant advantage in iterative expansion protocols, enabling high-resolution imaging with minimal distortion. This method stands out by simplifying the process of locating and imaging the same regions before and after expansion, a task that is often challenging with traditional ExM techniques.

title: Using Expansion Microscopy to Physically Enlarge Whole-Mount Drosophila Embryos for Super-Resolution Imaging
authors: Samia Parveen, Nicolas W. Jones, Ian Millerschultz, Adam C. Paré
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the ExM protocol on Drosophila embryos, highlighting the ability to visualize subcellular protein localization. Fig 2 details the manual devitellinization process, crucial for selecting properly staged embryos. Fig 3 compares unexpanded and expanded embryos, showing a consistent four-fold increase in size. Fig 4 illustrates the enhanced resolution of subcellular structures, such as the actomyosin cytoskeleton and mitochondrial networks, achieved through ExM.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of subcellular details in Drosophila embryos that are not visible with conventional confocal microscopy, allowing researchers to study protein localization patterns and mitochondrial network architecture at super-resolution.
novelty: This study adapts expansion microscopy for whole-mount Drosophila embryos, achieving a four-fold expansion that allows for super-resolution imaging using standard confocal microscopes. Unlike previous ExM variants, this protocol uses MA-NHS chemistry for protein anchoring, enhancing the visualization of subcellular structures without the need for specialized super-resolution hardware. The method provides a cost-effective alternative to traditional super-resolution techniques, making it accessible to a broader range of developmental biology labs.

title: Ultrastructure Expansion Microscopy for the Analysis of Trypanosoma cruzi Infection
authors: Felipe Castro Capurro, Victoria Lucia Alonso
summary: Fig 1: Computer-aided drug discovery methods for Chagas disease are described, highlighting their role in identifying new pharmacological targets. Fig 2: Chromatin interaction maps of Trypanosoma cruzi are presented, providing insights into genomic organization. Fig 3: A genome-wide GC composition tool is introduced for unbiased assessment of Trypanosoma cruzi genomic compartments. Fig 4: An algorithm for annotation of Trypanosoma cruzi MASP sequences is detailed, aiding in genetic studies. Fig 5: Cloning-free genome editing by CRISPR/T7RNAP/Cas9 in Trypanosoma cruzi is demonstrated, showcasing advancements in genetic manipulation.
application_goal: The protocol enables detailed analysis of Trypanosoma cruzi infection, providing insights into the parasite's interaction with host cells and potential targets for therapeutic intervention.
novelty: This work compiles advanced methodologies for studying Trypanosoma cruzi, emphasizing the integration of computational and experimental approaches. Compared to previous methods, this compilation offers a comprehensive toolkit for genetic, biochemical, and cell biology studies, facilitating a deeper understanding of Chagas disease. The use of CRISPR/Cas9 for genome editing in Trypanosoma cruzi represents a significant advancement, allowing for precise genetic manipulation and target validation, which was previously challenging due to the absence of RNAi pathways in the parasite.

title: Superresolution imaging of Drosophila tissues using expansion microscopy
authors: Nan Jiang, Hyeon-Jin Kim, Tyler J. Chozinski, Jorge E. Azpurua, Benjamin A. Eaton, Joshua C. Vaughan, Jay Z. Parrish
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates isotropic expansion of Drosophila tissues, showing pre- and postexpansion imaging. Fig 2 highlights the improved resolution of subcellular structures, such as mitochondria and microtubules, using ExM. Fig 3 focuses on superresolution imaging of presynaptic active zones (AZs) at the neuromuscular junction, revealing structural details not visible with conventional microscopy. Fig 4 examines age-dependent changes in AZ structure, showing increased AZ size and complexity with age. Fig 5 explores improved axial resolution for analyzing cell-cell interactions, particularly dendrite-epithelial interactions in sensory neurons.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed visualization of fine structural elements in Drosophila tissues, such as synaptic active zones and cell-cell interactions, which are not resolvable with conventional microscopy. This allows for more accurate analysis of synapse number and structure, as well as the study of age-dependent changes in synaptic architecture.
novelty: This study extends the utility of ExM to Drosophila tissues, demonstrating its compatibility with various tissue types and highlighting the need for tissue-specific optimization. Compared to prior ExM variants, this work achieves a resolution of ∼70 nm using standard confocal microscopy, comparable to other superresolution methods like STED. The study introduces a chitinase treatment step to facilitate expansion of chitin-rich tissues, such as the Drosophila body wall, which is a novel adaptation for ExM in organisms with rigid exoskeletons.
source_file: Superresolution imaging of Drosophila tissues using expansion microscopy.pdf

title: Nanoscale Whole-Body Expansion Microscopy Revealed the Early Skeletal Developmental Malformation Induced by Silver Nanoparticles
authors: Mengyu Wang, Wen-Xiong Wang
summary: Fig 1 shows the Ag concentration in zebrafish and medium, highlighting the low solubility of Ag+ from AgNPs. Fig 2 presents confocal imaging of AgNPs dissolution in zebrafish, indicating in vivo dissolution. Fig 3 illustrates the whole-body expansion microscopy imaging of zebrafish organs, providing nanoscale resolution of major organ systems. Fig 4 reveals anatomical changes in zebrafish body trunk due to AgNP exposure, showing skeletal muscle reduction and notochord curvature. These figures collectively demonstrate the impact of AgNPs on zebrafish development at a cellular level.
application_goal: The protocol enabled nanoscale resolution imaging of whole zebrafish, allowing for detailed observation of developmental malformations induced by silver nanoparticles. This approach provided insights into the biological toxicity of AgNPs, focusing on their impact on skeletal and muscular development in zebrafish.
novelty: This study introduces whole-body expansion microscopy (whole-ExM) as a novel technique for achieving nanoscale resolution imaging of entire small organisms like zebrafish. Unlike previous methods that required complex equipment, whole-ExM allows for detailed visualization of organ structures and developmental changes. The study highlights the in vivo dissolution of AgNPs as a significant factor in developmental toxicity, providing a new perspective on the biological effects of nanomaterials. This work advances the field by enabling cellular-level observations and emphasizing the need to assess the toxicity of nanoparticles themselves, rather than just their ionic forms.

title: Multiplexing spatially resolved omics with increased resolution: Development of an expansion microscopy platform
authors: Marisa Vanheusden
summary: Fig 1: The concept of expansion microscopy is introduced, highlighting its ability to expand biological samples for nanoscale imaging. Fig 2: The isotropic expansion potential of the hydrogel is evaluated, showing its capability for accurate structural representation. Fig 3: Improved labeling strategies are developed to retain fluorescent signals and facilitate crosslinking of biomolecules. Fig 4: The optimized workflow is applied to protein multiplexing using immuno-SABER. Fig 5: Expanded samples are imaged with super-resolution microscopy, demonstrating potential for resolving protein ultrastructures.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the integration of expansion microscopy with multiplexed omics approaches, allowing for the detailed spatial mapping of biomolecules within tissue samples. This advancement facilitates the study of cellular processes with high precision and could lead to better understanding of health and disease mechanisms.
novelty: This work advances expansion microscopy by optimizing labeling strategies and demonstrating its application in protein multiplexing. Compared to prior ExM variants, this study emphasizes the potential for isotropic expansion and improved fluorescent signal retention. The integration with super-resolution microscopy, such as STED, offers enhanced resolution capabilities, positioning this platform as a versatile tool for spatially resolved multi-omics studies.

title: Visualization of the intracellular structures of bacteria using expansion microscopy
authors: N A Rumyantseva, A D Vedyaykin, I E Vishnyakov, M A Khodorkovskii
summary: Fig 1 shows micrographs of E. coli cells before and after expansion, highlighting the effectiveness of proteinase K digestion. Fig 2 demonstrates the preservation of the Z-ring structure using formaldehyde fixation and proteinase K cleavage. Fig 3 illustrates the uneven expansion of DNA, suggesting the need for further protocol optimization. The study emphasizes the importance of sample preparation conditions in preserving intracellular structures during ExM.
application_goal: The protocol enabled visualization of intracellular structures in E. coli with significantly higher resolution than conventional fluorescence microscopy, allowing detailed analysis of protein localization within bacterial cells.
novelty: This study demonstrates the application of expansion microscopy to visualize bacterial structures, achieving a resolution of about 60 nanometers without the need for complex optical equipment. The work highlights the importance of optimizing sample preparation, particularly proteolytic cleavage, to preserve structures like the Z-ring. Compared to prior ExM variants, this approach provides a practical alternative for studying small bacterial cells, such as mycoplasmas, which are challenging to investigate due to their size being near the diffraction limit.

title: Expansion microscopy resolves the thylakoid structure of spinach
authors: Peter R. Bos, Jarne Berentsen, Emilie Wientjes
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates the workflow of ExM on thylakoids, highlighting the anchoring and expansion process. Fig 2: Shows a 3D reconstruction of a thylakoid, emphasizing the ability to visualize the entire chloroplast structure. Fig 3: Provides top views of expanded chloroplasts, illustrating the granum diameter measurement. Fig 4: Displays side views of chloroplasts, revealing the helical wrapping of stroma lamellae around grana. Fig 5: Probes the resolution of side-view images, showing distinguishable stroma lamellae.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed visualization of the 3D structure of spinach thylakoids, allowing for precise measurement of granum dimensions and the helical wrapping of stroma lamellae. This approach facilitates the study of thylakoid organization and its response to environmental conditions.
novelty: This study introduces a method combining U-ExM and pan-ExM to achieve high-resolution imaging of chloroplasts, bridging the resolution gap between EM and fluorescence microscopy. The approach allows for fast and reliable imaging of thylakoid structures, overcoming limitations of traditional methods like EM and AFM. The use of ExM provides a significant resolution improvement, enabling detailed analysis of thylakoid architecture and protein localization, which was previously challenging due to chlorophyll autofluorescence.

title: Mapping Protein Distribution in the Canine Photoreceptor Sensory Cilium and Calyceal Processes by Ultrastructure Expansion Microscopy
authors: Kei Takahashi, Raghavi Sudharsan, William A. Beltran
sample: cryosections from frozen archival retinal tissues
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the photoreceptor sensory cilium (PSC) architecture, highlighting the connecting cilium (CC) as a critical gateway for ciliary trafficking. Fig 2 compares tissue integrity and protein localization under different U-ExM conditions, showing that longer fixation preserves OS structure better. Fig 3 details the tubulin-based molecular structure of rod and cone PSCs, revealing significant differences in CC length and bulge region width. Fig 4 maps proteins in the bulge region and distal axoneme, identifying unique localization patterns for LCA5, RP1, and CCDC66. Fig 5 and 6 explore the localization of inner scaffold and Y-link-associated proteins, respectively, showing shorter CC lengths in cones. Fig 7 examines ciliary trafficking and distal appendage-related proteins, suggesting IFT57 and SDCCAG8 localize to distal appendages. Fig 8 and 9 characterize the ciliary rootlet and calyceal processes, respectively, highlighting structural differences between rods and cones.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed molecular mapping of the photoreceptor sensory cilium (PSC) in canine retinas, revealing significant structural differences between rod and cone photoreceptors. This study provides insights into the molecular architecture of the PSC, which is crucial for understanding the pathogenesis of retinal ciliopathies and evaluating the efficacy of gene therapies in canine models.
novelty: This work advances the application of ultrastructure expansion microscopy (U-ExM) to canine retinal tissues, including long-term cryopreserved samples, achieving nanometer-scale resolution. The study reveals significant architectural differences between rod and cone PSCs, which have not been extensively characterized before. Unlike previous ExM studies focused on mouse models, this research highlights the potential of using canine models to study retinal diseases, offering a more relevant system for understanding human retinal ciliopathies due to the structural similarities in photoreceptor architecture.

title: Imaging cellular ultrastructures using expansion microscopy (U-ExM)
authors: Davide Gambarotto, Fabian U. Zwettler, Maeva Le Guennec, Marketa Schmidt-Cernohorska, Denis Fortun, Susanne Borgers, Jörn Heine, Jan-Gero Schloetel, Matthias Reuss, Michael Unser, Edward S. Boyden, Markus Sauer, Virginie Hamel, Paul Guichard
summary: Fig 1: U-ExM was developed to preserve ultrastructure in isolated centrioles, revealing ninefold symmetry. Fig 2: U-ExM combined with confocal microscopy showed higher labeling efficiency and resolution than dSTORM. Fig 3: U-ExM applied to mammalian cells expanded microtubules and mitochondria with minimal distortion, preserving structural integrity. The method alleviates antibody competition and fluorophore loss, improving visualization of molecular architecture.
application_goal: The protocol enabled visualization of ultrastructural details of macromolecular assemblies, such as centriolar chirality, which were previously only observable by electron microscopy. U-ExM preserves the ultrastructure of isolated organelles and can be applied to both isolated and cellular samples, allowing for detailed study of molecular architecture.
novelty: U-ExM improves upon standard ExM by preserving ultrastructural details and alleviating antibody competition. Unlike previous methods, U-ExM avoids chemical fixation, improving structural integrity. It allows for isotropic expansion and can be combined with STED microscopy to reveal features like centriole chirality, previously only seen with super-resolution methods. This approach offers a significant advancement in visualizing molecular details with high spatial resolution.
source_file: Imaging cellular ultrastructures using expansion microscopy (U-ExM).pdf

title: Photoacoustic expansion microscopy of melanosomes
authors: Tingting Li, Xinrui Gong, Heng Guo, Lei Xi
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the OR-PAM system configuration and its performance in imaging nanoparticles. Fig 2 demonstrates the expansion protocol and shows a typical PA-ExM image of an expanded melanoma cell. Fig 3 compares PA imaging results of melanoma cells with different expansion rates, highlighting the improved resolution with increased expansion. Fig 4 presents a 3D imaging comparison of unexpanded and 64× expanded B16-F10 cells, showing enhanced visualization of melanosomes post-expansion.
application_goal: The protocol enabled super-resolution photoacoustic imaging of melanosomes in melanoma cells, overcoming the limitations of conventional OR-PAM systems in resolving densely distributed subcellular structures. By expanding the cells, the study achieved better separation and visualization of melanosomes, demonstrating the potential of PA-ExM for detailed subcellular imaging.
novelty: This study introduces PA-ExM, combining OR-PAM with expansion microscopy to achieve super-resolution imaging of melanosomes without breaking the optical diffraction limit. Compared to previous ExM variants, this approach allows for the visualization of subcellular structures using a low-NA objective, reducing photobleaching risks. The work extends the application of ExM to label-free imaging of melanosomes, offering a cost-effective alternative to ultrahigh NA objectives and enhancing the resolving capability of OR-PAM.

title: Expansion microscopy facilitates quantitative super-resolution studies of cytoskeletal structures in kinetoplastid parasites
authors: Peter Gorilak, Martina Pružincová, Hana Vachova, Marie Olšinová, Marketa Schmidt Cernohorska, Vladimir Varga
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the use of ExM to visualize the microtubule corset and axoneme in T. brucei and L. major, highlighting the method's ability to resolve individual microtubules. Fig 2 shows the resolution of individual structural components, such as axonemal microtubule doublets, emphasizing ExM's capability to discern fine details. Fig 3 explores structures inside the corset, revealing the presence of microtubule quartets and neck microtubules, which are crucial for understanding cytoskeletal organization. Fig 4 localizes cytoskeletal proteins in relation to microtubule-based structures, demonstrating ExM's potential for detailed protein mapping.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of cytoskeletal structures in kinetoplastid parasites with high resolution, facilitating the study of rare cell types and transient cell cycle phases. It allowed for the localization of proteins within the cellular volume, providing insights into the organization and dynamics of the cytoskeleton.
novelty: This study demonstrates the application of ExM to kinetoplastid parasites, a group of organisms with complex cytoskeletal structures. Compared to traditional EM and super-resolution techniques like STED and STORM, ExM offers a simpler and faster method for obtaining high-resolution images without specialized equipment. The study highlights the method's ability to resolve individual microtubules and localize proteins with high precision, providing a valuable tool for studying cytoskeletal organization in these parasites.
source_file: Expansion microscopy facilitates quantitative super-resolution studies of cytoskeletal structures in kinetoplastid parasites.pdf
