title: Click-ExM enables expansion microscopy for all biomolecules
authors: De-en Sun, Xinqi Fan, Yujie Shi, Hao Zhang, Zhimin Huang, Bo Cheng, Qi Tang, Wei Li, Yuntao Zhu, Jinyi Bai, Wei Liu, Yuan Li, Xiaoting Wang, Xiaoguang Lei, Xing Chen
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the click-ExM workflow, integrating click labeling with ExM for diverse biomolecules. Fig 2 demonstrates click-ExM imaging of lipids in COS-7 cells, showing preserved fluorescence post-expansion. Fig 3 applies click-ExM to glycans, resolving sialoglycans on HeLa cells and rat neurons. Fig 4 extends click-ExM to proteins, nucleic acids, and small molecules, highlighting its versatility across biomolecules. The study showcases click-ExM's compatibility with signal amplification and two-color imaging, broadening ExM's applicability.
application_goal: The protocol enabled super-resolution imaging of a wide range of biomolecules, including lipids, glycans, proteins, nucleic acids, and small molecules, using a unified procedure. This expands the applicability of ExM beyond proteins and nucleic acids, allowing for detailed visualization of cellular structures and biomolecular distributions in various biological samples.
novelty: Click-ExM introduces a novel integration of click chemistry with expansion microscopy, allowing for the imaging of biomolecules previously challenging to visualize with ExM, such as lipids and glycans. This approach leverages the versatility of click labeling to expand the range of biomolecules that can be imaged with ExM, providing a unified protocol that adapts the proExM workflow. The method achieves nanoscale resolution and is compatible with signal amplification and multicolor imaging, offering significant advancements over traditional ExM and super-resolution techniques.
source_file: Click-ExM enables expansion microscopy for all biomolecules.pdf

title: Toward Ultra-Resolution Biomolecular Mapping in Cells with Expansion Microscopy
authors: Yixi Liu
summary: Fig 1 introduces the concept of expansion microscopy (ExM) and its potential for nanoscale imaging. Fig 2 discusses the development of cleavable fixatives for improved ultrastructure preservation in ExM. Fig 3 presents subzero temperature expansion microscopy (subExM) for enhanced ultrastructure preservation and protein retention. The methods and results highlight the importance of maintaining biomolecular integrity during sample preparation.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the preservation of ultrastructure and enhanced fluorescent signal intensity, allowing for detailed investigation of structure-function relationships at nanoscale resolution.
novelty: This work introduces subzero temperature expansion microscopy (subExM), which improves structure preservation and fluorescent signal intensity compared to previous ExM methods. The use of cleavable fixatives and subExM represents a significant advancement in maintaining biomolecular integrity, offering a new approach to study biological systems at nanoscale resolution.

title: Orthogonal DNA Self-Assembly-Based Expansion Microscopy Platform for Amplified, Multiplexed Biomarker Imaging
authors: Xiaochen Tang, Wenxing Li, Tianshu Chen, Runchi Zhang, Yilin Yan, Chenbin Liu, Hongquan Gou, Fanping Zhang, Qiuhui Pan, Dongsheng Mao, Xiaoli Zhu
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the orthogonal DNA self-assembly-based ExM (o-DAExM) platform, highlighting its signal amplification and multiplexing capabilities. Fig 2 optimizes ExM by varying crosslinker concentrations, showing improved expansion and fluorescence retention. Fig 3 compares traditional IF-based ExM with o-DAExM, demonstrating enhanced signal intensity and structural clarity with DNA self-assembly. Fig 4 further analyzes imaging effects, confirming o-DAExM's superior signal amplification and SNR. Fig 5 applies o-DAExM to exosome imaging, revealing detailed structural information. Fig 6 showcases multiplexed protein target analysis, demonstrating o-DAExM's capability for high-throughput imaging.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution and high-sensitivity imaging of cellular structures and exosomes, overcoming limitations of traditional methods by enhancing signal amplification and multiplexing capabilities through orthogonal DNA self-assembly.
novelty: This work introduces o-DAExM, which combines DNA self-assembly with ExM to address challenges of low SNR and limited multiplexing in traditional ExM. Unlike previous methods, o-DAExM enhances signal output and resolution without requiring specialized equipment. The use of DNA self-assembly for signal amplification is novel, providing a versatile tool for high-throughput and high-resolution imaging, particularly beneficial for analyzing low-abundance targets like exosomes and enabling multiplexed protein and RNA imaging.
source_file: Small Methods - 2024 - Tang - Orthogonal DNA Self‐Assembly‐Based Expansion Microscopy Platform for Amplified  Multiplexed.pdf

title: Nanoscale imaging of clinical specimens using pathology-optimized expansion microscopy
authors: Yongxin Zhao, Octavian Bucur, Humayun Irshad, Fei Chen, Astrid Weins, Andreea L Stancu, Eun-Young Oh, Marcello DiStasio, Vanda Torous, Benjamin Glass, Isaac E Stillman, Stuart J Schnitt, Andrew H Beck, Edward S Boyden
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the ExPath workflow on human breast tissue, showing low distortion and high expansion factors. Fig 2 highlights the reduction of tissue autofluorescence post-expansion, improving signal-to-background ratios. Fig 3 showcases ExPath's applicability across various human tissues, revealing sub-diffraction-limit features. Fig 4 illustrates ExPath's ability to visualize kidney podocyte foot processes, enabling diagnosis of nephrotic diseases. Fig 5 shows improved computational pathology in breast lesions, with enhanced nuclear segmentation and classification accuracy post-expansion.
application_goal: The protocol enabled nanoscale imaging of clinical samples using conventional microscopes, facilitating the diagnosis of diseases like kidney minimal change disease and improving computational pathology for early breast lesions.
novelty: ExPath represents a significant advancement over previous ExM techniques by optimizing the protocol for clinical samples, including FFPE and H&E-stained tissues. Unlike traditional super-resolution methods requiring complex equipment, ExPath allows nanoscale imaging with standard microscopes, making it accessible for clinical pathology. The method's ability to reduce autofluorescence and enhance computational analysis of tissue samples marks a substantial improvement in diagnostic capabilities, particularly for diseases with known nanoscale pathology.

title: Chromatin expansion microscopy reveals nanoscale organization of transcription and chromatin
authors: Mark E. Pownall, Liyun Miao, Charles E. Vejnar, Ons M’Saad, Alice Sherrard, Megan A. Frederick, Maria D. J. Benitez, Curtis W. Boswell, Kenneth S. Zaret, Joerg Bewersdorf, Antonio J. Giraldez
resolution: 15-nm lateral resolution on a confocal microscope and ~3 nm in STED
summary: Fig 1: ChromExM visualizes Nanog and miR-430 transcription in zebrafish embryos, showing Nanog's role in transcriptional activation. Fig 2: ChromExM achieves single-nucleosome resolution, preserving chromatin organization and demonstrating isotropic expansion. Fig 3: Nanog and Pol II organization during genome activation is characterized, revealing distinct classes of transcriptional organization. Fig 4: Inhibition of transcription elongation shows enhancer-promoter dynamics, supporting the 'kiss and kick' model of transcriptional regulation.
application_goal: The protocol enabled visualization of chromatin and transcription factors at nanoscale resolution in vivo, revealing the organization of transcriptional hubs and the dynamics of enhancer-promoter interactions during genome activation.
novelty: This study introduces ChromExM, which combines expansion microscopy with multimodal labeling to achieve nucleosomal resolution, surpassing previous ExM applications and super-resolution methods like ChromEMT. The work provides new insights into the nanoscale organization of transcription factors and RNA Polymerase II, revealing distinct classes of transcriptional organization and supporting a novel 'kiss and kick' model of enhancer-promoter dynamics.

title: A Universal Labeling Strategy for Nucleic Acids in Expansion Microscopy
authors: Gang Wen, Marisa Vanheusden, Volker Leen, Taoufik Rohand, Katy Vandereyken, Thierry Voet, Johan Hofkens
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the design of TRITON linkers for RNA anchoring in ExM, enabling multicolor staining. Fig 2 shows the synthesis and optimization of chemical probes for nucleic acids, highlighting the efficiency of platinum(II)-based compounds. Fig 3 demonstrates immunostaining of microtubules using TRITON linkers in 4x and 10x ExM, achieving resolutions of 105 nm and 50 nm, respectively. Fig 4 presents RNA FISH with HCR v3.0 in ExM, showing high specificity and sensitivity for mRNA detection post-expansion.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the rapid functionalization of DNA oligonucleotides for use in ExM, allowing for the detection and localization of RNA transcripts with high specificity and sensitivity. This approach facilitates multicolor analysis and signal amplification, overcoming limitations of traditional FISH methods in dense cellular environments.
novelty: This study introduces a universal labeling strategy using TRITON linkers for nucleic acids in ExM, achieving nanoscale resolution imaging of RNA. Compared to previous ExM variants, this method offers improved anchoring and labeling efficiency, particularly with platinum(II)-based compounds. The approach allows for direct grafting of oligonucleotides and is compatible with existing RNA FISH amplification techniques, providing a cost-effective and versatile solution for multiplexed RNA analysis.
inferred_keywords: detection and localization of RNA transcripts

title: Visualisation of Euglena gracilis organelles and cytoskeleton using expansion microscopy
authors: Aneˇzka Konupkov´a, Priscila Peña-Diaz, Vladim´ır Hampl
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the expansion factor determination of E. gracilis cells using pellicular microtubules and axoneme width. Fig 2 provides a detailed view of the microtubular ultrastructure of the flagellar pocket and mitotic cells, highlighting the spatial organization of microtubular roots. Fig 3 shows mitochondrial morphologies at different culture ages, revealing changes in the mitochondrial network. Fig 4 illustrates mitochondrial morphology changes during the light phase, indicating dynamic structural adaptations. Fig 5 presents chloroplast morphologies across different culture ages, showing variations in chloroplast size and Rubisco activase signal intensity.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of cellular structures in Euglena gracilis, which are otherwise difficult to stain due to the organism's complex pellicle. This method allows for the immunolabeling of internal structures, facilitating the study of organelle morphology and dynamics under different growth conditions.
novelty: This study applies expansion microscopy to Euglena gracilis, an organism with a complex pellicle that hinders traditional immunofluorescence. The work demonstrates a modified protocol that preserves cell structures and allows for the visualization of organelles and cytoskeleton with submicron resolution. Compared to previous ExM applications, this study highlights the method's utility in protists and its potential to complement electron microscopy by providing 3D reconstructions of cellular structures.

title: Fluorescent labeling of abundant reactive entities (FLARE) for cleared-tissue and super-resolution microscopy
authors: Min Yen Lee, Chenyi Mao, Adam K. Glaser, Marcus A. Woodworth, Aaron R. Halpern, Adilijiang Ali, Jonathan T. C. Liu, Joshua C. Vaughan
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the FLARE chemistry and sample processing workflow for ExM and cleared-tissue microscopy, highlighting the labeling of carbohydrates, amines, and DNA. Fig 2 presents suggested workflows for combining FLARE with DNA FISH and immunofluorescence, emphasizing the flexibility of FLARE in various experimental setups. Fig 3 compares fixation conditions for expanded RPE cells, showing the preservation of cellular structures with PFA and GA fixation. Fig 4 demonstrates FLARE staining on human tissue microarrays, revealing detailed tissue morphology and contrast. Fig 5 showcases the compatibility of FLARE with other procedures, including immunostaining and DNA FISH, in mouse kidney tissue.
application_goal: The FLARE protocol enables rapid and robust fluorescent labeling of biological specimens, providing well-contrasted visualization of key features in both thin and thick tissues or cultured cells. It is particularly useful for cleared-tissue microscopy and expansion super-resolution microscopy, allowing for high-resolution, volumetric imaging compatible with various sample processing methods.
novelty: FLARE introduces a versatile and straightforward labeling method that addresses limitations of traditional fluorescent proteins and antibody conjugates, particularly in thick specimens. By targeting abundant chemical groups with reactive fluorophores, FLARE provides histology-like contrast with fluorescent probes, enhancing compatibility with volumetric imaging. Compared to prior ExM variants, FLARE offers improved multiplexing capabilities and is easily implemented in standard fluorescence microscopy workflows, making it a valuable tool for diverse biological applications.

title: A Beginner’s Guide to the Characterization of Hydrogel Microarchitecture for Cellular Applications
authors: Francisco Drusso Martinez-Garcia, Tony Fischer, Alexander Hayn, Claudia Tanja Mierke, Janette Kay Burgess, Martin Conrad Harmsen
summary: Fig 1 shows the increase in publications related to hydrogel microarchitecture, highlighting its growing importance. Fig 2 illustrates the use of electron-based imaging techniques like SEM, Cryo-SEM, and ESEM to visualize hydrogel structures. Fig 3 demonstrates SEM-EDX mapping to identify elements in hydrogels and cells. Fig 4 compares photon-based techniques like µ-CT, CLSM, and SHG for hydrogel imaging. Fig 5 presents data on collagen hydrogel microarchitecture parameters using CLSM and SEM. Fig 6 describes AFM for measuring hydrogel surface topology and mechanical properties.
application_goal: The protocol enables the characterization of hydrogel microarchitecture, which is crucial for understanding cell behavior in 3D environments and optimizing hydrogels for applications in tissue engineering and regenerative medicine.
novelty: This work provides a comprehensive review of techniques for characterizing hydrogel microarchitecture, emphasizing the importance of accurate and reproducible methods. It highlights the limitations of traditional SEM due to dehydration artifacts and suggests alternative methods like Cryo-SEM, ESEM, and photon-based techniques for more accurate imaging. The review also discusses the impact of microarchitecture on cell behavior, which is critical for advancing hydrogel applications in biomedical research.

title: Evaluation of Direct Grafting Strategies via Trivalent Anchoring for Enabling Lipid Membrane and Cytoskeleton Staining in Expansion Microscopy
authors: Gang Wen, Marisa Vanheusden, Aline Acke, Donato Valli, Robert K. Neely, Volker Leen, Johan Hofkens
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the multivalent linker concept for efficient localization and grafting of signaling moieties. Fig 2 demonstrates TRITON labels applied in ExM for direct cytoskeleton and lipid membrane staining, showing pre- and post-expansion images with improved resolution. Fig 3 shows immunostaining of α-tubulin using DNA-conjugated antibodies and post-expansion fluorescent oligo readout, highlighting high signal-to-noise ratio. The study showcases TRITON's capability for diverse biomolecular targeting in ExM.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the direct grafting of fluorophores to the hydrogel network, allowing for the visualization of lipid membranes and cytoskeletal structures in expansion microscopy. This approach facilitates the use of small-molecule targeting and post-expansion labeling, broadening the range of compatible fluorescent reporters and enhancing imaging resolution.
novelty: This work introduces TRITON, a trivalent linker strategy that allows for direct grafting of fluorophores in expansion microscopy, overcoming limitations of traditional antibody-based methods. Compared to prior ExM variants, TRITON enables the use of small-molecule targeting and post-expansion labeling, providing a robust solution for imaging lipid membranes and cytoskeletal structures. The study demonstrates significant resolution improvements and compatibility with a broader range of fluorescent dyes, setting a new standard for biomolecular imaging in ExM.

title: Parasite Genomics: Methods and Protocols
authors: Luis M. de Pablos, Javier Sotillo
summary: Fig 1: Describes hybrid genome assembly of Trypanosoma cruzi using long-read sequencing to improve contiguity. Fig 2: Details Hi-C sequencing for 3D genome conformation in Plasmodium falciparum, enhancing understanding of genomic interactions. Fig 3: Presents a method for reconstructing mitochondrial genomes from NGS data, aiding in the study of helminth parasites. Fig 4: Introduces a pipeline for ortholog and paralog gene identification, crucial for comparative genomics. Fig 5: Demonstrates the use of amplicon sequencing for detecting mixed parasite infections, improving diagnostic capabilities.
application_goal: The protocol enables comprehensive genomic analysis of protozoan parasites, facilitating high-quality genome assembly and enhancing the understanding of genetic complexity and regulatory mechanisms in parasites.
novelty: This work integrates long-read sequencing technologies with traditional short-read methods to overcome challenges in assembling highly repetitive parasite genomes. The use of hybrid assembly strategies significantly improves genome completeness compared to previous methods. Additionally, the application of ultrastructure expansion microscopy in studying Toxoplasma gondii represents a novel approach to understanding cellular architecture, offering insights not achievable with conventional microscopy techniques.

title: Ultrastructure expansion microscopy: Enlarging our perspective on apicomplexan cell division
authors: Sofía Horjales, Florencia Sena, María E. Francia
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the cell division modes used by apicomplexan parasites, highlighting the diversity in their division strategies. Fig 2 focuses on the application of U-ExM in Toxoplasma gondii, revealing detailed structures of the apical complex and basal complex during endodyogeny. The study emphasizes the utility of U-ExM in visualizing minute structures that are crucial for understanding the cell division mechanisms in apicomplexans.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of nanoscale structures in apicomplexan parasites, providing unprecedented insights into their cell division mechanisms. This enhanced understanding is crucial for developing strategies to combat diseases caused by these parasites.
novelty: This work places U-ExM as a transformative tool in the study of apicomplexan cell biology, offering a resolution that approaches electron microscopy but with the accessibility of conventional light microscopy. Compared to prior ExM variants, U-ExM allows for detailed visualization of proteomes and structural features without the need for specialized equipment, making it a valuable method for studying minute cellular structures in a wide range of organisms.

title: Expansion microscopy of the mitotic spindle
authors: Ivana Ponjavic, Kruno Vukusic, Iva M. Tolic
summary: Fig 1 describes the protocol for expansion microscopy of tubulin in the spindle, highlighting the steps involved in cell culture and synchronization. Fig 2 focuses on the protocol for expansion microscopy of PRC1-GFP, detailing the imaging process. Fig 3 presents the analysis and statistics, including determining the expansion factor and comparing visualization approaches for the bridging fiber. Fig 4 demonstrates that microtubule bundles in the mitotic spindle are better resolved after expansion. Fig 5 shows PRC1-GFP on microtubule bundles in expanded spindles, emphasizing the improved resolution.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed visualization of the mitotic spindle, allowing for better resolution of microtubule bundles and the localization of PRC1-GFP, which is crucial for understanding spindle dynamics.
novelty: This work provides a detailed protocol for expansion microscopy applied to the mitotic spindle, focusing on tubulin and PRC1-GFP. Compared to prior ExM variants, this study emphasizes the improved resolution of microtubule bundles, which is significant for spindle research. The work does not introduce new chemistry or anchoring strategies but applies existing methods to a new sample type, enhancing the visualization of spindle components.

title: Tetra‑gel enables superior accuracy in combined super‑resolution imaging and expansion microscopy
authors: Hsuan Lee, Chih‑Chieh Yu, Edward S. Boyden, Xiaowei Zhuang, Pallav Kosuri
summary: Fig 1: DNA origami nanorulers were used to assess structural preservation in PA gels, revealing distortions post-denaturation. Fig 2: Tetra-gel embedding preserved 28-nm features even after denaturation, showing superior structural preservation compared to PA gels. Fig 3: Tetra-gel ExM combined with STORM resolved 11-nm features in rectangular DNA origami, demonstrating increased resolution and accuracy.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the combination of tetra-gel expansion microscopy with STORM to achieve higher resolution imaging of DNA origami structures, preserving structural details at the sub-10 nm scale.
novelty: This study introduces tetra-gel, a new hydrogel that improves structural preservation in expansion microscopy by using click chemistry instead of free-radical polymerization. Compared to traditional PA gels, tetra-gel maintains structural accuracy at scales below 30 nm, enabling the resolution of 11-nm features when combined with STORM. This represents a significant advancement over previous ExM methods, which often introduced distortions at these scales.
source_file: Tetra-gel enables superior accuracy in combined super-resolution imaging and expansion microscopy.pdf

title: Visualization of Trypanosoma brucei flagellar pocket collar biogenesis identifies two new cytoskeletal structures
authors: Marie Zelená, Elina Casas, Chloé Lambert, Nicolas Landrein, Denis Dacheux, Eloïse Bertiaux, Kim Ivan Abesamis, Gang Dong, Vladimir Varga, Derrick Roy Robinson, Mélanie Bonhivers
summary: Fig 1 shows the use of U-ExM to track the formation of the new microtubule quartet (nMtQ) and flagellum elongation in T. brucei, highlighting the sequential assembly process. Fig 2 details the localization of BILBO1 during flagellar pocket collar (FPC) biogenesis, identifying novel structures like the proFPC and FPC-interconnecting fiber (FPC-IF). Fig 3 maps the stages of FPC formation in relation to the flagellar pocket, emphasizing the dynamic changes during cell division. Fig 4 illustrates the parallel biogenesis pathways of the FPC and hook complex (HC), with MORN1 localization providing insights into their coordination. Fig 5 confirms the presence of FPC-specific proteins in the proFPC and FPC-IF, underscoring their specialized roles.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the detailed visualization of the biogenesis of the flagellar pocket collar (FPC) in Trypanosoma brucei, revealing previously uncharacterized structures and providing insights into the assembly and regulation of essential cytoskeletal components during cell division.
novelty: This study advances the understanding of FPC biogenesis in T. brucei by employing ultrastructure expansion microscopy (U-ExM) to uncover novel structures like the proFPC and FPC-interconnecting fiber (FPC-IF). Unlike previous ExM variants, this approach provides a comprehensive view of the dynamic processes involved in FPC and hook complex (HC) formation, highlighting the de novo assembly of these structures. The work distinguishes itself by elucidating the molecular composition and functional roles of these components, offering a new perspective on cytoskeletal organization in trypanosomes.

title: Prospects and limitations of expansion microscopy in chromatin ultrastructure determination
authors: Ivona Kubalová, Markéta Schmidt Černohorská, Martina Huranová, Klaus Weisshart, Andreas Houben, Veit Schubert
summary: Fig 1 shows the expansion of isolated barley nuclei using different fixation and denaturation conditions to maintain chromatin ultrastructure. Fig 2 compares the chromatin structure in unexpanded and expanded nuclei using wide-field, deconvolution, and SIM, highlighting the resolution differences. Fig 3 demonstrates the expansion factor achieved and the visibility of chromatin domains in expanded nuclei. Fig 4 presents the chromatin structure preservation using the optimized ExM protocol. Fig 5 and 6 illustrate the detection of centromeric repeats and CENH3 in expanded nuclei, showing the preservation of general chromatin organization but altered ultrastructure.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of chromatin structures in isolated barley nuclei at a resolution of 25-35 nm, revealing chromatin domains and centromeric repeats that are not visible in unexpanded nuclei. This approach allows for the analysis of chromatin organization and the localization of specific DNA sequences and proteins within the expanded nuclei.
novelty: This study applies expansion microscopy to plant-derived samples, specifically isolated barley nuclei, achieving a 4.2x expansion factor. The work demonstrates the potential of ExM to visualize chromatin structures at a higher resolution than traditional wide-field microscopy. However, it also highlights the challenges in preserving chromatin ultrastructure during expansion, as the network-like organization is impaired. Compared to previous ExM protocols, this study emphasizes the need for optimized fixation and expansion conditions to maintain structural integrity in plant samples.

title: Expansion microscopy provides new insights into the cytoskeleton of malaria parasites including the conservation of a conoid
authors: Eloïse Bertiaux, Aure´lia C. Balestra, Lorène Bournonville, Vincent Louvel, Bohumil Maco, Dominique Soldati-Favre, Mathieu Brochet, Paul Guichard, Virginie Hamel
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the application of U-ExM to various Plasmodium stages, revealing detailed cytoskeletal structures. Fig 2 explores axoneme assembly in microgametocytes, highlighting the role of polyglutamylation. Fig 3 shows the resolution of mitotic hemispindles and subpellicular microtubules in schizonts, emphasizing species-specific differences. Fig 4 identifies a conoid-like structure in ookinetes, suggesting evolutionary conservation. Fig 5 uses NHS-ester staining to map the apical complex, providing spatial context for the ATR and APR.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of Plasmodium cytoskeletal structures at a nanoscale resolution, bridging the gap between traditional fluorescent microscopy and electron microscopy. This approach allowed for the detailed study of axoneme assembly and the identification of a conserved conoid-like structure in ookinetes, providing new insights into the parasite's cytoskeletal organization.
novelty: This study introduces the use of ultrastructure expansion microscopy (U-ExM) to Plasmodium, revealing nanoscale details of its cytoskeleton previously only accessible by electron microscopy. Unlike prior ExM variants, this work uncovers a conserved conoid-like structure in Plasmodium ookinetes, challenging the notion that this feature was lost in the genus. The study also highlights the potential of U-ExM to resolve species-specific differences in microtubule organization, offering a new tool for malaria research.

title: Stimuli-Responsive Phosphate Hydrogel: A Study on Swelling Behavior, Mechanical Properties, and Application in Expansion Microscopy
authors: Yokly Leng, Collin N. Britten, Fatema Tarannum, Kayla Foley, Christopher Billings, Yingtao Liu, Keisha B. Walters
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the chemical structures of MOEP, BMOEP, and PMOEP. Fig 2 shows ESEM images of the hydrogel's porous structure, crucial for drug delivery. Fig 3 presents the deswelling rate in various salt solutions, highlighting the impact of cation valency. Fig 4 uses EDS mapping to confirm uniform calcium distribution in the hydrogel. Fig 5 compares swelling rates and degrees in different salt concentrations, showing monovalent cations induce more swelling. Fig 6 examines pH effects on swelling, with neutral pH showing the highest degree. Fig 7 and 8 explore temperature and polymerization conditions, revealing decreased swelling with increased temperature and pH. Fig 9 and 10 discuss mechanical properties and fracture behavior, with 40°C polymerization yielding the highest compressive stress. Fig 11 confirms low cytotoxicity of PMOEP hydrogels. Fig 12 demonstrates twofold cell expansion using PMOEP in ExM, though image quality was affected by autofluorescence and digestion steps.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the use of PMOEP hydrogels in expansion microscopy, allowing for a twofold expansion of 4T1 mouse breast cancer cells. This expansion facilitates improved imaging resolution, overcoming the diffraction limit and enhancing visualization of cellular structures. The study highlights the potential of PMOEP hydrogels in biomedical applications, such as drug delivery and tissue engineering, due to their stimuli-responsive swelling behavior and low cytotoxicity.
novelty: This work introduces a novel application of phosphate-based PMOEP hydrogels in expansion microscopy, achieving a twofold cellular expansion. Compared to prior ExM variants, this study utilizes a unique phosphate chemistry that enhances biocompatibility and swelling capabilities in various environments. The PMOEP hydrogels offer a significant advantage in imaging resolution, reaching ∼65 nm, which is four times better than conventional microscopy. The study also explores the impact of polymerization conditions on swelling behavior, providing insights into optimizing hydrogel properties for diverse biomedical applications.

antibodies_and_dyes.name: wheat germ agglutinin conjugated with AlexaFluor488 (WGA-AF488)

title: Expansion microscopy on Drosophila spermatocyte centrioles
authors: Alan Wainman
summary: Fig 1 describes the preparation of Drosophila centriole samples for expansion microscopy, highlighting the importance of sample integrity. Fig 2 outlines the Pro-ExM method for testes preparations, emphasizing the role of antibody staining in visualization. Fig 3 compares Pro-ExM and U-ExM techniques, demonstrating their effectiveness in expanding Drosophila spermatocyte centrioles. Fig 4 shows the combination of modified U-ExM with structured illumination microscopy (SIM), enhancing resolution and detail. Fig 5 discusses the measurement of centriole size and isotropic expansion, providing insights into the accuracy of expansion techniques.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed visualization of Drosophila spermatocyte centrioles, allowing for precise measurement of their size and structure. By combining expansion microscopy with structured illumination microscopy, the study achieved enhanced resolution, facilitating the study of centrioles as molecular rulers.
novelty: This work advances the field by applying expansion microscopy to Drosophila spermatocyte centrioles, a novel model system for this technique. The combination of modified U-ExM with SIM represents a significant improvement over traditional methods, offering enhanced resolution and detail. This approach provides a new avenue for studying centrioles, which are critical for understanding cell division and structure. Compared to prior ExM variants, this study demonstrates the potential of combining expansion with super-resolution techniques to achieve unprecedented insights into cellular structures.

title: Geometry-preserving expansion microscopy microplates enable high-fidelity nanoscale distortion mapping
authors: Rajpinder S. Seehra, Samantha J. Warrington, Benjamin H.K. Allouis, Thomas M.D. Sheard, Michael E. Spencer, Tayla Shakespeare, Ashley Cadby, Daniel Bose, David Strutt, Izzy Jayasinghe
sample: dissected pupal Drosophila melanogaster wing tissue
summary: Figure 1 illustrates the design of a 3D-printable microplate system for ExM, which preserves gel geometry and allows in situ imaging. Figure 2 demonstrates pre- and post-ExM imaging of HeLa cells, highlighting the ability to track distortions. Figure 3 shows dual-color ExM experiments, revealing sub-cellular distortions in HeLa cells and tissue-wide distortions in Drosophila wing tissue. The study emphasizes the importance of pre- and post-ExM imaging for accurate distortion mapping.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-fidelity mapping of nanoscale distortions in expanded biological samples by preserving gel geometry and allowing in situ imaging, thus improving reproducibility and reducing manual handling errors.
novelty: This study introduces a 3D-printable microplate system that preserves gel geometry during ExM, allowing for in situ imaging and accurate distortion mapping. Unlike previous ExM methods that require manual handling, this approach reduces errors and improves reproducibility. The use of a microplate system is a novel strategy that enhances the scalability and convenience of ExM, making it more accessible for high-resolution imaging of both cell cultures and tissue samples.

title: Expansion microscopy reveals unique ultrastructural features of pathogenic budding yeast species
authors: Md. Hashim Reza, Srijana Dutta, Rohit Goyal, Hiral Shah, Gautam Dey, Kaustuv Sanyal
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates the U-ExM protocol for C. albicans, highlighting the expansion and visualization of sub-cellular structures. Fig 2: Shows mitochondrial network segregation before nuclear segregation, confirmed by co-staining with BodipyTR. Fig 3: Details nucleolar segregation during the cell cycle, validated by Nop1 staining. Fig 4: Explores SPB organization, revealing asymmetry and Tub4 distribution differences. Fig 5: Extends U-ExM to other fungal pathogens, showing sub-cellular organization and SPB arrangements.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of sub-cellular structures in Candida albicans and other fungal pathogens at high resolution, revealing unique features such as the side-by-side arrangement of spindle pole bodies and mitochondrial dynamics during cell division.
novelty: This study advances the application of ultrastructure expansion microscopy (U-ExM) to pathogenic fungi, particularly Candida albicans, revealing unique ultrastructural features not observed in model organisms like Saccharomyces cerevisiae. The work highlights the ability to resolve inner and outer plaques of spindle pole bodies and demonstrates the applicability of U-ExM to a range of fungal pathogens, overcoming challenges posed by complex cell wall compositions. This approach provides a cost-effective alternative to super-resolution microscopy, offering insights into fungal cell biology and pathogenicity.

title: An Image-Based High-Throughput and High-Content Drug Screening Method Based on Microarray and Expansion Microscopy
authors: Junfang Xie, Daobo Han, Shuai Xu, Haitong Zhang, Yonghe Li, Mingshan Zhang, Zhichao Deng, Jianguo Tian, Qing Ye
summary: Fig 1: Developed a high-throughput, high-content drug screening method using SMAP and proExM, improving efficiency. Fig 2: Demonstrated SMAP preparation and cell culture viability, ensuring no cross-contamination. Fig 3: Combined SMAP with proExM, achieving 68 nm resolution imaging of microtubules. Fig 4: Analyzed microtubule aggregation under docetaxel treatment, showing increased bundling with higher concentrations. Fig 5: Evaluated microtubule density changes with β-elemene, revealing dispersion at higher doses. Fig 6: Assessed mitochondrial morphology in untreated cells, establishing baseline distribution. Fig 7: Quantified mitochondrial changes post-CCCP treatment, highlighting increased round/intermediate forms.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-throughput and high-content drug screening by combining a superhydrophobic microwell array plate (SMAP) with protein-retention expansion microscopy (proExM). This method allows for rapid and detailed morphological analysis of cellular structures, such as microtubules and mitochondria, under various drug treatments, facilitating efficient pharmacodynamics evaluation.
novelty: This study introduces a novel combination of SMAP and proExM for drug screening, offering a significant improvement in throughput and content richness over traditional methods. Unlike previous ExM variants, this approach does not rely on silicon molds, allowing flexible microwell geometry. The method achieves a resolution of 68 nm, comparable to super-resolution techniques, but with reduced time and equipment requirements, making it accessible for typical biomedical laboratories.

title: Nanoscale Resolution Imaging of Whole Mouse Embryos Using Expansion Microscopy
authors: Jueun Sim, Chan E. Park, In Cho, Kyeongbae Min, Minho Eom, Seungjae Han, Hyungju Jeon, Eun-Seo Cho, Yunjeong Lee, Young Hyun Yun, Sungho Lee, Deok-Hyeon Cheon, Jihyun Kim, Museong Kim, Hyun-Ju Cho, Ji-Won Park, Ajeet Kumar, Yosep Chong, Jeong Seuk Kang, Kiryl D. Piatkevich, Erica E. Jung, Du-Seock Kang, Seok-Kyu Kwon, Jinhyun Kim, Ki-Jun Yoon, Jeong-Soo Lee, Cheol-Hee Kim, Myunghwan Choi, Jin Woo Kim, Mi-Ryoung Song, Hyung Jin Choi, Edward S. Boyden, Young-Gyu Yoon, Jae-Byum Chang
sample: mouse embryo slices, whole mouse embryos, neonatal mice
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the development of the whole-body ExM protocol, showing the cyclic digestion process for uniform expansion of mouse embryos. Fig 2 validates the isotropy of whole-body ExM at micro- and nanoscales, confirming minimal distortion. Fig 3 illustrates the compatibility of whole-body ExM with immunolabeling, preserving fluorescent signals in various antibodies. Fig 4 maps neuronal systems in developing mouse embryos, highlighting the detailed visualization of the peripheral nervous system. Fig 5 showcases super-resolution imaging of the abducens nerve, demonstrating the technique's ability to resolve fine neuronal structures.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the super-resolution, volumetric imaging of anatomical structures, proteins, and endogenous fluorescent proteins within embryonic and neonatal mice by expanding them 4-fold. This allows for detailed studies of molecular changes in various vertebrates, facilitating research into developmental biology and nervous system organization.
novelty: This work introduces a novel ExM technique, termed whole-body ExM, which overcomes the challenges of expanding calcified tissues in mouse embryos. By employing a cyclic digestion process, the method achieves uniform expansion and retains fluorescent protein signals, enabling nanoscale imaging of entire vertebrate bodies. Compared to prior ExM variants, this approach is easily applicable across a wide range of developmental stages, including neonatal mice, without extensive optimization. The technique's ability to preserve molecular labeling and achieve sub-100 nm resolution represents a significant advancement in the field.

title: Expansion microscopy reveals characteristic ultrastructural features of pathogenic budding yeast species
authors: Md Hashim Reza, Srijana Dutta, Rohit Goyal, Hiral Shah, Gautam Dey, Kaustuv Sanyal
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrated the U-ExM protocol for C. albicans, showing subcellular structures and expansion factor. Fig 2: Confirmed mitochondrial network using co-staining, showing organelle inheritance patterns. Fig 3: Visualized nucleolar segregation during cell division, highlighting nucleolar dynamics. Fig 4: Analyzed SPB organization, showing asymmetry and protein density differences. Fig 5: Compared spindle dynamics between C. albicans and S. cerevisiae, showing faster anaphase onset in C. albicans. Fig 6: Extended U-ExM to other fungal pathogens, revealing conserved SPB arrangements.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution visualization of subcellular structures in C. albicans and other fungal pathogens, providing insights into organelle dynamics and SPB organization, which are crucial for understanding fungal cell biology and pathogenicity.
novelty: This study extends the application of U-ExM to a broader range of fungal pathogens, revealing conserved ultrastructural features like the side-by-side SPB arrangement. Compared to previous ExM applications, this work highlights the adaptability of the protocol to diverse fungal species, overcoming challenges posed by complex cell wall compositions. The study also provides a detailed analysis of SPB asymmetry and organelle inheritance, offering new insights into fungal cell division mechanisms.

title: Iterative expansion microscopy
authors: Jae-Byum Chang, Fei Chen, Young-Gyu Yoon, Erica E Jung, Hazen Babcock, Jeong Seuk Kang, Shoh Asano, Ho-Jun Suk, Nikita Pak, Paul W Tillberg, Asmamaw T Wassie, Dawen Cai, Edward S Boyden
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the concept of iterative expansion microscopy (iExM), showing the process of embedding a sample in a swellable gel, expanding it, and then embedding it again for further expansion. Fig 2 validates iExM by demonstrating the resolution of microtubules in BS-C-1 cells, achieving ~20x expansion and resolving structures with confocal microscopy. Fig 3 applies iExM to synaptic proteins in mouse brain, resolving synaptic architecture and protein organization. Fig 4 demonstrates the use of iExM in visualizing dendritic spines in mouse hippocampal circuitry, highlighting the method's ability to resolve fine neural structures.
application_goal: The protocol enabled visualization of synaptic proteins and detailed architecture of dendritic spines in mouse brain circuitry, achieving ~25-nm-resolution imaging of cells and tissues on conventional microscopes.
novelty: This work introduces iterative expansion microscopy (iExM), which achieves expansion factors of ~16-22x, significantly surpassing the ~4.5x expansion of previous ExM variants. The method allows for ~25-nm resolution imaging, comparable to high-performing super-resolution techniques, and is applicable to large-volume imaging. The use of cleavable crosslinkers and re-embedding strategies represents a novel approach to achieving high expansion factors while maintaining structural integrity.

title: Expansion microscopy in Placozoa: improving resolution and preservation of fragile samples during marine expedition
authors: Daria Y. Romanova, Yana A. Frank, Leonid L. Moroz
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the chemical scheme for obtaining the copolymer used in ExM. Fig 2 shows the expansion process during dialysis, highlighting the increase in size of Trichoplax. Fig 3 presents confocal microscopy images of ExM samples, demonstrating the preservation of cellular structures. Fig 4 details the use of acridine orange for visualizing lysosomes and other cellular components in Trichoplax.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the detailed examination of subcellular organization in fragile marine organisms like Placozoa, allowing for improved resolution and preservation during long-term marine expeditions. This approach facilitates the study of microscopic animals in remote locations, providing a cost-efficient method for storage and fixation.
novelty: This study adapts expansion microscopy for Placozoa, a novel application for this phylum, enabling subcellular resolution without morphological disarray. The protocol includes a modified polymerization and storage method, allowing for long-term preservation of samples in field conditions. Compared to prior ExM variants, this approach offers a practical solution for studying fragile marine organisms, expanding the applicability of ExM to new sample types and environments.

title: Optimizing Scanning Bessel Beam Light Sheet Microscopy with Custom-designed Lens Cap for Expansion Microscopy
authors: Chia-Ming Lee, Xuejiao Tian, Min-Ju Tsai, Bi-Chang Chen
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates the system diagram of Scanning Bessel Beam Light Sheet Microscopy and compares images of expanded zebrafish liver with and without the custom lens cap, showing improved signal capture and reduced background with the lens cap.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the acquisition of high-quality light sheet images for large ExM samples by using a custom-designed lens cap to convert a standard objective into an immersion objective with a longer working distance, thus overcoming limitations in imaging large samples.
novelty: This work introduces a cost-effective custom lens cap that transforms a standard objective into an immersion objective, allowing for high-resolution imaging of large ExM samples without the need for expensive custom-designed objectives. This approach addresses the challenge of imaging large samples with limited working distance, providing an alternative to existing methods that either compromise on resolution or require costly equipment.
inferred_keywords: Scanning Bessel Beam Light Sheet Microscopy

title: Expansion microscopy reveals thylakoid organisation alterations due to genetic mutations and far-red light acclimation
authors: Jarne Berentsen, Peter R. Bos, Emilie Wientjes
summary: Fig 1 shows the comparison of granum diameters in enveloped chloroplasts and isolated thylakoid membranes, indicating no significant difference. Fig 2 presents expanded thylakoid membranes from WT, FR-acclimated WT, and curt1a plants, highlighting structural differences. Fig 3 provides z-stacks of side views, illustrating the 3D architecture of thylakoids. Fig 4 offers 3D representations of thylakoids, showing connections between grana. Fig 5 compares granum diameters and interspaces, revealing larger diameters in FR-acclimated and curt1a thylakoids. Fig 6 analyzes granum height, stroma lamellae distance, and wrapping angles, showing variations across conditions.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution 3D imaging of thylakoid membranes, allowing for detailed analysis of structural changes due to genetic mutations and environmental acclimation. This approach provided insights into the architectural dynamics of thylakoids, contributing to a better understanding of photosynthetic efficiency and adaptation mechanisms.
novelty: This study demonstrates the application of expansion microscopy to plant thylakoid membranes, offering a high-throughput alternative to electron microscopy with improved resolution. The work highlights the ability to visualize structural changes in thylakoids due to far-red light acclimation and CURT1A mutations, which were previously challenging to observe. The use of ExM in this context provides a new tool for studying photosynthetic structures, complementing existing super-resolution techniques and expanding the potential for plant biology research.

title: Enhanced synaptic protein visualization by multicolor super-resolution expansion microscopy
authors: Janna Eilts, Sebastian Reinhard, Nikolas Michetschläger, Christian Werner, Markus Sauer
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates post-expansion immunolabeling of synaptic proteins in hippocampal neurons, showing improved labeling density and reduced linkage error. Fig 2: Illustrates four-color imaging of synaptic proteins, revealing spatial organization and alignment of pre- and post-synaptic proteins. The method achieves 20-30 nm resolution, enabling visualization of synaptic vesicles and their colocalization with fusion sites.
application_goal: The protocol enabled multicolor super-resolution imaging of synaptic proteins in neurons, achieving 20-30 nm resolution. This allows for detailed visualization of synaptic protein organization and interactions, providing insights into synaptic function and structure.
novelty: This study presents an optimized expansion microscopy approach that combines post-expansion immunolabeling with Airyscan and SIM, achieving multicolor imaging with 20-30 nm resolution. Compared to previous methods, this approach reduces linkage error and improves labeling density, allowing for detailed visualization of synaptic proteins. The use of an eightfold expansion factor balances resolution and signal-to-noise ratio, outperforming higher expansion factor methods that suffer from dilution effects.

title: Expansion microscopy in honeybee brains for high-resolution neuroanatomical analyses in social insects
authors: Nadine Kraft, Thomas S. Muenz, Sebastian Reinhard, Christian Werner, Markus Sauer, Claudia Groh, Wolfgang Rössler
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the structure and organization of mushroom bodies and microglomeruli in the honeybee brain, highlighting their role in sensory integration. Fig 2 compares pre- and post-expansion images of honeybee brain structures, demonstrating the linear increase in tissue size and resolution gain. Fig 3 presents a distortion analysis of Kenyon cell nuclei, confirming the isometric expansion of tissue. Fig 4 shows pre- and post-expansion comparison of projection neuron boutons, revealing increased spatial resolution of synapsin and BRP immunostaining. Fig 5 provides 3D reconstructions of projection neuron boutons, highlighting age-related differences in BRP cluster numbers. Fig 6 quantifies BRP clusters in nurse and forager bees, indicating synaptic plasticity. Fig 7 examines GABAergic innervation in mushroom body calyces, showing distinct arrangements with synapsin-positive boutons. Fig 8 combines neuronal tracings with antibody labeling, offering detailed insights into pre- and postsynaptic architecture of microglomeruli.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution visualization and quantification of synaptic structures in honeybee brains, allowing for detailed analysis of age- and experience-related synaptic plasticity in social insects. By overcoming the diffraction limit of conventional microscopy, the study provided new insights into the microarchitecture of synaptic circuits, particularly in the mushroom body calyces, which are crucial for sensory integration and memory formation.
novelty: This study is the first to apply expansion microscopy in a social insect species, specifically the honeybee, achieving expansion factors up to 4.5x. The work advances the field by combining ExM with immunohistochemical and neuronal tracing techniques, enabling visualization of synaptic structures at a subdiffraction scale. Compared to previous methods, this approach offers improved resolution and the ability to co-label presynaptic and postsynaptic elements, providing a more comprehensive understanding of synaptic plasticity. The use of Acryloyl-X SE (AcX) for anchoring represents a significant development, facilitating the retention of conventional antibodies and fluorescent proteins in the expanded matrix.

title: Expansion Microscopy-based imaging for visualization of mitochondria in Drosophila ovarian germline stem cells
authors: Chi-Hung Lin, Tzu-Yang Lin, Shao-Chun Hsu, Hwei-Jan Hsu
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the Drosophila germarium and ovary structure, highlighting the location of GSCs. Fig 2 details the gelation process for ExM, emphasizing the arrangement of germaria. Fig 3 shows the mounting of expanded gels for imaging. Fig 4 demonstrates improved visualization of mitochondria post-expansion, with increased resolution and signal-to-noise ratio. The study confirms that ExM enhances mitochondrial imaging in GSCs, facilitating detailed structural analysis.
application_goal: This protocol enables detailed visualization of mitochondrial morphology in Drosophila ovarian germline stem cells, overcoming the limitations of standard immunofluorescence and electron microscopy. By expanding the samples fourfold, researchers can achieve nanoscale optical imaging, which is crucial for studying mitochondrial dynamics and their role in stem cell behavior and tissue homeostasis.
novelty: This study presents a novel application of expansion microscopy to Drosophila ovarian germline stem cells, providing a simple and cost-effective method for nanoscale imaging of mitochondria. Compared to previous ExM protocols, this approach offers enhanced resolution and signal-to-noise ratio without the need for complex super-resolution techniques. The use of AcX as an anchoring agent and the specific adaptation of the protocol for germarial tissues represent significant advancements in the field, allowing for more detailed studies of mitochondrial structure and function in stem cell biology.

title: Adhesive interactions within microbial consortia can be differentiated at the single-cell level through expansion microscopy
authors: Pu-Ting Dong, Wenyuan Shi, Xuesong He, Gary G. Borisy
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the principle of heterotropic expansion microscopy, showing how weakly and strongly adhesive bacteria respond differently to expansion forces. Fig 2 demonstrates the separation of S. mutans cells in a monospecies biofilm, allowing for single-cell visualization. Fig 3 shows the application of expansion microscopy to a dual-species biofilm, enabling the visualization of individual S. mutans and S. sanguinis cells. Fig 4 presents quantitative analysis of spatial organization in dual-species biofilms, highlighting the clustering behavior of each species. Fig 5 explores the interactions within a three-species consortium, revealing differential adhesion between F. nucleatum and two Streptococcus species.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the differentiation of adhesive interactions within microbial consortia at the single-cell level, allowing for the visualization and analysis of individual bacterial members in dense biofilm communities.
novelty: This study introduces heterotropic expansion microscopy, a novel application of expansion microscopy that focuses on differentiating microbial adhesive interactions rather than achieving superresolution imaging. Unlike conventional expansion microscopy, which digests biological matter for isotropic expansion, this method maintains microbial integrity while expanding the extracellular space. This approach provides a new way to study microbial interactions at the single-cell level, offering insights into the spatial organization and adhesion dynamics within microbial communities, which were not possible with previous ExM variants or super-resolution methods.

title: Morphological assessment of GABA and glutamate inputs to GnRH neurons in intact female mice using expansion microscopy
authors: Shel-Hwa Yeo, Michel K. Herde, Allan E. Herbison
summary: Fig 1 shows synaptophysin boutons surrounding GnRH neuron dendrites, highlighting synaptic density. Fig 2 quantifies synaptophysin synapses along GnRH neuron dendrites, showing peak density in the first 45 µm. Fig 3 compares VGLUT2 and VGAT synapses, revealing a predominance of glutamatergic inputs. Fig 4 uses Homer1 and gephyrin markers to confirm synaptic types, emphasizing spatial distribution. Fig 5 and 6 detail the distribution of VGLUT2-Homer1 and VGAT-gephyrin synapses, respectively, with no significant differences between dioestrous and pro-oestrous mice.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the detailed mapping of synaptic inputs to GnRH neurons, revealing a concentrated 'hot-spot' of excitatory inputs along the proximal dendrite, which is crucial for understanding the synaptic architecture related to the GnRH surge.
novelty: This study employs expansion microscopy to achieve super-resolution imaging of synapses on GnRH neurons, providing a more accurate assessment of synaptic density and distribution compared to traditional confocal microscopy. The findings highlight a distinct clustering of excitatory inputs on the proximal dendrite, offering insights into the synaptic mechanisms underlying the GnRH surge, which were not previously detectable with conventional methods.

title: Isotropic multi-scale neuronal reconstruction from high-ratio expansion microscopy with contrastive unsupervised deep generative models
authors: Gary Han Chang, Meng-Yun Wu, Ling-Hui Yen, Da-Yu Huang, Ya-Hui Lin, Yi-Ru Luo, Ya-Ding Liu, Bin Xu, Kam W. Leong, Wen-Sung Lai, Ann-Shyn Chiang, Kuo-Chuan Wang, Chin-Hsien Lin, Shih-Luen Wang, Li-An Chu
summary: Fig 1: Introduces the IsoGAN model, a GAN-based approach for isotropic neuronal reconstruction, addressing anisotropic resolution issues. Fig 2: Demonstrates IsoGAN's ability to enhance axial resolution and improve neuron morphology consistency. Fig 3: Shows IsoGAN's generalization across various datasets, including VMAT proteins and human brain tissues. Fig 4: Compares IsoGAN with other models, highlighting its superior image enhancement capabilities. Fig 5: Illustrates IsoGAN's effectiveness in reconstructing neurons from noisy backgrounds. Fig 6: Validates IsoGAN's ability to enhance VMAT protein imaging and reconstruct mouse brain vessels with improved spatial consistency.
application_goal: The IsoGAN model enables the reconstruction of isotropic images of neuronal structures from high-ratio expansion microscopy data, overcoming challenges of anisotropic resolution and manual annotation. This approach facilitates high-fidelity 3D representations of neurons, proteins, and blood vessels, streamlining imaging reconstruction processes and enhancing the accuracy of morphological analyses.
novelty: This study introduces IsoGAN, a novel unsupervised deep learning model that significantly improves isotropic image reconstruction from high-ratio expansion microscopy data. Unlike previous methods requiring extensive manual annotation, IsoGAN leverages multi-scale deconvolution components and contrastive learning to enhance axial resolution and image quality. The model's adaptability to diverse biological samples, including complex mammalian neurons, and its ability to maintain high fidelity in 3D reconstructions, positions it as a transformative tool in the field of expansion microscopy, offering a substantial advancement over traditional supervised learning approaches.

title: Expansion Microscopy Provides Nanoscale Insight into Nucleolar Reorganization and Nuclear Foci Formation during Nucleolar Stress
authors: Katelyn R. Alley, Katelyn M. Wyatt, Adam C. Fries, Victoria J. DeRose
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the morphological changes in nucleoli under stress, highlighting the transition from amorphous to rounded shapes. Fig 2 demonstrates the preservation of nucleolar structure during 4x expansion, showing increased resolution of nucleolar features. Fig 3 presents the nanoscale reorganization of nucleolar proteins during stress, revealing distinct stages of nucleolar shutdown. Fig 4 quantifies the increase in RNA Pol I cluster size during stress, indicating early nucleolar reorganization. Fig 5 shows the translocation of fibrillarin and NPM1 during stress, with the formation of nucleoplasmic foci. Fig 6 quantifies the increase in nucleoplasmic fibrillarin foci over time, correlating with prolonged stress. Fig 7 proposes a model for nucleolar reorganization during stress, highlighting the stages of nucleolar shutdown.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of nucleolar reorganization at nanoscale resolution, providing insights into the structural dynamics of nucleolar stress responses. By combining expansion microscopy with SoRa spinning disk microscopy, the study achieved unprecedented resolution of nucleolar components, allowing for the detailed observation of protein and RNA distribution during stress. This approach offers a powerful tool for studying the structural and functional changes in membraneless organelles under various conditions.
novelty: This work advances the field of expansion microscopy by achieving the highest reported resolution for nucleolar imaging, approximately 45 nm, using a combination of pro-ExM and SoRa spinning disk microscopy. The study provides new insights into nucleolar reorganization during stress, revealing stages of nucleolar shutdown and the formation of nucleoplasmic foci. Compared to previous ExM variants, this approach offers improved resolution and the ability to visualize dynamic changes in nucleolar structure and function. The study also introduces a novel application of click-ExM to monitor nascent RNA production during nucleolar stress, highlighting the potential of ExM for studying complex cellular processes.

title: Expansion Microscopy of trichomonads
authors: Paula Terra Bandeira, Sharmila Fiama das Neves Ortiz, Marlene Benchimol, Wanderley de Souza
summary: Fig 1 shows Tritrichomonas foetus before and after expansion, highlighting the increased size and visibility of internal structures. Fig 2 demonstrates the use of fluorescence microscopy to visualize Trichomonas vaginalis and Tritrichomonas foetus, showing detailed cytoskeletal structures like the axostyle and costa. Fig 3 presents the immunofluorescence microscopy results, revealing the distribution of costain 1 in the costa and the individual microtubules in the axostyle. These figures collectively illustrate the enhanced resolution and structural insights provided by expansion microscopy in these protozoa.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of the cytoskeletal structures of Trichomonas vaginalis and Tritrichomonas foetus with unprecedented detail, allowing for the precise localization of proteins such as tubulin and costain 1. This improved understanding of the protozoa's internal architecture could aid in the study of their biology and pathogenic mechanisms.
novelty: This study applies expansion microscopy to trichomonads, providing a significant resolution improvement over conventional immunofluorescence techniques. The use of a 4.5x expansion factor and specific chemical protocols allowed for the detailed visualization of cytoskeletal proteins, such as tubulin and costain 1, in these protozoa. Compared to previous ExM applications, this work highlights the potential of ExM in studying neglected parasitic diseases, offering new insights into the structural organization of these pathogens.

title: Expansion microscopy of neutrophil nuclear structure and extracellular traps
authors: Jason Scott Holsapple, Lena Schnitzler, Louisa Rusch, Tobias Horst Baldeweg, Elsa Neubert, Sebastian Kruss, Luise Erpenbeck
summary: Fig 1: Developed a method for expansion microscopy of neutrophils, showing isotropic expansion. Fig 2: Demonstrated isotropy and expansion factor of 4.9x for neutrophil nuclei and NETs. Fig 3: Showed increased resolution and spatial information of chromatin and nuclear proteins using expansion microscopy. Fig 4: Quantified colocalization and signal intensity changes post-expansion. Fig 5: Identified histone-rich domains in NETotic cells, revealing granularity not visible in non-expanded images. Fig 6: Validated expansion microscopy for various neutrophil structures, including MPO and nuclear lamins. Fig 7: Revealed punctate NPM1 distribution in the nucleus, suggesting phase separation.
application_goal: The protocol enabled super-resolved imaging of neutrophil nuclear structures and NETs, providing insights into chromatin and protein distribution that are not possible with conventional microscopy. This method allows for detailed visualization of fragile and complex cellular structures, enhancing our understanding of neutrophil biology and NETosis.
novelty: This study presents a novel application of expansion microscopy to human neutrophils, achieving a resolution of <40–50 nm, which surpasses conventional super-resolution methods like STED and STORM in terms of accessibility and cost-effectiveness. The work introduces a robust protocol for visualizing nuclear and cytoplasmic structures in neutrophils, revealing new insights into chromatin organization and protein distribution during NETosis. The use of expansion microscopy provides a significant resolution gain without the need for complex optical setups, making it a valuable tool for studying dynamic immune cell structures.

title: Dual-color expansion microscopy of membrane proteins using bioorthogonal labeling
authors: Steven Edwards, Birthe Meineke, Sebastian Bauer, Hans Blom, Simon Elsässer, Hjalmar Brismar
summary: Figure 1 demonstrates the incorporation of ncAAs into NKA subunits and their selective labeling using click chemistry, highlighting successful membrane localization. Figure 2 shows STED microscopy of NKA β1, revealing its non-homogeneous distribution in the plasma membrane. Figure 3 illustrates the ExM process, achieving super-resolution imaging of NKA β1 in expanded cells, with improved resolution of protein distribution. Figure 4 presents dual-color labeling of NKA α1 and β1 subunits in expanded cells, showcasing the potential for multiplexed imaging.
application_goal: The protocol enabled dual-color super-resolution imaging of membrane proteins, specifically the Na,K-ATPase α1 and β1 subunits, in expanded HEK 293T cells. This approach provided nanoscale insights into the distribution of these proteins using conventional confocal microscopy, overcoming the limitations of traditional labeling methods and achieving high localization precision.
novelty: This study introduces a novel combination of genetic code expansion (GCE) for site-specific labeling with expansion microscopy (ExM) to achieve dual-color super-resolution imaging. Compared to previous ExM variants, this method minimizes linkage error associated with antibody-based labeling, achieving sub-nanometer precision. The use of bioorthogonal click chemistry for labeling, combined with ExM, allows for Ångström-level resolution, surpassing traditional super-resolution techniques like STED and SMLM. The study also highlights the compatibility of specific fluorophores with the ExM process, addressing challenges in fluorophore stability during gel polymerization.

title: Expansion Microscopy for Imaging the Cell–Material Interface
authors: Melissa L. Nakamoto, Csaba Forró, Wei Zhang, Ching-Ting Tsai, Bianxiao Cui
resolution: tens of nanometers to several micrometers
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the protocol for imprinting substrate topography into hydrogels, preserving the nano-bio interface. Fig 2 quantifies the uniformity of expansion over large areas, showing consistent expansion factors across different regions. Fig 3 shows high-resolution imaging of cell membrane interactions with topographic features, revealing non-conformal adhesion to concave surfaces. Fig 4 visualizes the spatial segregation of AP2 and F-actin at the nano-bio interface, with AP2 localizing to the top of nanopillars and F-actin to the bottom. Fig 5 applies ExM to image osteoblast interactions with titanium implants, highlighting non-conformal membrane adhesion to rough surfaces.
application_goal: The protocol enables high-resolution imaging of the cell–material interface, particularly for substrates with complex topographies like titanium implants. This allows for detailed visualization of how cells interact with nanoscale features, which is crucial for understanding processes like osseointegration.
novelty: This study presents a novel application of expansion microscopy to image the cell–material interface, overcoming limitations of traditional super-resolution methods that are incompatible with non-expandable materials. By imprinting substrate topography into hydrogels, the method preserves the nano-bio interface and allows for high-resolution imaging of cellular interactions with complex surfaces. This approach provides new insights into the spatial distribution of proteins at the interface, offering a more accessible alternative to electron microscopy and expanding the applicability of ExM to a wider range of materials and biological questions.

title: Expansion Microscopy of the Enteric Nervous System: A Feasibility Study
authors: Xin Xu, Wenchuan Zhang, Menachem Hanani
sample: mouse colonic ENS tissue, external muscle layers with the myenteric plexus
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the expansion of neuronal somata and fibers in the mouse colonic myenteric plexus, highlighting the increased visibility of neuronal structures post-expansion. Fig 2 shows fluorescence imaging of enteric glia, with enhanced visualization of glial cell bodies and processes after expansion. The study confirms the utility of ExM in improving structural clarity in fluorescence imaging, making it a powerful tool for further investigations into the architecture of the ENS.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution structural analysis of the enteric nervous system (ENS) in mouse colonic tissues, allowing for the visualization of neuronal and glial structures that were previously unresolvable with conventional microscopy. This approach provides a framework for applying ExM to other peripheral tissues, facilitating detailed studies of peripheral neural networks.
novelty: This study represents a novel application of expansion microscopy (ExM) to the enteric nervous system (ENS), specifically in mouse colonic tissues. Unlike previous ExM applications focused on brain tissues, this protocol addresses the challenges posed by the dense extracellular matrix of peripheral tissues. By relying solely on Proteinase K digestion, the study avoids the need for collagenase, simplifying the protocol and reducing the risk of structural distortion. This work extends the utility of ExM to peripheral nervous systems, offering a new avenue for high-resolution studies of the ENS and other smooth muscle-containing tissues.

title: Detection of Chlamydia Developmental Forms and Secreted Effectors by Expansion Microscopy
authors: Tobias C. Kunz, Ralph Götz, Markus Sauer, Thomas Rudel
summary: Fig 1 shows the use of ExM to visualize CPAF secretion in Chlamydia-infected cells, highlighting its accumulation in the inclusion. Fig 2 demonstrates the differentiation of Chlamydia's elementary and reticulate bodies by size using ExM. Fig 3 illustrates the localization of Cdu1 in the inclusion membrane, providing insights into its role in infection. The study emphasizes ExM's capability to resolve nanoscale details in pathogen-infected cells, offering a simpler alternative to super-resolution microscopy.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of nanoscale details of Chlamydia infection processes, such as distinguishing between elementary and reticulate bodies, and localizing effector proteins like CPAF and Cdu1 within infected cells. This approach allows researchers to study intracellular pathogens with high resolution using conventional confocal microscopy.
novelty: This study demonstrates the application of expansion microscopy (ExM) to visualize intracellular pathogens, specifically Chlamydia trachomatis, which had not been previously expanded. The work highlights ExM's ability to differentiate between Chlamydia's developmental forms and localize effector proteins, offering a simpler alternative to super-resolution techniques like STED or PALM. The use of ExM in this context provides a new tool for studying pathogen-host interactions at a resolution close to that of more complex super-resolution methods, without requiring specialized equipment.

title: Zooming in on the Glycome: Visualizing Glycans at the Nanoscale Level through Expansion Microscopy
authors: Joshua M. Kofsky, Chantelle J. Capicciotti
summary: Figure 1 illustrates the ExM process, highlighting its ability to resolve glycans at the nanoscale. Figure 2 demonstrates the metabolic incorporation of azide-containing GalNAz probes into O-glycan structures, enabling precise imaging. The study uses ExM linkers to visualize glycans in breast cancer cells, revealing nanoscale structures like migrasomes and microvilli. In C. elegans, the method maps O-glycosylation patterns with high resolution, overcoming previous limitations in imaging internal features. This work significantly advances glycan imaging, offering a robust alternative to electron microscopy.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization and mapping of glycans at the nanoscale within cells, tissues, and whole organisms, providing insights into glycan-mediated processes and their roles in health and disease. By using metabolic oligosaccharide engineering and expansion microscopy, the study offers a powerful tool for imaging glycans with high resolution, which is crucial for understanding their biological functions.
novelty: This work introduces a novel application of expansion microscopy by integrating metabolic oligosaccharide engineering to visualize glycans, a biomolecule previously challenging to image at high resolution. The use of trifunctional ExM linkers for direct anchoring of glycan probes to the expansion matrix is a significant advancement, allowing for detailed imaging comparable to electron microscopy. This approach expands the capabilities of ExM beyond proteins and nucleic acids, offering a new avenue for studying glycans in complex biological systems, which was not possible with prior ExM variants or super-resolution methods.

title: High-Resolution Imaging of Tumor Spheroids and Organoids Enabled by Expansion Microscopy
authors: Steven J. Edwards, Valentina Carannante, Kyra Kuhnigk, Henrik Ring, Tatsiana Tararuk, Finn Hallböök, Hans Blom, Björn Önfelt, Hjalmar Brismar
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the workflow for expansion microscopy on tumor spheroids, highlighting improved antibody penetration. Fig 2 compares endogenous and immunostained tdTomato in spheroids, showing enhanced labeling post-expansion. Fig 3 validates the protocol with various antibodies, confirming epitope preservation. Fig 4 shows improved signal-to-background ratio and segmentation accuracy in expanded samples. Fig 5 applies the protocol to diverse 3-D cultures, including MDCK II cysts and retinal organoids, demonstrating its versatility.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution imaging of 3-D cell cultures, such as tumor spheroids and organoids, without the need for physical sectioning. This approach improved antibody penetration and labeling quality, allowing for detailed visualization of cellular structures and interactions within the samples.
novelty: This study demonstrates the application of expansion microscopy to 3-D cultures, providing a significant improvement in imaging resolution and antibody penetration compared to traditional clearing methods. The use of expansion microscopy allows for isotropic expansion and high signal-to-background ratio, facilitating better segmentation and analysis of complex structures. This work advances the field by enabling detailed study of tumor spheroids and organoids, which are challenging to image due to their dense and light-scattering nature.
source_file: High-Resolution Imaging of Tumor Spheroids and Organoids Enabled by Expansion Microscopy.pdf
