title: An In-depth Guide to the Ultrastructural Expansion Microscopy (U-ExM) of Chlamydomonas reinhardtii
authors: Nikolai Klena, Giovanni Maltinti, Umut Batman, Gaia Pigino, Paul Guichard, Virginie Hamel
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates that the cell wall of Chlamydomonas does not affect the four-fold expansion factor in U-ExM. Fig 2 provides tools and visual aids for Chlamydomonas U-ExM, highlighting the gelation chamber setup. Fig 3 compares U-ExM without fixation and cryo-ExM, showing the preservation of cellular structures. Fig 4 details the setup and methodology of 12 mm coverslip cryo-fixation. Fig 5 illustrates BODIPYTM lipid staining using a membrane-optimized cryo-ExM protocol, revealing membrane structures. Fig 6 presents examples of Chlamydomonas imaging in U-ExM, showing localization of IFT trains and chloroplasts.
application_goal: The protocol enables the visualization of the 3D organization of Chlamydomonas reinhardtii cellular ultrastructure, allowing for detailed imaging of cellular components such as flagella, basal bodies, and chloroplasts using expansion microscopy.
novelty: This study applies ultrastructure expansion microscopy (U-ExM) to Chlamydomonas reinhardtii, demonstrating a four-fold expansion factor without fixation artifacts. The use of cryo-fixation and NHS-ester staining enhances the preservation and visualization of cellular structures, offering a simpler alternative to complex super-resolution techniques like STORM or STED. The protocol's adaptability to other organisms and its ability to maintain isotropy and resolution at 70 nm provide significant advancements over previous ExM variants.

title: Plasmon-Enhanced Expansion Microscopy
authors: Priya Rathi, Prashant Gupta, Avishek Debnath, Harsh Baldi, Yixuan Wang, Rohit Gupta, Baranidharan Raman, Srikanth Singamaneni
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the design of plasmonic-fluor (PF) nanolabels, showing their structure and fluorescence enhancement. Fig 2 demonstrates the stability and fluorescence retention of PFs post-expansion, highlighting their compatibility with ExM. Fig 3 shows improved spatial resolution and fidelity of p-ExM in imaging hippocampal neurons, emphasizing the enhanced resolution of neurite structures. Fig 4 quantifies neuronal morphological features using p-ExM, revealing increased neurite terminal points and area. Fig 5 addresses diffusion limitations of PFs, proposing a cyclic draining and replenishment method to improve labeling efficiency.
application_goal: The protocol enabled improved visualization and quantification of neuronal structures, overcoming fluorescence signal dilution challenges in expansion microscopy. By using ultrabright plasmonic-fluors, the study achieved enhanced resolution and accurate morphological analysis of neural networks, facilitating better understanding of neuronal connectivity and structure.
novelty: This work introduces plasmon-enhanced expansion microscopy (p-ExM) using ultrabright plasmonic-fluors, which retain high fluorescence post-expansion, unlike conventional fluorophores that suffer from signal dilution. The study demonstrates significant improvements in spatial resolution and morphological quantification of neurons, offering a robust alternative to traditional ExM and super-resolution methods. The use of plasmonic-fluors as digital nanolabels represents a novel approach to overcoming limitations of fluorescence signal loss, enabling more detailed and accurate imaging of biological samples.

title: Quantitative Analysis of Mitochondrial Shape and Ultrastructure Based on Expansion Microscopy
authors: Alexander Sauer
summary: Fig 1: Introduces the machine learning pipeline for segmenting mitochondria in ExM images, highlighting its scalability. Fig 2: Demonstrates the use of pan-staining combined with immunolabeling to reduce human annotation in training segmentation models. Fig 3: Presents a novel algorithm leveraging inter-annotator disagreement to enhance semi-supervised model performance. Fig 4: Applies the segmentation pipeline to analyze mitochondrial shape and ultrastructure in HeLa cells and mouse kidney tissue, revealing drug-induced morphological changes.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the development of a machine learning pipeline that automatically segments mitochondria and their ultrastructure in pan-stained ExM images, facilitating scalable quantitative analysis. This approach allows for the integration of additional dyes and immunolabeling, reducing the need for extensive human annotation and enabling the study of mitochondrial morphology under various conditions.
novelty: This work introduces a machine learning pipeline for ExM images that automates the segmentation of mitochondria, a significant advancement over manual annotation methods. Unlike previous ExM variants, this approach combines pan-staining with immunolabeling to enhance segmentation accuracy and reduce annotation workload. The novel algorithm for handling inter-annotator disagreement further improves model performance, setting this study apart from traditional ExM and super-resolution methods by offering a scalable solution for analyzing large datasets.

title: Multiplexed spatial transcriptomics methods and the application of expansion microscopy
authors: Andra Fortner, Octavian Bucur

model_system: human breast cancer metastasis in liver

summary: Fig 1 illustrates the classification of spatial transcriptomics methods into ISS, ISH, and NGS-based techniques, highlighting their distinct approaches. Fig 2 details the FISSEQ method, emphasizing its ability to sequence RNA in situ, which is crucial for understanding cellular RNA distribution. Fig 3 demonstrates the ExSEQ process, showing how expansion microscopy enhances RNA accessibility and spatial mapping. Fig 4 explains the MERFISH method, focusing on its error-robust barcoding for precise RNA identification. Fig 5 describes the VISIUM platform, showcasing its use of microarrays for spatial RNA capture, which is vital for tissue-wide gene expression analysis. Fig 6 compares Slide-seq, Stereo-seq, and Seq-Scope, highlighting their unique approaches to spatial transcriptomics with region capture.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the integration of expansion microscopy with spatial transcriptomics methods, enhancing the resolution and RNA detection capabilities. This combination allows for more precise spatial mapping of RNA within tissues, providing deeper insights into cellular organization and gene expression patterns. The improved resolution and detection facilitate the study of complex biological processes and disease mechanisms at a subcellular level.
novelty: This work advances the field by integrating expansion microscopy with spatial transcriptomics, offering enhanced resolution and RNA detection compared to traditional methods. Unlike previous ExM variants, this approach allows for subcellular resolution in spatial transcriptomics, overcoming limitations of optical crowding and enabling more genes to be interrogated simultaneously. The novel application of ExM to methods like MERFISH and VISIUM significantly improves their spatial resolution, making it possible to study complex tissues with greater detail and accuracy. This integration represents a significant step forward in the ability to map gene expression in situ, providing a powerful tool for biological and medical research.

title: Single extracellular vesicle imaging via rolling circle amplification–expansion microscopy
authors: Jiacheng Wu, Quanhao Dou, Miao Mao, Xin Wan, Minhao Wu, Tony Y. Hu, Yuanqing Zhang
summary: Fig 1: The RCA–ExM method was developed to profile single EVs, enabling super-resolution imaging with conventional microscopy. Fig 2: A dual-labeling approach was used to capture and label tumor-derived EVs, enhancing detection sensitivity. Fig 3: Liposome fusion was employed to deliver an enzyme circuit for miRNA detection, amplifying the signal for specific miRNA targets. Fig 4: RCA-Lipo-EVs were embedded in a hydrogel matrix and expanded for super-resolution imaging, allowing detailed phenotypic profiling. Fig 5: The RCA-ExM method was applied to clinical samples, distinguishing cancer patients from healthy donors and predicting immunotherapy responses.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the sensitive and specific detection of single extracellular vesicles (EVs) by integrating rolling circle amplification with expansion microscopy (RCA–ExM). This approach allowed for the super-resolution imaging of EVs using conventional fluorescence microscopy, facilitating the profiling of EV biomolecules such as proteins and miRNAs. The method demonstrated potential for cancer diagnostics and monitoring immunotherapy efficacy by analyzing EVs directly from clinical samples.
novelty: This study introduces a novel integration of rolling circle amplification with expansion microscopy (RCA–ExM) to achieve super-resolution imaging of single extracellular vesicles (EVs) using conventional fluorescence microscopy. Unlike previous methods that require sophisticated equipment, this approach allows for the sensitive detection of EV biomolecules, including proteins and miRNAs, directly from clinical samples. The RCA–ExM method provides a streamlined workflow for capturing and labeling EVs, offering significant advantages in terms of sensitivity and specificity over traditional bulk analysis methods. This work represents a significant advancement in EV research, particularly for cancer diagnostics and treatment monitoring.

title: ExCIDS: a combined approach coupling Expansion Microscopy (ExM) and Circular Intensity Differential Scattering (CIDS) for chromatin-DNA imaging
authors: RICCARDO MARONGIU, AYMERIC LE GRATIET, LUCA PESCE, PAOLO BIANCHINI, ALBERTO DIASPRO
summary: Fig 1 shows the improved resolution of chromatin-DNA in Hek cells using ExCIDS, highlighting the nuclear membrane and chromatin compaction. Fig 2 explains the scattering process and SNR decrease with expansion, emphasizing the need for digestion to improve contrast. Fig 3 presents histograms showing improved correlation between CIDS and fluorescence signals post-expansion. Fig 4 demonstrates the effect of digestion time on imaging contrast, with overnight digestion yielding the best results. Fig 5 compares pixel distributions, showing enhanced correlation after digestion.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the imaging of chromatin-DNA organization in situ within entire cells, enhancing optical resolution and contrast by combining ExM with CIDS. This approach allows for label-free imaging of DNA without isolating nuclei, preserving native chromatin structure and providing insights into cellular phases and genetic disorders.
novelty: This study introduces ExCIDS, a novel combination of ExM and CIDS, to achieve high-resolution, label-free imaging of chromatin-DNA. Unlike previous ExM variants, ExCIDS leverages the chiral sensitivity of CIDS to enhance contrast and resolution, particularly in the nuclear region. The method improves upon traditional super-resolution techniques by maintaining native chromatin organization without extensive fluorescent labeling, offering a new avenue for studying DNA structure in cellular contexts.

title: Expansion STED microscopy (ExSTED)
authors: Mengfei Gao, Ria Thielhorn, Jakob Rentsch, Alf Honigmann, Helge Ewers

title: Protein and lipid expansion microscopy with trypsin and tyramide signal amplification for 3D imaging
authors: Ueh-Ting Tim Wang, Xuejiao Tian, Yae-Huei Liou, Sue-Ping Lee, Hsiao-Tang Hu, Chieh-Han Lu, Po-Ting Lin, Ya-Jen Cheng, Peilin Chen, Bi-Chang Chen
summary: Fig 1: TT-ExM protocol is introduced, highlighting trypsin digestion and tyramide signal amplification to enhance fluorescence signals. Fig 2: Demonstrates the application of TT-ExM in COS-7 cells, showing enhanced protein retention and clear imaging of endoplasmic reticulum and mitochondria. Fig 3: Compares trypsin and proteinase K treatments, showing superior fluorescence retention with trypsin. Fig 4: Quantitative analysis of expansion isotropy and resolution improvement post-expansion. Fig 5: Biotin-DHPE staining reveals complex lipid structures in COS-7 cells, highlighting nuclear and chromosomal matrices. Fig 6: TT-ExM applied to cultured neurons, visualizing mitochondrial networks and nuclear structures. Fig 7: Detailed nuclear organization in neurons revealed by TT-ExM, showing lipid-rich structures adjacent to DNA.
application_goal: The TT-ExM protocol enables enhanced fluorescence signal retention and visualization of protein and lipid structures in 3D, using readily available reagents. This approach allows for high-quality imaging of cellular components, such as endoplasmic reticulum, mitochondria, and lipid-rich structures, under conventional confocal microscopy.
novelty: TT-ExM introduces a novel combination of trypsin digestion and tyramide signal amplification to address the fluorescence signal dilution issue in expansion microscopy. Compared to previous ExM variants, TT-ExM offers improved fluorophore retention and signal amplification, enabling detailed visualization of cellular structures without the need for specialized reagents. This method provides a significant resolution gain, achieving approximately 63 nm resolution, and is applicable to both protein and lipid imaging, expanding the utility of ExM in biological research.

title: Expansion Microscopy of Synaptic Contacts on the Mauthner Cells of Larval Zebrafish
authors: Sundas Ijaz, Sandra P. Cárdenas-García, Alberto E. Pereda
summary: Fig 1: Describes the dissection and immunostaining of larval zebrafish brains to expose synaptic proteins. Fig 2: Details the gel polymerization process to embed samples in a hydrogel for expansion. Fig 3: Shows the orientation and cutting of the gel-embedded samples for expansion. Fig 4: Illustrates the mounting of expanded samples for imaging. Fig 5: Demonstrates the removal of samples from the well plate for imaging. The figures collectively highlight the method's ability to map synaptic protein distribution with high resolution.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization and mapping of synaptic protein distribution at the nanoscale level in the Mauthner cells of larval zebrafish, providing insights into the organization of synaptic contacts.
novelty: This study applies protein-retention expansion microscopy (proExM) to the Mauthner cells of larval zebrafish, offering a less labor-intensive alternative to electron microscopy. The method allows for the mapping of synaptic proteins with sufficient resolution to discern spatial features previously only visible with electron microscopy. The use of proExM in this context is novel, as it facilitates the study of synaptic organization in a genetically tractable model organism, providing a new avenue for exploring synaptic structure and function.

title: In Situ Super-Resolution Imaging of Organoids and Extracellular Matrix Interactions via Phototransfer by Allyl Sulfide Exchange-Expansion Microscopy (PhASE-ExM)
authors: Michael R. Blatchley, Kemal Arda Günay, F. Max Yavitt, Elijah M. Hawat, Peter J. Dempsey, Kristi S. Anseth
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the PhASE-ExM technique, combining allyl sulfide crosslinking with photoexpansion microscopy for organoid imaging. Fig 2 demonstrates the method's ability to achieve optical clearance and super-resolution imaging of organoids in Matrigel, highlighting improved imaging depth and resolution. Fig 3 explores cell-ECM interactions in organoids, showing spatial heterogeneity in collagen IV and integrin β1 interactions. Fig 4 extends the method to PEG-AlS hydrogels, revealing cell-secreted ECM protein localization and dynamics during organoid differentiation.
application_goal: The protocol enabled deep, super-resolution imaging of organoids and their extracellular matrix (ECM) in 3D, overcoming limitations of light scattering and absorption in traditional imaging methods. It allowed for the visualization of cell-ECM interactions and protein localization with sub-micrometer resolution, providing insights into organoid growth and differentiation processes.
novelty: PhASE-ExM represents a significant advancement over traditional expansion microscopy by integrating allyl sulfide crosslinking with photoexpansion techniques, enabling rapid and efficient imaging of organoids in 3D. Unlike previous methods, it achieves optical clearance and sub-micrometer resolution without additional degradation steps, facilitating high-throughput imaging. The use of synthetic PEG-based hydrogels further allows for tailored microenvironments, enhancing the study of cell-ECM interactions and ECM dynamics in organoid models.
source_file: Advanced Materials - 2022 - Blatchley - In Situ Super‐Resolution Imaging of Organoids and Extracellular Matrix Interactions.pdf

title: Combined expansion microscopy with structured illumination microscopy for analyzing protein complexes
authors: Yongfu Wang, Zulin Yu, Cori K. Cahoon, Tari Parmely, Nancy Thomas, Jay R. Unruh, Brian D. Slaughter, R. Scott Hawley
sample: thick tissues such as brain and organs
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the ExM-SIM protocol for analyzing protein complexes in Drosophila ovaries. Fig 2 shows the importance of adjusting immersion oil RI for optimal SIM imaging. Fig 3 illustrates the process of straightening and averaging profiles from expansion data to enhance resolution. The protocol enables detailed 3D mapping of protein localization, crucial for understanding the structure of the synaptonemal complex.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the analysis of the three-dimensional organization of multiprotein complexes at a resolution of ~30 nm, allowing for detailed mapping of protein localization in situ, which is critical for understanding complex biological structures.
novelty: This work combines expansion microscopy with structured illumination microscopy (ExM-SIM) to achieve a lateral resolution of ~30 nm, comparable to other super-resolution techniques like iExM and serial-sectioning STORM. The method maintains the ability to image up to four colors and is particularly useful when protein density limits further expansion. The use of cryosectioning and post-expansion labeling enhances the applicability of ExM to thicker samples, providing a significant advantage over traditional super-resolution methods.
source_file: Combined expansion microscopy with structured illumination microscopy for analyzing protein complexes.pdf

title: A detailed protocol for expansion microscopy of Paracentrotus lividus embryos and larvae: Incorporating decalcification for improved imaging
authors: Thomas M. D. Sheard, Davide Sartori, Matteo Colombo, Izzy Jayasinghe, Andrea Gaion
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the application of ExM to P. lividus larvae, showing improved resolution of subcellular structures post-expansion. Fig 2 illustrates the differential labelling of embryonic stages using NHS esters, highlighting distinct structural compartments. The decalcification step in Fig 3 addresses skeletal distortions, enabling isotropic expansion and detailed imaging of larval stomach cilia. These figures collectively validate the protocol's effectiveness across developmental stages.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed subcellular imaging of Paracentrotus lividus embryos and larvae, overcoming challenges posed by autofluorescence and calcified structures. It provides a reproducible workflow for developmental and environmental research, particularly in marine invertebrates.
novelty: This study introduces a decalcification step using EDTA in the ExM protocol, crucial for preserving morphology in calcified larvae and ensuring isotropic expansion. Compared to previous ExM applications, this adaptation allows for reliable imaging of marine invertebrates with complex structures, expanding the technique's applicability beyond traditional model organisms.
source_file: Journal of Microscopy - 2025 - Sheard - A detailed protocol for expansion microscopy of Paracentrotus lividus embryos and.pdf

title: Ultrastructural expansion microscopy (U-ExM) visualization of malaria parasite dense granules using RESA as a representative marker protein
authors: Junpei Fukumoto, Takafumi Tsuboi, Eizo Takashima
summary: Fig 1: U-ExM was used to identify rhoptry and microneme organelles in malaria parasites, demonstrating the method's capability to visualize subcellular structures. Fig 2: Anti-RESA antibodies were used to describe the localization of dense granules throughout the asexual life cycle of parasites, highlighting the potential of U-ExM to identify novel DG proteins. The study confirms RESA localization in merozoites and its translocation to the infected erythrocyte membrane, aligning with previous IEM findings.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of dense granules in Plasmodium falciparum merozoites using U-ExM, facilitating the identification of novel DG proteins without the need for time-consuming immunoelectron microscopy. This advancement enhances the understanding of erythrocyte parasitism by P. falciparum and could aid in the development of intervention strategies.
novelty: This study demonstrates the application of U-ExM to visualize dense granules in malaria parasites, a task previously reliant on immunoelectron microscopy. By expanding merozoites to four times their original size, U-ExM allows for higher localization resolutions than conventional microscopy. This approach overcomes the limitations of IEM, such as the need for quality antibodies and harsh sample preparation, providing a more efficient method for studying small organelles in Plasmodium falciparum. The use of U-ExM in this context is novel and offers a significant improvement over traditional methods.

title: Spatially resolved proteomics via tissue expansion
authors: Lu Li, Cuiji Sun, Yaoting Sun, Zhen Dong, Runxin Wu, Xiaoting Sun, Hanbin Zhang, Wenhao Jiang, Yan Zhou, Xufeng Cen, Shang Cai, Hongguang Xia, Yi Zhu, Tiannan Guo, Kiryl D. Piatkevich
summary: Fig 1: Developed ProteomEx workflow for spatially resolved proteomics using tissue expansion and mass spectrometry. Fig 2: Benchmarked ProteomEx against traditional methods, showing higher peptide yield and lower missed cleavages. Fig 3: Validated ProteomEx in different tissues, demonstrating isotropic expansion and high protein identification. Fig 4: Applied ProteomEx to AD mouse brains, identifying differentially expressed proteins in specific brain subregions.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the spatially resolved proteomic profiling of sub-nanoliter volumes of tissue at hundreds of micron lateral resolution, allowing for the identification of proteins associated with Alzheimer's disease in specific brain subregions.
novelty: ProteomEx offers a higher expansion factor and spatial resolution compared to previous methods like proExM-MS, achieving ~160 µm lateral resolution. It uses N-succinimidyl acrylate for protein anchoring, which is more stable and affordable than Acryloyl-X. The method is applicable to various mammalian tissues and compatible with immunohistochemistry, providing a practical alternative to sophisticated equipment like LCM for spatially resolved proteomics.

title: The components of an electrical synapse as revealed by expansion microscopy of a single synaptic contact
authors: Sandra P Cárdenas-García, Sundas Ijaz, Alberto E Pereda
summary: Fig 1: Expansion microscopy revealed multiple gap junctions at club endings in zebrafish, highlighting their spatial distribution. Fig 2: Immunolabeling showed that electrical and chemical synaptic areas are mutually exclusive, with glutamate receptors confined to the periphery. Fig 3: Labeling for gap junction proteins indicated multiple puncta at synaptic contact areas, suggesting individual gap junction plaques. Fig 4: Expansion microscopy detailed the molecular components of gap junction plaques, confirming the postsynaptic localization of ZO1. Fig 5: Expansion revealed variability in the size and number of gap junctions, indicating a complex structural organization. Fig 6: Gap junctions were found closely associated with adherens junctions, suggesting a functional relationship.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed visualization of the spatial distribution of synaptic components at electrical synapses, revealing the presence of multiple gap junctions and their association with adherens junctions, which may coordinate the function of these synapses.
novelty: This study provides a new perspective on the structural organization of electrical synapses, revealing a complex arrangement of multiple gap junctions closely associated with adherens junctions. Unlike previous expansion microscopy studies, this work highlights the intricate spatial distribution of synaptic components, offering insights into the functional diversity of electrical synapses. The use of expansion microscopy allowed for a detailed map of synaptic proteins, surpassing the resolution limitations of traditional microscopy and providing a complementary view to electron microscopy.

title: Volumetric, Nanoscale Optical Imaging of Mouse and Human Kidney via Expansion Microscopy
authors: Tyler J. Chozinski, Chenyi Mao, Aaron R. Halpern, Jeffrey W. Pippin, Stuart J. Shankland, Charles E. Alpers, Behzad Najafian, Joshua C. Vaughan
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the ExM process on mouse kidney tissue, highlighting the need for collagenase digestion to achieve uniform expansion. Fig 2 shows the application of ExM to visualize glomerular structures with immunostaining, resolving podocyte foot processes and other features. Fig 3 quantifies foot process width and GBM thickness, demonstrating the method's ability to provide clinically relevant metrics. Fig 4 extends the method to human kidney tissue, overcoming homogenization challenges with additional elastase digestion.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed volumetric and nanoscale imaging of kidney tissues, allowing for the visualization of structures previously only resolvable by electron microscopy, such as podocyte foot processes and the glomerular basement membrane, using a standard confocal microscope.
novelty: This study presents an optimized ExM protocol for mouse and human kidney tissues, achieving 70-75 nm resolution. Unlike previous methods, it includes a novel homogenization strategy using collagenase and elastase to address the dense extracellular matrix in kidney tissues. This approach provides a cost-effective alternative to electron microscopy, enabling detailed 3D imaging of kidney structures with molecular specificity, which is not possible with traditional super-resolution techniques like STED or SIM due to their limitations in multicolor imaging and depth resolution.
source_file: Volumetric, Nanoscale Optical Imaging of Mouse and Human Kidney via Expansion Microscopy.pdf

title: A Multifunctional Probe for Visualization of the Nanoscale Distribution of Cholesterol in Cells by Expansion Microscopy
authors: Gang Wen, Dominic A. Helmerich, Lisa Behringer-Pließ, Markus Sauer
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the synthesis and application of a multifunctional cholesterol probe for ExM, showing improved fluorescence in low FBS conditions. Fig 2 illustrates the use of TREx-Airyscan SR and TREx-SIM to visualize cholesterol aggregates in late endosomes/lysosomes with high resolution. Fig 3 tracks cholesterol distribution changes in endocytic pathways using 4x ExM, highlighting colocalization with LAMP1. Fig 4 examines cholesterol distribution in clathrin-coated pits, indicating non-clathrin-dependent internalization pathways.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of cholesterol distribution in cells at different time points with high spatial resolution, allowing for the tracking of cholesterol dynamics in endocytic pathways and its colocalization with cellular markers.
novelty: This study introduces a multifunctional cholesterol probe that can be fixed and labeled for ExM, overcoming limitations of previous cholesterol probes that could not be covalently trapped. The combination of 10x ExM with super-resolution techniques like Airyscan and SIM provides unprecedented resolution of cholesterol aggregates, distinguishing this work from prior ExM variants and super-resolution methods. The use of a fixable probe that remains stable during chemical fixation and permeabilization represents a significant advancement in visualizing lipid distribution at the nanoscale.

title: Controlled Grafting Expansion Microscopy
authors: Ria Thielhorn, Isabelle Heing-Becker, Nadja Hümpfer, Jakob Rentsch, Rainer Haag, Kai Licha, Helge Ewers
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the development of a trifunctional probe combining targeting, fluorescent labeling, and gel linkage to improve fluorescence signal retention in ExM. Fig 2 compares the stability and retention of the new BG-TMR-MA dye against SNAP-Cell TMR-Star, showing superior retention with increased AcX concentration. Fig 3 demonstrates the resolution of nuclear pores using the new dye in ExM compared to STED microscopy. Fig 4 explores local delivery of AcX to enhance dye retention and expansion factor, highlighting the importance of grafting in ExM. Fig 5 presents a model explaining the role of surface grafting in dye retention, emphasizing the need for controlled grafting strategies.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of nuclear pores with subdiffraction resolution using conventional spinning disc confocal microscopy, demonstrating the potential for high-resolution imaging of cellular structures with improved fluorescence signal retention.
novelty: This work introduces a trifunctional probe that combines targeting, fluorescent labeling, and gel linkage in a single molecule, addressing the challenge of fluorescence signal loss in ExM. The use of a rhodamine-based dye with an acrylate moiety allows for superior dye retention compared to previous methods. The study highlights the importance of surface grafting for effective dye incorporation into the hydrogel, offering a new strategy for controlled grafting in ExM. This approach provides a significant improvement over traditional immunostaining and enhances the resolution and brightness of ExM, making it comparable to STED microscopy.

title: PAExM: label-free hyper-resolution photoacoustic expansion microscopy
authors: Hyojin Kim, Jin Woo Baik, Seungwan Jeon, Jin Young Kim, Chulhong Kim
summary: Fig 1: Developed a high-speed reflection-mode UV-PAM system for label-free imaging. Fig 2: Demonstrated enhanced resolution of expanded mouse brain sections, showing better separation of nuclei. Fig 3: Showed volumetric expansion and improved nuclear separation in expanded samples. Fig 4: Highlighted optical sectioning capability post-expansion, revealing detailed volumetric architecture.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of densely distributed cell nuclei in mouse brain sections without staining, improving the separation capability of UV-PAM by increasing internuclear distances through tissue expansion.
novelty: This study introduces PAExM, combining photoacoustic microscopy with tissue expansion to achieve label-free imaging of cell nuclei with enhanced resolution. Unlike traditional UV-PAM, which struggles with closely adjacent nuclei, PAExM leverages tissue expansion to improve separation without the need for fluorescent labeling. This approach offers a significant advancement over previous ExM variants by maintaining intrinsic optical absorption characteristics, thus avoiding complications from additional staining processes. The work demonstrates a novel application of expansion microscopy in conjunction with photoacoustic imaging, providing a new tool for histological studies with potential preclinical and clinical applications.

title: Expansion microscopy revealed specific impacts of nano zinc oxide on early organ development in fish
authors: Mengyu Wang, Wen-Xiong Wang
summary: Fig 1 shows the experimental design and Zn accumulation in fish, highlighting the impact of different Zn diets. Fig 2 presents expansion microscopy images of medaka retinal parts, revealing developmental differences due to Zn exposure. Fig 3 illustrates the skeletal muscle system's response to Zn diets, with significant differences in muscle cell area and spinal cord density. Fig 4 focuses on intestinal microvilli, showing how Zn diets affect their length. Fig 5 and 6 provide RNA-sequencing results, identifying differentially expressed genes and pathways affected by Zn exposure.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization and quantification of the subtle developmental toxicities of nano zinc oxide (nZnO) and Zn2+ across different fish organs, providing a novel perspective for evaluating the toxicity of nanomaterials.
novelty: This study applies expansion microscopy (ExM) to achieve nanoscale imaging of organ development in fish, specifically assessing the toxicity of nZnO. Unlike traditional methods, ExM allows for direct quantification of toxic effects on cells at different developmental stages with nanoscale resolution. The study highlights the differential toxicity of nZnO and Zn2+ on various organ systems, emphasizing the need for comprehensive risk assessment strategies. This approach offers a new tool for understanding the toxicological impacts of nanomaterials, surpassing the limitations of conventional imaging techniques.
source_file: Expansion microscopy revealed specific impacts of nano zinc oxide on early organ development in fish.pdf

title: Expansion Microscopy with Multifunctional Polymer Dots
authors: Jie Liu, Xiaofeng Fang, Zhihe Liu, Rongqin Li, Yicheng Yang, Yujie Sun, Zhongying Zhao, Changfeng Wu
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the design of multifunctional polymer dots (Pdots) for ExM, highlighting their ability to target, anchor, and report fluorescence. Fig 2 shows the high-fidelity imaging of microtubules and neuron synapses using Pdots, emphasizing the resolution enhancement post-expansion. Fig 3 illustrates the combination of ExM with SOFI, achieving subcellular resolution of ≈30 nm, showcasing the potential of Pdots in super-resolution imaging.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of subcellular structures and neuron synapses with high brightness and specificity using multifunctional polymer dots (Pdots) in expansion microscopy. The Pdots facilitated multicolor imaging and improved fluorescence retention, allowing for detailed examination of biological samples at nanoscale resolution.
novelty: This study introduces multifunctional polymer dots (Pdots) that enhance expansion microscopy (ExM) by providing high brightness and efficient anchoring. Compared to previous ExM variants, the Pdots offer improved fluorescence retention and multicolor imaging capabilities. The integration with super-resolution optical fluctuation imaging (SOFI) further enhances resolution to ≈30 nm, surpassing traditional ExM methods. The use of Pdots represents a significant advancement in ExM, enabling detailed visualization of subcellular structures and neuron synapses.
source_file: Advanced Materials - 2021 - Liu - Expansion Microscopy with Multifunctional Polymer Dots.pdf

title: Nanoscale imaging using differential expansion microscopy
authors: Sebastian P. Pernal, Asiri Liyanaarachchi, Domenico L. Gatti, Brent Formosa, Rishika Pulvender, Eric R. Kuhn, Rafael Ramos, Akshata R. Naik, Kathleen George, Suzan Arslanturk, Douglas J. Taatjes, Bhanu P. Jena
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the optimized fixation protocol for rat liver tissue, achieving up to eightfold expansion while retaining cellular morphology. Fig 2 shows anisotropic expansion in human skeletal muscle cells, highlighting differential expansion between nucleus and myosin fibers. Fig 3 presents a computational pipeline for analyzing DiExM images, confirming anisotropic expansion and enabling precise morphometric assessments. Fig 4 compares the new protocol with previous methods, emphasizing improved expansion and antigen retention.
application_goal: The protocol enabled precise, rapid, and inexpensive diagnosis of disease from pathological specimen slides by achieving significant expansion of biological samples while retaining structural integrity and antigenicity, allowing for detailed morphometric analysis at the nanoscale.
novelty: This study introduces differential expansion microscopy (DiExM), which achieves greater than 500-fold volumetric expansion with improved antigen retention compared to previous ExM methods. The protocol optimizes fixation and polymer loading, allowing for anisotropic expansion analysis of tissues and organelles. Unlike prior ExM variants, DiExM combines expansion with machine learning to assess cellular states, offering a novel approach for diagnostic pathology.

antibodies_and_dyes.name: mouse monoclonal heavy chain primary antibody

title: Expansion microscopy reveals nano-scale insights into the human neuromuscular junction
authors: Abdullah Ramadan, Thomas M.D. Sheard, Abrar Alhindi, Philippa A. Rust, Ross A. Jones, Izzy Jayasinghe, Thomas H. Gillingwater
summary: Fig 1 shows expanded NMJs from mouse and human muscle biopsies, highlighting differences in AChR and SV2 distribution. Fig 2 compares pre- and post-expansion NMJs, confirming a 4x expansion factor. Fig 3 demonstrates the enhanced resolution of NMJ ultrastructure using ExM compared to standard confocal microscopy. Fig 4 illustrates the effect of deconvolution on ExM images, improving contrast and noise reduction. Fig 5 provides quantitative analysis of AChR stripes, revealing significant differences between human and mouse NMJs. Fig 6 and 7 explore the spatial relationship between AChRs, SV2, and NaV1.4 channels, highlighting species-specific differences in NMJ architecture.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution imaging of neuromuscular junctions in both human and mouse tissues, revealing species-specific differences in the distribution of acetylcholine receptors, synaptic vesicles, and NaV1.4 channels. This approach provides a cost-effective alternative to super-resolution microscopy, allowing for detailed structural analysis of NMJs without the need for specialized equipment.
novelty: This study demonstrates the adaptation of expansion microscopy for use with human and mouse neuromuscular junctions, providing nano-scale insights comparable to super-resolution methods. The work highlights the ability of ExM to reveal detailed structural differences between species, such as the distribution of AChRs and NaV1.4 channels, which were previously difficult to observe with conventional microscopy. The use of a 4x expansion factor and the application of ExM to whole-mount muscle biopsy samples represent significant advancements in the field, offering a more accessible and cost-effective approach to high-resolution imaging.

title: Aptamer-Based Cell Nucleus Imaging via Expansion Microscopy
authors: Yue Sun, Zhicheng Zhang, Tao Bing, Jing Liu, Weiwei Li, Xiangjun Liu, Nan Zhang, Yang Shu, Jianhua Wang, Dihua Shangguan
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the expansion of polyacrylamide gel and the clear imaging of expanded nuclei using Ac-Ch4−1-FAM. Fig 2 shows the colocalization of Ac-Ch4−1-FAM with nuclear dyes and histone antibodies, highlighting the aptamer's specificity. Fig 3 illustrates the imaging of nuclei at different mitotic stages, revealing chromatin morphology and nucleolus structure. The study emphasizes the aptamer's role in simplifying the ExM process and achieving high-resolution imaging.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution imaging of cell nuclei by using an aptamer-based expansion microscopy strategy. This approach simplifies the traditional ExM process by using a dual-labeled aptamer for direct gel anchoring and fluorescence reporting, allowing for clear visualization of chromatin morphology and nucleolus structure at different mitotic stages.
novelty: This study introduces an aptamer-based ExM strategy that simplifies the traditional immunolabeling and chemical handle labeling process. By using a dual-labeled aptamer, the method achieves a resolution of ∼70 nm, comparable to other ExM techniques, but with a more straightforward procedure. The use of aptamers for direct gel anchoring and fluorescence reporting is a novel approach that enhances the efficiency and specificity of ExM, particularly for imaging nuclear structures.

title: Antibiotics: Methods and Protocols, Second Edition
authors: Peter Sass
summary: Fig 1: Structures of exemplary antibiotics are shown, highlighting their diverse modes of action. Fig 2: The inhibition of cell wall biosynthesis in Staphylococcus aureus by antibiotics is depicted, emphasizing the importance of targeting bacterial cell walls. Fig 3: Target sites of protein biosynthesis inhibitors are illustrated, showcasing how antibiotics interfere with bacterial protein synthesis. Fig 4: The mechanism of action of ADEP antibiotics is detailed, demonstrating their unique ability to deregulate ClpP proteolytic activity, leading to bacterial cell death.
application_goal: The protocol enables the identification and characterization of novel antibiotics with unique modes of action, such as teixobactin and ADEP antibiotics, which target essential bacterial processes and structures, offering potential solutions to combat antibiotic-resistant bacteria.
novelty: This work highlights the discovery and characterization of antibiotics with novel mechanisms of action, such as teixobactin, which targets lipid II and III, and ADEP antibiotics, which activate ClpP proteolytic activity. These findings contrast with traditional antibiotics that primarily inhibit enzymatic functions, offering new strategies to overcome resistance. The study emphasizes the potential of targeting non-traditional pathways and structures, such as riboswitches and the BAM complex, to develop antibiotics with resistance-breaking properties.

title: A Multifunctional Anchor for Multimodal Expansion Microscopy
authors: Yi Cui, Gaojie Yang, Daniel R. Goodwin, Ciara H. O'Flanagan, Anubhav Sinha, Chi Zhang, Kristina E. Kitko, Demian Park, Samuel Aparicio, IMAXT Consortium, Edward S. Boyden
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the use of GMA as a multifunctional anchor for ExM, enabling simultaneous detection of proteins and RNAs in mouse brain tissue and cultured cells. Fig 2 characterizes the resolution improvement and RNA retention efficiency of uniExM, showing nearly 100% RNA retention. Fig 3 explores the preservation of protein ultrastructure, specifically the periodic distribution of βII-spectrin in neurons, using uniExM. Fig 4 showcases the application of uniExM in in situ RNA sequencing (ExSeq) in PDX breast cancer tissue, revealing spatial heterogeneity in gene expression.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the simultaneous anchoring and visualization of multiple biomolecular species, such as proteins and RNAs, in a single experimental step, simplifying the ExM process and reducing costs. This unified approach supports multimodal nanoscale analysis of cells and tissues, facilitating high-resolution imaging and spatial transcriptomics.
novelty: This study introduces a novel epoxide-based anchoring strategy using glycidyl methacrylate (GMA) that simplifies the ExM process by allowing multiple biomolecular species to be anchored in a single step. Compared to previous methods requiring different anchors for proteins and RNAs, this approach reduces complexity and cost. The uniExM protocol maintains high resolution and retention efficiency, supporting applications like ExSeq for spatial transcriptomics. This work advances ExM by providing a versatile and cost-effective method for multimodal imaging, potentially broadening its applicability in biological research.

title: Pre-gelation staining expansion microscopy (PS-ExM) for visualization of the Plasmodium liver stage
authors: Kodzo Atchou, Bianca Manuela Berger, Volker Heussler, Torsten Ochsenreiter
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the isotropic five-fold expansion of Plasmodium liver stage parasites using PS-ExM, highlighting the preservation of cell morphology. Fig 2 explores the interaction between Plasmodium liver stage parasites and host cell lysosomes, showing lysosome association with the parasitophorous vacuole membrane (PVM). The study emphasizes the protocol's ability to visualize host-pathogen interactions, providing insights into the Plasmodium liver stage development.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of intracellular Plasmodium parasites during liver stage development, allowing for the study of host-pathogen interactions, such as lysosome association with the parasitophorous vacuole membrane. This approach provides a deeper understanding of the Plasmodium liver stage, which is crucial for developing anti-malaria interventions.
novelty: This study introduces a pre-gelation staining expansion microscopy (PS-ExM) protocol that adapts the ultrastructure expansion microscopy (U-ExM) for pre-stained samples. Compared to traditional U-ExM, PS-ExM reduces incubation times and better preserves epitopes, allowing for simultaneous non-expanded controls. This method is particularly advantageous for studying host-pathogen interactions in the Plasmodium liver stage, offering a faster and potentially more epitope-preserving alternative to existing ExM protocols.

title: Expansion microscopy using a single anchor molecule for high-yield multiplexed imaging of proteins and RNAs
authors: Yi Cui, Gaojie Yang, Daniel R. Goodwin, Ciara H. O’Flanagan, Anubhav Sinha, Chi Zhang, Kristina E. Kitko, Tay Won Shin, Demian Park, Samuel Aparicio, CRUK IMAXT Grand Challenge Consortium, Edward S. Boyden
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the use of a multifunctional epoxide anchor for simultaneous protein and RNA retention in ExM, showing improved signal retention compared to traditional methods. Fig 2 characterizes the resolution and distortion of the uniExM protocol, confirming submicron resolution and minimal distortion. Fig 3 highlights the preservation of protein ultrastructure, specifically the periodic distribution of βII-spectrin in neurons, using the uniExM protocol. Fig 4 showcases the application of uniExM in ExSeq, enabling high-resolution spatial transcriptomics in PDX cancer tissues, revealing tumor heterogeneity.
application_goal: The uniExM protocol enabled the simultaneous expansion and visualization of proteins and RNAs in a single experimental step, simplifying the process and reducing costs compared to previous methods. This approach facilitates multimodal nanoscale analysis of biological samples, supporting applications in spatial transcriptomics and high-resolution imaging of complex tissues.
novelty: This study introduces a unified anchoring strategy using glycidyl methacrylate (GMA) for expansion microscopy, allowing for the simultaneous retention of proteins and RNAs. This approach simplifies the ExM protocol by eliminating the need for separate anchoring steps for different biomolecules, reducing complexity and cost. Compared to previous methods, uniExM offers improved signal retention and compatibility with high-resolution imaging techniques, such as ExSeq, for spatial transcriptomics. The use of a single anchor molecule represents a significant advancement in the field, enabling broader applications in biological research.
source_file: Expansion microscopy using a single anchor molecule for high-yield multiplexed imaging of proteins and RNAs.pdf

title: TissUExM enables quantitative ultrastructural analysis in whole vertebrate embryos by expansion microscopy
authors: Emmanuelle Steib, Rob Tetley, Romain F. Laine, Dominic P. Norris, Yanlan Mao, Julien Vermot
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates TissUExM's ability to expand whole embryos and preserve ultrastructural details, crucial for studying endogenous proteins. Fig 2 explores ciliary architecture in zebrafish, revealing tissue-specific diversity and structural details previously limited to electron microscopy. Fig 3 extends TissUExM to Drosophila and mouse models, confirming its versatility and ability to resolve organelles at super-resolution. The study highlights TissUExM's potential for detailed ultrastructural analysis in various biological models.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the quantitative ultrastructural analysis of whole vertebrate embryos, allowing for the localization of endogenous proteins in high-density environments. This method facilitates the study of ciliary architecture and other organelles in situ, providing insights into developmental processes and potential pathological features.
novelty: TissUExM represents a significant advancement over previous ExM methods by enabling the expansion of mechanically heterogeneous tissues like whole embryos. Unlike traditional ExM, which often struggles with large samples, TissUExM maintains tissue integrity and allows for post-expansion labeling, enhancing the resolution of endogenous protein complexes. This method surpasses prior techniques by offering a versatile approach applicable to multiple model organisms, including zebrafish, mouse, and Drosophila, and provides a new avenue for studying complex biological systems at the nanoscale.
source_file: TissUExM enables quantitative ultrastructural analysis in whole vertebrate embryos by expansion microscopy.pdf

title: Expansion sequencing: Spatially precise in situ transcriptomics in intact biological systems
authors: Shahar Alon, Daniel R. Goodwin, Anubhav Sinha, Asmamaw T. Wassie, Fei Chen, Evan R. Daugharthy, Yosuke Bando, Atsushi Kajita, Andrew G. Xue, Karl Marrett, Robert Prior, Yi Cui, Andrew C. Payne, Chun-Chen Yao, Ho-Jun Suk, Ru Wang, Chih-Chieh (Jay) Yu, Paul Tillberg, Paul Reginato, Nikita Pak, Songlei Liu, Sukanya Punthambaker, Eswar P. R. Iyer, Richie E. Kohman, Jeremy A. Miller, Ed S. Lein, Ana Lako, Nicole Cullen, Scott Rodig, Karla Helvie, Daniel L. Abravanel, Nikhil Wagle, Bruce E. Johnson, Johanna Klughammer, Michal Slyper, Julia Waldman, Judit Jané-Valbuena, Orit Rozenblatt-Rosen, Aviv Regev, IMAXT Consortium, George M. Church, Adam H. Marblestone, Edward S. Boyden
summary: Fig 1: The authors developed expansion sequencing (ExSeq) to enable in situ sequencing of RNA with high spatial precision, allowing for nanoscale resolution mapping of RNAs in tissues. Fig 2: Untargeted ExSeq was applied to mouse hippocampal neurons, revealing the presence of various RNA types, including intron-retaining transcripts. Fig 3: ExSeq was used to map RNA distributions in dendrites, showing spatially distinct patterns of RNA localization. Fig 4: Targeted ExSeq was used to map cell types in the mouse visual cortex, identifying layer-specific cell types. Fig 5: ExSeq revealed nanoscale RNA compartmentalization in mouse hippocampal neurons, highlighting differences in RNA distribution between dendrites and spines. Fig 6: In a human metastatic breast cancer biopsy, ExSeq mapped gene expression differences in cell types based on proximity to other cell types, providing insights into tumor microenvironment interactions.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the spatially precise mapping of RNA molecules in intact tissues, allowing for the study of RNA localization at nanoscale resolution. This capability is crucial for understanding the spatial organization of gene expression in complex biological systems, such as the brain and tumors, and can provide insights into cellular interactions and functions.
novelty: This work introduces expansion sequencing (ExSeq), which combines expansion microscopy with in situ sequencing to achieve nanoscale resolution of RNA mapping in tissues. Unlike previous methods that either offered high spatial resolution or high molecular multiplexing, ExSeq provides both, enabling detailed mapping of RNA distributions in complex tissues. The study demonstrates the utility of ExSeq in various biological contexts, including the mouse brain and human cancer biopsies, highlighting its potential to reveal new insights into cellular organization and interactions.
source_file: Expansion sequencing- Spatially precise in situ transcriptomics in intact biological systems.pdf

title: Hybrid Structured Illumination Expansion Microscopy Reveals Microbial Cytoskeleton Organization
authors: Aaron R. Halpern, Germain C. M. Alas, Tyler J. Chozinski, Alexander R. Paredez, Joshua C. Vaughan
summary: Fig 1: ExSIM method overview, highlighting its simplicity and compatibility with conventional probes. Fig 2: ExSIM resolves Giardia's adhesive disc microtubules, revealing a spiral array and DAP86676 localization. Fig 3: DAP16263 localization in the disc overlap zone, suggesting a structural role. Fig 4: ExSIM resolves axoneme microtubule substructure, identifying DAP16263 in the paraflagellar rod.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of Giardia lamblia's cytoskeleton at a resolution of ~30 nm, revealing detailed structures of the adhesive disc and flagellar axonemes, which were previously unresolvable with conventional methods.
novelty: This study introduces ExSIM, combining expansion microscopy with structured illumination microscopy to achieve ~30 nm resolution, comparable to STED and SMLM but with simpler sample preparation. The method successfully resolves dense microtubule arrays and localizes proteins within Giardia lamblia, offering a powerful tool for studying nanoscale structures in microbial pathogens.
source_file: Hybrid Structured Illumination Expansion Microscopy Reveals Microbial Cytoskeleton Organization.pdf

title: Uniform distribution of photosystems in dark-adapted Synechocystis cells
authors: Peter R. Bos, Elio Langlois – Legrand, Emilie Wientjes
summary: Fig 1: Cryo-ExM was used to resolve thylakoid layers in Synechocystis cells, showing clear separation. Fig 2: Immunostaining localized PSI, PSII, and PBS to thylakoid membranes, indicating homogeneous distribution. Fig 3: Pearson's coefficient analysis showed high colocalization of PSI, PSII, and PBS, suggesting no microdomains. Fig 4: In dividing cells, phycocyanin was absent in connecting regions, indicating spatial exclusion during division.
application_goal: The protocol enabled visualization of individual thylakoid membranes and mapping of photosynthetic complexes in Synechocystis, providing insights into their spatial organization without evidence of microdomains.
novelty: This study introduces cryo-ExM for visualizing cyanobacterial thylakoid membranes, achieving a 5.5-fold expansion that allows resolution of structures down to 60 nm. Unlike previous methods, cryo-ExM does not require cell wall-degrading enzymes and provides a homogeneous distribution of photosystems, contrasting with reports of microdomains in other studies. The method's ability to maintain cell shape and enhance immunolabeling intensity marks a significant advancement over traditional ExM and super-resolution techniques.

title: Lipid Expansion Microscopy
authors: Brittany M. White, Pratik Kumar, Amanda N. Conwell, Kane Wu, Jeremy M. Baskin
summary: In Fig 1, the authors introduce LExM, a method for anchoring phospholipids to a hydrogel network for super-resolution imaging. Fig 2 demonstrates the expansion and visualization of cellular membranes using LExM, achieving expansion factors of 6.8x and 4.9x. Fig 3 shows LExM's ability to resolve organelle membranes and colocalize with organelle markers. Fig 4 extends LExM to visualize low-abundance signaling lipids using IMPACT labeling. Fig 5 applies LExM to study nuclear invaginations, revealing detailed structures previously limited to electron microscopy.
application_goal: The protocol enabled super-resolution imaging of phospholipids within cellular membranes without the need for detergent-based permeabilization, preserving membrane integrity and allowing for detailed visualization of organelle membranes and subcellular structures.
novelty: LExM introduces a novel approach to expansion microscopy by using small-molecule reagents for direct chemical anchoring of metabolically labeled phospholipids, avoiding the need for detergent-based permeabilization. This method allows for tunable and isotropic expansion, providing high-resolution imaging of lipids and membranes with standard confocal microscopes. Compared to prior ExM variants, LExM offers a more accessible and less invasive technique for visualizing lipid structures, expanding the potential for super-resolution imaging in various physiological contexts.
